content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I have had some mixed feelings about this game, but then again this happens for a lot of horror games I've played. I'm not a big fan of jumpscares as I feel them being a cheap way to enthrill. Then again I've played this game through 3 times and the reason for that is that this game has a very good gameplay. It has some mediocre issues in storytelling and atmosphere that prevents this being an outstanding game. Instead, this is just good.I have played all parts of the series, except third installement is still uncompleted. Then again the third one didn't seem to have anything to do with the first one so I though I might as well review this now.The plot of the game is pretty generic. In space no one can hear you scream. Weird monsters invade space ship and the protagonist must fight back after their immediate escape possibilities are cut down. Plot starts immediately and isn't very surprising at any point. Player travels back and forth in the ship doing stuff while other characters in the game stand still and cry. Kendra Daniels is one of the most annoying side characters I've so far seen or heard in a game.The part where this game excels is that it makes the playing part fun, although the plot is uninsteresting. By giving the possibility to cut limbs instead of just shooting aliens, this game makes the fights somewhat more interesting and more pleasing. In a fight with multiple enemies, one can shoot their legs off before move to finishing them with another weapon. Also by making playable character a walker instead of a runner, the game is much better paced than some other horror games. Sure he can run, but he cannot shoot while running and running usually ends in a situation where a necromorph is close enough to hug Isaac.Then again even though the pacing excels, this is yet another example where I think the game could've used a real director(like movies have). Though the game tries to be a horror game, it rarely excels in it. Most of the enemies are given away by loud roars or sudden violin sounds. Basically player just turns to where ever the sound came and shoots. Some jump scares are not enough to call it a horror game. It's a jump-scare-game. I'm not afraid of jumpscare, I just don't like them, like sewage. The game loses a lot of atmosphere by doing this. Games scaries part are the vacuum scenarios where no sound is played, so one must stay alert all the time for the enemy. Also there are occasionally so many enemies that I felt like playing a shooter instead of atmospheric horro game.The game is really cheap today(2,5eur in sales) so no hurt trying. Easiest difficulty setting is enough to take any challenge out of the game if one feels like going it just for the story, although some atmosphere is lost by doing this.To anyone suffering mouse problems, try V-sync out and force v-sync from video driver software or utilities like radeonpro. Also playable without v-sync but some say they've had problems related to one door not opening. Also playing without any kind of vsync might cause coil whine in gpu with FPS running over 200 with better cards(2012 enthusiast ->)I recommend this game as a nice way to pass 8-10 hours, but don't expect anything great out of it. It's solid and it's good enough to give it a try. If you don't like it, don't buy the next installements either, they give nothing more.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												Haven't gotten around to finishing it yet but, if you like scary games, this is definitely the one for you. While it does have some jump scares, like many games of this type do, it doesn't rely on them in any way, shape, or form. Dead Space is all about ambiance. Almost no matter where you go, there's deep dark shadows where things can lurk, twisted and broken scenery from past struggles, gaps in the walls, ceilings, and floors so that you can see the creatures crawling between walls and into vents. Then there's the sound. At all times there's the sounds of loose metal clanking, echoes of transmissions being broadcast and some of the eeriest music you'll find on a game. All of this combines to engender a feeling of constant anxiety while playing.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Dead Space is the classic definition of horror. This game made me feel so uncomfortable and disgusted, yet so attached and interested. It has a good story, filled with mistery and conspiracy. Everything about the game feels right and natural. It delivers a solid gameplay, which consists of exploring and fixing a huge ship, fighting an endless variety of necromorphs, playing with gravity, crafting and upgrading equipment, uncovering the truth about what happened, and just trying to survive. You get to be Isaac Clarke, the "speechless" protagonist of the game, who slowly goes insane while under the effects of a "relic" called - The Marker.    The game's name is the perfect description of how the game feels. Everything seems so cold, so lifeless, diseased and abandoned. Everywhere you look, it's just cold metal walls, dry blood spilled on the floor and doors, rotten bodies everywhere and flickering xenon lights. Aside the ship, there are also times when you have to go "outside". The space looks gorgeous. It's dark and dangerous, but also endlessly beautiful. All of these create an unforgettable atmosphere, full of terror, shock and dementia. I wish I could say "Don't worry, it's not that scarry." But I can't. You will get scared. Even when you tread carefully, trying to notice the vents or ducts from where the necromorphs might come, you'll still get surprised every time. The developers have scripted the game so well, that it's impossible not to get scared. You'll start getting used to the monsters after a while. And when you're letting your guard down for a minute, just when you least expect it, you get a instant heart attack and a broken chair.   Dead Space makes you feel absolutely stranded, alone, but not helpless. The player can choose from a variety of weapons and tools. Which not only look cool, but also behave differently. And each of those weapons can be found and upgraded at the Work Benches. You also get to use Kinesis, which is totally awesome. Especially when combined with the Stasis. But what I liked the most most, was the suit. The RIG, as they call it, can also be upgraded and augumented. I just loved it. It looked so armored and heavy, and cold. But also so very cool and protective. The game becomes more challenging as you progress. There are new types of monsters lurking the corridors, wishing to get their... hands/paws/claws/teeth/blades/tails/tentacles/quills/proboscis/pustules and other limbs around your neck. But besides all those gruesome and brutal deaths, there are also other things that can and will kill you if you're not careful enough. Such as getting hit with some massive spinning tethers, getting electrocuted, running out of air, being hit with a meteorite, jumping into open space, and my personal favorite - getting crushed by a door. That's just what I remember anyway. But I'm sure there's a lot more to choose from.    Another absolutely great feature of this game is the sound and music. Everything sounds just right. Shooting sounds awesome. Stomping and punching the necromorphs feels so very satisfying, because I always found myself crushing every body I saw. Which is a little strange come to think of it... Oh, and the music. I don't know if you can really call it music, because it's mainly a series of very well done ambient soundtracks. Always tensionate, rhythmic, and terror-inducing. Nothing scares me more than a rotten-baby-tentacle-monster jumping on me, while some extremely loud and terrifying chimes are playing on the background. But it was also... fun. I liked to be scared. And if you like to be scared too, this is it my friend.   Although this game was made back in 2008, it looks fantastic. It has got awesome lightning, good-looking models and a most satisfying dismembering system. You can literally tear someone's limbs apart, one by one. And a good physics engine that allows you to do a lot of crazy stuff with those gravity boots.   Finally, a must play. It's a shame I haven't played this a long time ago. This game delivers an amazing experience, full of horror and action. With a good story and lovely sound design.   You need to hear this.  10/10

content:
Posted: January 14
												Dead Space is one of those horror games that EVERYONE should own. The entire trilogy is worth every penny spent. The first game isn't perfect. It's flawed, it has issues, it's not really scary - but it's a damn good game.GRAPHICS: Visually, the game has aged quite a bit, but the graphics do their job. The game is every much as visceral and gory and disgusting as you could want, filled with Saw-like moments that leave you wanting to throw up.SOUND/MUSIC: The musical score isn't too special, but it does its job. Most of the soundtrack is composed of typical horror themes that play during jump scare moments. The sound design, however, is fantastic - every monster, gun, creak and groan of the ship; all of them set you on edge. There's never a moment where you feel safe, even on the easiest difficulty with the most maxed out character you could ever create. It's simply a wonder for horror fans.STORY: Story-wise, Dead Space is possibly one of the most unoriginal pieces ever conceived. If Ridley Scott's Alien was merely Jaws in space, then Dead Space is just Ridley Scott's Alien but with zombies. The plot is predictable, the characters on-dimensional and unlikable in every conceivable way, and the twists and turns so dull and emotionless that it makes M. Night Shyamalan look good by comparison. This game isn't really going to satisfy people searching for deep, interesting, unique lore by any stretch, but it's good enough to compel you to complete the game.GAMEPLAY: This is where the game flops - or at least, the PC version does. I played Dead Space on the Xbox 360 long before I had a functioning PC that could run anything more demanding than Solitare, and even then, the gameplay was clunky, but it at least worked. The PC version seems like it wasn't tested at all. The mouse and keyboard controls are abysmal and practically broken. The aiming in particular is so bugged that it's nearly impossible to hit your targets without wasting half of your ammo, and when it comes to the Dead Space formula (shoot off the limbs) that requires precision, it's absolutely ludicrous that the developers would skimp out on testing the most important part of the game. The Dead Space franchise has always had stellar gameplay: there's no hud, leaving you to see your health meter, ammo, and other such important pieces of information on your guns or armour. The gameplay consists of strategically shooting the limbs off of your opponents, and it's a blast to play, but even when I plug my Xbox controller into my PC, the port simply barely works. I've played this game for years, and can't even begin to count the amount of unnecessary deaths I've experienced on the PC port due to bad controls that hindered my ability to aim. The sad part is, I TRULY love this game, but with controls that are so dysfunctional, I doubt that I'll ever pick it up on my PC again.I wish there was an in-between rating, because the game is DEFINITELY worth playing, but people should be warned about the bad controls. Overall, if you can find a series of mods that will keep you from destroying your PC from the rage that this game will put you through due to the devs refusing to test it out, then you should DEFINITELY buy it.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful26 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Dead Space is a survival horror game where you play a mute space engineer named Isaac Clarke. Isaac is a tragic character. When he was a child, malfunctioning SecuRom DRM prevented him from playing his favourite game. This traumatised him so badly he never spoke again. Although he occasionally yells "Fark EA", but nobody knows what that means.Isaac and his team are on their way to the Japanese mining ship USG Kutabare because a rare Pokemon that they want has been spotted on board. The USG Kutabare is a huge Chinko class mining ship that strip mines entire planets for rare minerals like Tiberium, Adamantium, Kryptonium and Unobtanium. Also, Isaac's attractive girlfriend Nicole is there and he's hoping to catch up with her for some surreptitious zero-gravity nookie.When they arrive near the USG Kutabare they suspect that something is wrong. Not only is the mining ship not responding, there are no Greenpeace ships in sight and no environmental activists chaining themselves to asteroids. Unbeknownst to Isaac and his team, something has indeed gone horribly wrong on board the ship, and its status is now officially 'clitical[www.engrish.com]'. That means 'seriously bad' in Japanese.Upon docking, they find the ship strangely deserted, and this is where the true horror begins. Some chick named Kendra starts telling Isaac what to do despite her not being his girlfriend or his wife. Isaac go get the keycard. Isaac go open that door. Isaac go fix the tram. Isaac put the toilet seat down. Isaac has to do everything she says. Seriously scary stuff. Admittedly Kendra is rather hot and perhaps Isaac is hoping to catch up with her for some surreptitious zero-gravity nookie.Anyway after much faffing about, Isaac discovers a sinister conspiracy involving the colony on the planet below. Hoping that there might be some colonist's daughters he could rescue from their virginity, he decides to investigate further. Apparently the colonists found an ancient alien obelisk thousands of years old. They also unearthed a box of McDonald's Cheeseburgers buried in the dirt that was also thousands of years old, but still edible. However no one was impressed because you could still buy McDonald's Cheeseburgers from the colony cafeteria that were older than that.During the excavation of the alien obelisk, the colonists accidentally released a contagious alien saprophytic parasite that contaminated the entire colony. This insidious alien parasite is not only highly virulent but capable of transforming corpses into monsterous human-porkchop hybrids called Necrochops. Mistaking the alien parasite for Curry Vindaloo, the colonists ate most of it during their Thanksgiving celebrations and were sadly all transformed into slavering monsters. Dumb♥♥♥♥♥colonists.Following in the footsteps of horror themed luminaries such as the F.E.A.R. and Residential Evil series, Dead Space is certainly not an original concept. What it does do incredibly well however is the atmosphere. Soft, almost indistinct susurration permeate the ship. Corpses, severed limbs, and other unidentified viscera litter the claustrophobic corridors. Blood splatters decorate the walls like the abstract art of some deranged artist. Lights flicker and occasionally go out. The feeling of paranoia, dread, and unease is palpable. This is the closest you'll ever get to the experience of being afraid and alone on a desolated ship beset by monsters. Other than going on a Contiki Cruise as an attractive nubile female.There are obligatory jump-scares, although they are used sparringly and not ingeminated to the point of banality. Incidentally, never trust corpses. Not because they send scam emails but because some of them have a disconcerting habit of re-animating at inopportune times. Conveniently, Isaac has a stomp attack and it's your sacred duty to stomp every single corpse into so much tenderised porkchop. It's the only way to be sure.Because Isaac is only an engineer, and not some tough Space Marine, most of his weapons are construction equipment that he uses in ways that contravene every single Health & Safety regulation in existence. Who would have thought the humble Plasma Cutter would be a good for impromptu face reconstruction surgery. But desperate times and all that. Fortunately for Isaac, he's on a Japanese ship and you can buy everything from ubiquitous vending machines; from dangerous weapons and ammunition to schoolgirl panties.The action of Dead Space is similar to the tactical 3rd-person aim-shoot style of Resident Evil instead of the FPS run-and-gun style of F.E.A.R. and Bioshock. What Dead Space does uniquely is the innovative selective dismemberment combat system where the good old Double Tap head-shot just doesn't cut it anymore. Severing the various articulated appendages of your target is the key to victory. Isaac also gets a stasis ability that allows him to violate the Laws of Physics by slowing time. It's used mainly for crowd control when surrounded by Necrochops and useful for getting that perfect sirloin cut.Dead Space has a steep difficulty curve, similar to Bioshock and Resident Evil 4, where the game is initially difficult because of weak weapons and sparse ammunition but gets easier after weapon and suit upgrades. Isaac has a melee attack, but it's about as effective as arguing with strangers on the Internet. Completing the game unlocks a New Game+ mode that allows you to retain your equipment and upgrades in the previous playthrough, but only on the same difficulty. Starting a new game in a higher difficulty resets your equipment back to nothing.Barring a few exceptions, Dead Space has aged rather well. It runs in 1080p with good frame rates and still looks good. However there are some problems with VSync on modern machines that prevents progress but workarounds are available. Also glitchy PhysX can sometimes cause corpses to catapult around the room, but the effect is more hilarious than horrific.Highly recommended for fans of space horror movies like Alien, Event Horizon, Prometheus, and Star Wars VII: The Force Awakens. This is one of those games that is best experienced in the quiet of the night, in a dark room, wearing brown underpants. Also best played alone. In space, no one can hear your girly screams.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												SCARY. That is the short review. Since its been a while since I played it, that is the overrall tone of the game. You play as Isaac, an engineer who just can't catch a break. You go to investigate a ship that has gone dark and is in need of repair. Boy does it need repair. The game has jump scares which I don't find to be a negative because there is tons of others stuff that should creep you out. The ship is a character, as you piece the story together through various videos, documents, and audio journals. It is a creepy story. Also, you feel very alone. Even though you arrive with a small team, it quickly becomes apparent that no one can really help you. I like to think of the monsters as space zombies, and man are they freaky. Instead of the normal pop them in the head method, you have to take care of the limbs instead. There is a nice variety of weapons and armor to keep you on par with the nightmares you face. This is a game meant for playing after 10 PM with a good set of headphones. The ending is great and creepy and gets you ready for Dead Space 2. Even though it relies on shooting and blasting your way through, you will be on pins and needles the whole way through, wondering if your gun is enough to get you through in one piece.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Dead Space is a First Person Shooter-Horror game where you arrive at a Spaceship which has ceased communication and must figure out what has happened to the crew. You make your way through various levels of the ship and learn about the horrors that have taken place, while fighting a variety of creatures who have infested the ship. With monsters that jump out around every corner, the game offers a fast-paced, fright-fest and should not be played by the feint of heart.I don't have to give away any more of the plot as it is a pretty interesting storyline. The learning curve is fairly decent and the game is fun on the hardest settings for the experienced FPS'er. Graphically speaking the game looks pretty good, the lighting is fantastic and adds to the thrill and horror of the gameplay. Dead Space is a good game to purchase and has been successful enough to spawn sequels

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												If you want to play this game, play it on a console.PC version is extremely buggy and crashes frequently. The game was not made to be played with a mouse. Menus are only navigable with arrow keys, mouse sensitivity is ♥♥♥♥ed up, cannot turn off mouse acceleration. Zero-G jumps onto uneven surface or at too shallow an angle consistently causes freezing and death. "Continue" instead of "Load Game" will sometimes change your game difficulty, with no way to change it back.Half way through a run on Hard, I got bugged down to Medium and the game became trivial. There was almost no increase in difficulty for the second half of the game. I spent the entire game drowning in ammo and money. You start with the best weapon in the game; the rest are irrelevant. Very few of my deaths were attributable to enemies. Most of them were environmental deaths, and about half of those were the previously mentioned Zero-G bug. Final boss was underwhelming.Those things aside, the game was okay. Story was decent I guess. Gameplay was fine when not bugging. I had enough fun to finish it, but I'm probably never coming back to it.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Great game its stuff we have already seen before just like the Resident evil series this game will make you poop your pants when you least expect it!. Its not true survival horror its more akin to the arcadey RE4 style of gameplay where you can buy ammo/weapons/health kits from a shop and store your valuable equipment and any supplies you find along the way and you can also upgrade your weapons/suit whenever you find a workbench in game. What sets it apart is definantly its atmosphere every rattle and shadow somehow makes you look around to make sure there isnt a flesh eating alien necro trying to sneek up behind you to claim you as its dinner tonight.A great experience yet im not entirely sure about the replay value as its taken me near 21hrs to complete it on my first playthrough I took my time and explored pretty much everywhere I picked the game up when it was about £4 and can honestly say its worth even the current price of £9.99 Great game, dont forget to wear head phones turn off the lights and have a clean pair of underpants on hand to get the best out the game ;D

												Well, what can I say about this Video Game. It has lots of big spooky monsters. They look like something out of Grandpa's medication induced nightmares. The game has stellar features that even Grandpa can figure out, first there is a stomping feature that allows the main character to open crates on the ground, inside these crates are Arthritis Medicine and bullets for the main gun which shoots lasers (I wish we had this back when we were fighting those damned krauts). This game seemed to cater well to Grandpa's growing Alzheimers, it seems to tell what is going on whenever.What was I talking about again? Oh yes, I believe this nickel is for you, Billy...but don't tell your father I gave this to you, he might put me in a home. (laughs)Grandpa is always proud of you, Billy. Stay in school.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												As a shooter, sure, I can definitely recommend this, but don't go into this game expecting horror. Maybe I'm just not affected by it but I didn't find what I've played so far to be scary in any way. I don't mean that as trying to say I'm tough either. I'd never played a horror game or seen a horror movie before and actually wanted to try one out to see if I'd enjoy it. What I got was dark corridors and the occasional jumpscare. I eventually grew to expect them as well. At one point I was in an elevator and took a few seconds to stretch. When the doors opened I saw a mutant, and wasn't surprised at all. I calmly reached for my mouse and took aim.Again, as a shooter, I think this game does a great job. You're encouraged to stay far from enemies and when you shoot you're told to dismember them for more damage. The game does a pretty good job of setting the atmosphere as well.One fallback I saw with it were the ragdoll physics. Maybe its just the time it came out but they seemed silly. I'd kill an enemy and go to walk past, only to have its body stick between my legs and vibrate. I don't think its that big of a deal, but if you do, be warned.If you're looking for something to scare you I suggest finding something else. However, as a dark mystery sci-fi adventure, I can safely say its not bad.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												Replayed this in 2016 after being reminded by it in the ‘EDGE special edition – the 100 greatest video games’, not having touched it since release. Incredibly it stands up enormously today, both in terms of gameplay, graphics, and story. The integration with the game world is complete, focusing on survival, exploration, and tightly choreographed bouts of intense combat. In particular, the sound and monster design is out of this world, making it just as creepy and unsettling as it was back in 2008. While some critics prefer the sequel, I would liken it to the comparison of the film Alien, and Aliens; essentially suspense vs. action.Of the material that inspired it, Alien I strongly prefer, and if like me, you enjoy being sucked into a realistic world of terror in space, this is the one for you.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												A 2008 game from EA, one of the first games to really take advantage of the atmosphere factor to make a game really immersive and scary, this is an horror game (in a certain way) mixed with some aliens and religious fanatics and you got yourself a mix for a great game.The story was good enough, the gameplay itself was great for that time and it still is, the chapters get kinda repetitive with the same pattern of solving objective and going back to the next area, blah blah, there isnt free will, you follow a linear story so if you dont like linear, ye...But all in all, a good experience and the only criticism to the PC port is the mouse sensitivity issue but there are fixes for that, just check the forums.I bought the Dead Space package and didnt regret it, so my advice is that you do the same and enjoy the crazy adventure of Isaac.8.5/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on May 13, 2011 Event Horizon, Pandorum, Alien, even 2001. All of these films and many other great Sci Fi traditions act as a healthy source base for Dead Space. The game features a distress call, a seemingly silent ship which we quickly realize is dark and full of monsters. Something has gone terribly wrong.The game's carefully crafted atmosphere and surprisingly good voice acting are really what draw you in. Although the plot is very transparent, and the character development (especially for Kendra) is a little weak, the game isn't really about that. It's about living out some version of the space horror fantasy you've had in your head ever since the first time you saw say, Event Horizon. The game has it all, spooky lighting, creepy cultists, a wide array of frightening monsters, and a slowing unfolding backstory involving a typical breakdown of the chain of command and descent into chaos.Playing this game with headphones and in the dark, while alone, even a second time through, is quite an experience. Your heart will pound and you will jump out of your seat.Graphically speaking the game isn't much to look at, and the necromorphs aren't very inspired in their design, although they are scary. Nevertheless, the lighting and audio more than make up for the game's low resolution textures and low poly models.Apart from really wonky object physics, the game feels very good to play as well. The slow turning speed of Isaac, your avatar, contributes to the sense of the game as being about horror/survival, and scavenging is essential. You aren't incredibly vulnerable, especially after upgrades, but you feel like you are, and that's what counts.Ultimately, Dead Space is a surprising and fun guilty pleasure of a game that will remind you of nights spent watching sci-fi horror movies scaring yourself senseless in the dark.

												Great horror game. Gameplay doesn't get boring, mainly because you arent usually aiming for the head like every other shooter. The game also mixes in cool puzzles and turret sections that help keep the game fresh. You feel like a handyman, but you also feel like a badass. If you don't like games where you are alone however, this is NOT the game for you. There is very little interaction with NPC's that aren't enemies.I would recommend this game to anyone who likes a cool futuristic story and art design, and wants to play a tense and scary game too.

												This is a masterpiece of a game and one of my all time favorites, its the thing, event horizon and sillent hill all rolled into one big gore fest, its not the scariest of games but it does cause a few jumps when a creature sneaks up on you and gets up close just as you turn around, and panic can set in when your ammo is nearly spent whilst wiping out a large wave of creatures. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												As a shooter, sure, I can definitely recommend this, but don't go into this game expecting horror. Maybe I'm just not affected by it but I didn't find what I've played so far to be scary in any way. I don't mean that as trying to say I'm tough either. I'd never played a horror game or seen a horror movie before and actually wanted to try one out to see if I'd enjoy it. What I got was dark corridors and the occasional jumpscare. I eventually grew to expect them as well. At one point I was in an elevator and took a few seconds to stretch. When the doors opened I saw a mutant, and wasn't surprised at all. I calmly reached for my mouse and took aim.Again, as a shooter, I think this game does a great job. You're encouraged to stay far from enemies and when you shoot you're told to dismember them for more damage. The game does a pretty good job of setting the atmosphere as well.One fallback I saw with it were the ragdoll physics. Maybe its just the time it came out but they seemed silly. I'd kill an enemy and go to walk past, only to have its body stick between my legs and vibrate. I don't think its that big of a deal, but if you do, be warned.If you're looking for something to scare you I suggest finding something else. However, as a dark mystery sci-fi adventure, I can safely say its not bad.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Dead Space is a game, which ignites my memories of films like Aliens, Lost In Space, and other movies with isolated, or abandoned space vessels.At first I found Dead Space boring, but on my 3rd play-through I eventually got hooked and started to increase further into the game, and story. Dead Space is amazingly eerie, and you have that 'alone' space feeling through-out the main campaign. As I got further into the main story I found myself getting hooked, and thinking to myself 'WOW'! This game is incredible, and for anyone that likes old space movies from the early 80's/90's, then this is the game for you!The plot of Dead Space is simple. You are sent with a crew to investigate a planet mining vessel that sent out a request for help. The game starts with you arriving at that vessel and then you begin to find out what happened, and why the help signal was sent. Not all is as seems however - as the badly damaged vessel seems to be empty upon arrival - Or is it?The story has many twists and turns. It's a story about experimentation, love, and 'what happens when things go wrong'.Dead Space is great! It's thrilling, inventive, and the level-up system, and skill tree is genius.This game is so alike to the scene in 'Lost In Space' when they arrive at the abandoned Space vessel. If you haven't watched Lost In Space, and you haven't played Dead Space - then you NEED to.I rate this game 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Dead Space is one of my all-time favorites, and in a true sense a masterpiece. I bought and played it upon its original release, and it was pretty much bug free and stable out of the box, even if it pushed my trusty old Core2Duo I had then pretty hard.The design choices, story line (augmented by a couple of animated movies ,"Dead Space: Downfall" and "Dead Space: Aftermath"), atmosphere, and gritty industrial Sci-Fi environment, make this a memorable, terrifying, and unique experience. Think of it as an amalgamation of Aliens, Event Horizon, The Thing, and Pandorum. It does have some jump scares, but mainly all the adversaries are manageable, especially since you get to upgrade your gear throughout.You definitely get the feeling of being in space, in particularly due to the very, very awesome Zero-G sequences, and your requirement for Oxygen and the ability to magnetize your boots. This is pretty unique in games, and certainly was a novelty back when Dead Space was released. This is probably the fourth time I've bought the game, for one due to DRM-freeness, and because it's worth it. Of all the games published by EA over the years, the Dead Space (and Mass Effect) franchises are certainly one of the best games ever made.In fact, the only negative I have to say about Dead Space is the ridiculous control/button assignments. Being left handed I do not use WASD, I use the cursor, and surrounding keys, and Dead Space isn't very helpful there. I had to get a program called GlovePIE which I've had to use a few times since. Once setup though, everything works just fine.In conclusion, if you are a Sci-Fi/Horror fan, enjoy a good third person shooter style experience, and enjoy roaming around in beautiful, atmospheric environments, then this is for you! And remember: In space, no one can hear you scream!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Note: Disabling v-sync makes the game unplayableDead space is essentially a modern upgrade of System Shock 2, featuring hideous monsters, gunslinging, and minor puzzles.  The story is well written, the universe is well developed, and the characters, minor or major, are interesting for even the small periods of interaction you have.  Dispite it's linearity, and the fact that the main character has no voice, the game never feels unrelatable, and you find yourself immersed: wandering a derelict vessel trying to figure out how to fix it and get off with your life.  Any complaints I have from this game stem from the out of character and out of context minigames.I played this game with a controller, which felt a lot more natural as the game was designed to use one. There is one sequence of the game where I was forced to use the mouse, but it had nothing to do with the base mechanics of the game, more to do with my above point about minigames.Expect about 12 hours of gameplay, with replayability in a newgame+ mode.Overall, this game is a lot of fun and I would definitely recommend picking it up for a couple sleepless nights of shooting abominations.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2011
												Going in for a fourth playthrough, this game is still an incredible gem. One of the greatest console ports I've played, one of my all-time favorite scifi horror pieces. Maybe it's not such a pure horror case in the way that Amnesia is but it sure blows Resident Evil games and such out of the water. Atmosphere and audio are incredible. Loud surround sound + vibrating gamepad + Ripper saw = glee! and gore. Concerned neighbours, maybe.Mandatory protip: Do NOT have Vsync on, it is bugged and will screw up your controls, making you think it's a sloppy console job. Other than that I've not found any technical flaws. Supposedly main menu's "continue game" can reset your difficulty to Normal, use "load game" instead.Protip #2: DO NOT PLAY ON ANYTHING LESS THAN HARD DIFFICULTY. You'll thank yourself later.  Easy/Normal is like playing with god mode. (Impossible difficulty is extra fun but it needs unlocking)The sequel has huge stompin' boots to fill.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												Replayed this in 2016 after being reminded by it in the ‘EDGE special edition – the 100 greatest video games’, not having touched it since release. Incredibly it stands up enormously today, both in terms of gameplay, graphics, and story. The integration with the game world is complete, focusing on survival, exploration, and tightly choreographed bouts of intense combat. In particular, the sound and monster design is out of this world, making it just as creepy and unsettling as it was back in 2008. While some critics prefer the sequel, I would liken it to the comparison of the film Alien, and Aliens; essentially suspense vs. action.Of the material that inspired it, Alien I strongly prefer, and if like me, you enjoy being sucked into a realistic world of terror in space, this is the one for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												I decided to have another run through of this gem over Halloween - I've owned various copies on various platforms over the years but figured it might as well refresh my memory from my first playthrough back in 2008. For a horror fan, this game is a must. The atmosphere this title manages to evoke is amongst some of the best I've ever come across in my 20-year gaming career. If you're a fan of The Thing, Event Horizon, Alien, anything along those lines, you will *relish* the game's mixture of music, storytelling and pace. The fact that I've just finished my god-knows-how-many-th run through here in 2015 having thoroughly enjoyed every minute really underlines how well the devs did.The game does like it's share of jump scares but I found it didn't overdo them - rather than go down Doom 3's route of continuously letting loose horrors from hidden cabinets, half the time the game lets your own head do it's work for you - you'll glimpse things rushing down corridors, you'll hear whispers in the dark without any clear source, every so often something will clang and crash. It's classic horror stuff of messing with your head to make the reveal all the better. The game drip-feeds it's story by way of audio logs, footage, and gradual exposition across what used to be a place where it's crew worked and lived, as you slowly learn what the f*** happened on this doomed ship, and the excellent voice acting really pushes the script in the right direction. Technically, it's a fairly standard third-person shooter - much of the ruckus about how your character is an average blue-collar Parker-from-Alien engineer thrown into a nightmarish ghost ship crawling with horrific entities is fairly thin, as your 'improvised engineering tools' can be turned into shockingly devastating instruments of destruction (quite what a miner needs a giant particle cannon for is explained as, um, shooting rocks... yeah, makes you wonder how fast and ferocious rocks are in the future) but none of that is really important - expect a gameplay pace sitting somewhere between Mass Effect 1 and Gears of War with *very* rough narrative outline and atmosphere similar to System Shock 2. Intially playing like a Survival Horror, padding down corridors with a palpable feeling that you are only alive by sheer luck with precious little kit, the game steadily becomes more and more action-packed with Isaac the Engineer undergoing some serious nerd rage, upgrading his contraptions to fight ever more gross and numerous monsters that take leaves out of pretty much every sci-fi horror of the last 20 years.But don't play this for the simple gameplay, as entertaining as it is. Play it to enjoy a truly awesome sci-fi horror and wish that the gaming industry produced half as much as this stuff as it did CoD clones.Then play it's sequel. Like me. :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Dead Space is a game, which ignites my memories of films like Aliens, Lost In Space, and other movies with isolated, or abandoned space vessels.At first I found Dead Space boring, but on my 3rd play-through I eventually got hooked and started to increase further into the game, and story. Dead Space is amazingly eerie, and you have that 'alone' space feeling through-out the main campaign. As I got further into the main story I found myself getting hooked, and thinking to myself 'WOW'! This game is incredible, and for anyone that likes old space movies from the early 80's/90's, then this is the game for you!The plot of Dead Space is simple. You are sent with a crew to investigate a planet mining vessel that sent out a request for help. The game starts with you arriving at that vessel and then you begin to find out what happened, and why the help signal was sent. Not all is as seems however - as the badly damaged vessel seems to be empty upon arrival - Or is it?The story has many twists and turns. It's a story about experimentation, love, and 'what happens when things go wrong'.Dead Space is great! It's thrilling, inventive, and the level-up system, and skill tree is genius.This game is so alike to the scene in 'Lost In Space' when they arrive at the abandoned Space vessel. If you haven't watched Lost In Space, and you haven't played Dead Space - then you NEED to.I rate this game 10/10.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Wonderfully immersive and exciting. A true horror thriller with a nice twist of 3rd person action.For a long time i had played the IOS version of Dead Space, and loved almost everything about it - the graphics, the style, the action, the jump scares... I could go on! However, it lacked immersion due to the touch controls and how itd take up most the screen controlling Issac.However, when i then saw that Humble Bundle was selling this along side DS2 & DS3, i was over the moon - finally i would be able to play my favourite franchise (depsite never having even played the PC versions). A year passed and i had yet to play the game on my PC (a HP Pavillion Intel Pentium laptop, i think you can understand why), so when i bought a PS3, i once again bought DS1&DS2.Now here is why i have brought all this up - the controls. The games graphics and gameplay is stunning, however it may take you a while to learn the auxilliary controls on keyboard. Whereas there are 16 buttons max on a PS3/4 Controller, there are 80+ keys on a keyboard, which are not always the easiest to reach from WASD, so when accessing the mission log, map or objectives, it can be a pain remembering which keys are which and stretching to reach them. Sure you could remap the keys, but then once again youd be having to learn them again.Otherwise, this game is stunning, with a thrilling story and plenty of jump scares, and a real sense of terror.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Dead Space is one of my all-time favorites, and in a true sense a masterpiece. I bought and played it upon its original release, and it was pretty much bug free and stable out of the box, even if it pushed my trusty old Core2Duo I had then pretty hard.The design choices, story line (augmented by a couple of animated movies ,"Dead Space: Downfall" and "Dead Space: Aftermath"), atmosphere, and gritty industrial Sci-Fi environment, make this a memorable, terrifying, and unique experience. Think of it as an amalgamation of Aliens, Event Horizon, The Thing, and Pandorum. It does have some jump scares, but mainly all the adversaries are manageable, especially since you get to upgrade your gear throughout.You definitely get the feeling of being in space, in particularly due to the very, very awesome Zero-G sequences, and your requirement for Oxygen and the ability to magnetize your boots. This is pretty unique in games, and certainly was a novelty back when Dead Space was released. This is probably the fourth time I've bought the game, for one due to DRM-freeness, and because it's worth it. Of all the games published by EA over the years, the Dead Space (and Mass Effect) franchises are certainly one of the best games ever made.In fact, the only negative I have to say about Dead Space is the ridiculous control/button assignments. Being left handed I do not use WASD, I use the cursor, and surrounding keys, and Dead Space isn't very helpful there. I had to get a program called GlovePIE which I've had to use a few times since. Once setup though, everything works just fine.In conclusion, if you are a Sci-Fi/Horror fan, enjoy a good third person shooter style experience, and enjoy roaming around in beautiful, atmospheric environments, then this is for you! And remember: In space, no one can hear you scream!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on May 13, 2011 Event Horizon, Pandorum, Alien, even 2001. All of these films and many other great Sci Fi traditions act as a healthy source base for Dead Space. The game features a distress call, a seemingly silent ship which we quickly realize is dark and full of monsters. Something has gone terribly wrong.The game's carefully crafted atmosphere and surprisingly good voice acting are really what draw you in. Although the plot is very transparent, and the character development (especially for Kendra) is a little weak, the game isn't really about that. It's about living out some version of the space horror fantasy you've had in your head ever since the first time you saw say, Event Horizon. The game has it all, spooky lighting, creepy cultists, a wide array of frightening monsters, and a slowing unfolding backstory involving a typical breakdown of the chain of command and descent into chaos.Playing this game with headphones and in the dark, while alone, even a second time through, is quite an experience. Your heart will pound and you will jump out of your seat.Graphically speaking the game isn't much to look at, and the necromorphs aren't very inspired in their design, although they are scary. Nevertheless, the lighting and audio more than make up for the game's low resolution textures and low poly models.Apart from really wonky object physics, the game feels very good to play as well. The slow turning speed of Isaac, your avatar, contributes to the sense of the game as being about horror/survival, and scavenging is essential. You aren't incredibly vulnerable, especially after upgrades, but you feel like you are, and that's what counts.Ultimately, Dead Space is a surprising and fun guilty pleasure of a game that will remind you of nights spent watching sci-fi horror movies scaring yourself senseless in the dark.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2011
												Going in for a fourth playthrough, this game is still an incredible gem. One of the greatest console ports I've played, one of my all-time favorite scifi horror pieces. Maybe it's not such a pure horror case in the way that Amnesia is but it sure blows Resident Evil games and such out of the water. Atmosphere and audio are incredible. Loud surround sound + vibrating gamepad + Ripper saw = glee! and gore. Concerned neighbours, maybe.Mandatory protip: Do NOT have Vsync on, it is bugged and will screw up your controls, making you think it's a sloppy console job. Other than that I've not found any technical flaws. Supposedly main menu's "continue game" can reset your difficulty to Normal, use "load game" instead.Protip #2: DO NOT PLAY ON ANYTHING LESS THAN HARD DIFFICULTY. You'll thank yourself later.  Easy/Normal is like playing with god mode. (Impossible difficulty is extra fun but it needs unlocking)The sequel has huge stompin' boots to fill.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												+ Now you can step into the suit of the Isaac Clarke!+ It is quick and simple repair mission, nothing will go wrong+ Cut off limbs of the enemies to conserve ammo+ Oh, wait what, you said it's just an easy repair mission?+ Lethal and haunting atmosphere+ Extremly outstanding audio+ In this game, the loot from the enemies are random+ Start a new game with your finished-game-inventory!+ Detailed graphics and shadow effects makes the world alive+ Easy, Medium, Hard and Impossible (after beating the game once)+ Action-packed Resident Evil 4 style over-the-shoulder view+ Destroy targets at the shooting range to win some prizes+ Slow down fast enemies with your bullet-time-device (doesn't regenerate)+ "Unique", you have the Dead Space version of the Gravity Gun!+ Careful near the vents, enemy can pop out of it!+ Kendra, let's play basketball!+ Sorry enemy, I got to toss some furniture at you with my Gravity Gun to conserve my ammo!+ This game will test your manliness+ Obviously, as we're in space, no-gravity rooms, walk on the ceiling like Lionel Richie!+ Better freeroam on the map after everything is dead, to make sure everything stays dead+ Every inventory, videolog, map and chatlog item will be projected in front of you as a hologram+ You got to be careful in the vacuumed areas, all you hear is your heart beating+ Overpowered weapons, after you've been upgrading them to the max, using the "node"s+ Uh oh, dilemmas! Or use "node"s to unlock secret doors, for some great loot- Selecting "continue game" may reset your difficulty you're playing with, manually load your game- Incredebly annoying mouselag, can fix by adjusting sensitivity to the max- Raised heartbeat, wet pants and sweaty forehead9/10

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												I enjoyed this game. It is scary... if dead bodies scare you. I mean, ..sure there are moments where I jumped a bit, but..scary is ..giving it too much credit. Perhaps how I played (as a paranoid person I shot all bodies, removed all corpses from rooms before fully entering them, had plenty of ammo at all times with all weapons, kept aware of all surroundings and exits, etc) maybe I killed the scary..but ...whatever. Its good. Good gameplay, good story, good characters, great environments. Even good puzzles / level design.What's wrong is that... its not scary, its just incredibly gore intensive. Its piles of flesh and blood here, constant disgusting dismemberment of reanimated alien dead things..and ...I was grossed out. Half the time I was supposed to be scared of something I was more worried how gross it was going to be to kill it. The game has some great moments though that are worth the money to experience. A good buy.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												+ Now you can step into the suit of the Isaac Clarke!+ It is quick and simple repair mission, nothing will go wrong+ Cut off limbs of the enemies to conserve ammo+ Oh, wait what, you said it's just an easy repair mission?+ Lethal and haunting atmosphere+ Extremly outstanding audio+ In this game, the loot from the enemies are random+ Start a new game with your finished-game-inventory!+ Detailed graphics and shadow effects makes the world alive+ Easy, Medium, Hard and Impossible (after beating the game once)+ Action-packed Resident Evil 4 style over-the-shoulder view+ Destroy targets at the shooting range to win some prizes+ Slow down fast enemies with your bullet-time-device (doesn't regenerate)+ "Unique", you have the Dead Space version of the Gravity Gun!+ Careful near the vents, enemy can pop out of it!+ Kendra, let's play basketball!+ Sorry enemy, I got to toss some furniture at you with my Gravity Gun to conserve my ammo!+ This game will test your manliness+ Obviously, as we're in space, no-gravity rooms, walk on the ceiling like Lionel Richie!+ Better freeroam on the map after everything is dead, to make sure everything stays dead+ Every inventory, videolog, map and chatlog item will be projected in front of you as a hologram+ You got to be careful in the vacuumed areas, all you hear is your heart beating+ Overpowered weapons, after you've been upgrading them to the max, using the "node"s+ Uh oh, dilemmas! Or use "node"s to unlock secret doors, for some great loot- Selecting "continue game" may reset your difficulty you're playing with, manually load your game- Incredebly annoying mouselag, can fix by adjusting sensitivity to the max- Raised heartbeat, wet pants and sweaty forehead9/10

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												I enjoyed this game. It is scary... if dead bodies scare you. I mean, ..sure there are moments where I jumped a bit, but..scary is ..giving it too much credit. Perhaps how I played (as a paranoid person I shot all bodies, removed all corpses from rooms before fully entering them, had plenty of ammo at all times with all weapons, kept aware of all surroundings and exits, etc) maybe I killed the scary..but ...whatever. Its good. Good gameplay, good story, good characters, great environments. Even good puzzles / level design.What's wrong is that... its not scary, its just incredibly gore intensive. Its piles of flesh and blood here, constant disgusting dismemberment of reanimated alien dead things..and ...I was grossed out. Half the time I was supposed to be scared of something I was more worried how gross it was going to be to kill it. The game has some great moments though that are worth the money to experience. A good buy.

												Dead Space conjures up the claustrophobic ambient terror that the first Alien movie did so well. You will simultaneously dread and relish turning each corner, and breathe a sigh of relief each time you discover a shop or save point.For added immersion, I played Dead Space in 3D with Nvidia 3D Vision, and it worked really well with this game. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5
												StorySci-fi horror with RPG elements, Dead Space provides a graphic experience aimed to induce fear as you make your way through hellish sections of a broken mining ship. Set on what's left of a large 'planet-cracker' ship named USG Ishamura. You play as Isaac Clarke, an engineer assigned to perform routine repairs of the Ishamura. Upon arrival you and your team soon learn there are much more concerning matters than rebooting engines and repairing downed communications. By working together with your remaining crew, you will uncover the truth behind the Ishamura's downfall and it's now necromorph staff, and struggle to avoid sharing the same fate.GameplayMovement and aiming controls felt cumbersome and clunky, like two bad dancers stepping on each others toes. Enemy AI behaved intelligently when ambushing and cornering, despite their predictable appearances and entrances. Dead Space's minimal HUD helps bring about a more immersive experience and interaction with objects and environments felt fluid. Abundance of items and gear dampens the horror aspect, but creates an enjoyable amount of gear customization and weapon variety. (For a more intense experience I'd recommend a harder difficulty) Nicely paced story and chapters that introduce new obstacles and enemy variants as the game progresses. Challenging yet rewarding.SoundEerie and grim, the music works well in adding to the gruesome nature of the game. Sound effects and necromorph screams/grunts are hair-raising, despite feeling amplified for cheap jump scares. Quality voice acting, though it's worth mentioning you (Isaac) play as a silent protagonist.GraphicsPlaying 8 years later it's impressive that these graphics don't show their age. Necromorphs are horrifically stunning in detail, as well as the games gorey environment. Lighting and textures appear believable and fitting for both the horror genre and sci-fi. Unlike movement and aiming, the graphics and sounds come together in a beautifully orchestrated ensemble of fear and sweet, sweet necromorph dismemberment.Replay ValueOffering NG+ it's hard to not revisit Ishamura for a round 2. Even after much exploring there still feels like Dead Space has a lot more to offer and likely grows in enjoyment each playthrough, giving it a strong replay value which I feel we can all agree on is a wonderful feature for any game.Wrapping UpOverall Dead Space offers a quality gaming experience, interesting story, detailed atmosphere, and nicely implemented scares. What few flaws you can find in the game are outshined by everything it does right.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Horror probably isn't the right word here. The game doesn't really go for good scares, mostly just sudden "oh my god it's an alien coming straight for you suddenly have a loud noise" and they just got incredibly predictable after a while. But it can be quite creepy at times - probably helped absolutely humonguous amounts by the absolutely incredible sound design of this game. I think that this might the only time I max out one of the score categories for a game.Seriously, the sound design is just amazing. Incredible ambient noise, with really creepy nuances and fantastic utterly disgusting music for when you get under attack. Every single sound made is absolutely perfect.Also the UI of this game is just amazing. Everything makes sense in the game world, it's all projected out of your suit or from screens on everything. It's fantastic, and it helps increase the tension because you can't pause the game by opening the map screen/inventory screen.The gameplay is pretty good, though I didn't feel it got tough enough on Normal difficulty so perhaps Hard difficulty is the right difficulty to play it on. The weapons are all satisfying to use, and can be very effective when upgraded correctly. I liked the way most of the enemies had weak points you could exploit to kill them quicker and conserve more ammo. The design of the aliens was fantastic, and the ship design was quite good (I liked how you had to revisit some levels for good reason, and some things had changed and that actually made it slightly creepy and foreboding).The story wasn't particularly impressive, but a few bits of it were quite good. I was quite disappointed by the very end of the game though, like literally the last few seconds [if you've played it you'll know what I mean] because it just felt incredibly cheap.Other than that, this game was very good. A definite play, if not for the perfectly adequate gameplay then just for the mindblowingly incredible sound. Seriously, someone give the guy who did all that all the awards. Ever. All the awards.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Great game to play if you love survival horror games. If you haven't played the sequels or watched the movies, play this for a couple hours and you'll see just how dark this game's can become. There's also plenty of collectibles to find. Some are video or audio logs, however most of it is text logs. Now while that may be a huge turnoff for some, you don't need those logs to know what's happening. The logs are there to provide some more details on what's happening as well as giving some background information. The combat system in this game is pretty unique, too. The Necromorphs which are like space zombies need to be killed by severing their limbs. Shooting them in the head however won't work Anyway it's been awhile since I played it on my Xbox One and I've forgotten how the story goes at some parts, but what I can tell you is that this game is worth the buy. Especially if you're reading this during the winter 2016 sale. $5 for a 2008 AAA title. Pretty damn good price. Same for DS2 (also on sale). 3 on the other hand isn't great.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												This game is right around 7 years old now, but I am just now playing for the first time, and boy do I love it. The combat is not anything special and is a little slow paced, but that really isn't anything to complain about. The game looks damn good considering how old it is, but the best part about the game is the story. I really like the setting and atmosphere of the game. I enjoy finding the audio/video logs that explain the lore even further. The game does a good job pacing itself and I am always intrigued to find out what will happen next to the characters and how it will turn out in the end. The game itself really isn't all that scary, just with some cheap jumpscares and all, but is rather creepy and eerie. I think this is one of the best horror games in the past decade.The actual port of the game is decent. After the Vsync change that fixed a gamebreaking bug the game plays just fine. I personally use a wired 360 controller because I just wasn't a fan of the default key layout and did't want to deal with the mouse sensitivity/acceleration problems. Other than those 2 issues I have had no other problems.I give Dead Space a solid 9/10

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												This game is the best of both the horror and action genre. It mixes so many good elements to scare you through suspense, jump scares, gore, fear and the big broader threat that everyone could die if you aren’t successful. Dead Space has set the standard for Sci-Fi Survival/Horror and its name stills sends shivers down the backs of gamers almost a decade later. The game starts with you, Isaac Clark, with a maintenance crew attending to the distress call on the U.S.G. Ishimura; a massive mining ship. Things go south quickly as the ship crashed into the main hanger and the crew is nowhere to be found. Throughout your struggle to restore functions to the ship and find out what happened you have constant deadly problems to deal with. This game is very original in the way the threats develop and you deal with them. There are sequences where you have to solve zero-g puzzles, mazes in zero-g, fight enemies with unique abilities, time very careful threats from the decaying ship and use the full range of your abilities. The game has 12 chapters, which you can finish in about an hour each making it great to set down with natural pauses. The game has upgrades from the stores found around the ships and you need to balance your credits and upgrade pick-ups with your need for ammunition and health throughout the game. One of my personal favorite mechanics in this game has to do with the soundtrack changing from the ambience to combat music. Most games start combat music when you enter a room or an enemy spawns. In Dead Space, with the exception of cut scenes, the combat music doesn’t start until you almost make eye contact with an enemy. This makes it terrifying when that one enemy that you missed comes up behind you and grabs you suddenly out of the nice ambient space music. There are also many sequences when you are in the vacuum of space and the game lets you only hear one sound, Isaac’s breathing. Unless you see the enemy coming, he’ll be behind you. The most immersive aspect of the game is the face that there is really no HUD. Your health is displayed as a series of bars on the back of Isaac’s armor and when looking at your inventory he projects the screen from his armor rather than the game opening a menu. Overall, the game is a wonderful, immersive sci-fi survival/horror game that has really set the bar for its unique niche. I would highly recommend it and play it in a dark room with headphones all the way up in the dead of night.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												Been a while since I completed this game, but I would definitcounmmend this to anyone looking for a Sci-fi Horror game with Survival elements. At its core, it's a third-person shooter that has you playing as Isaac Clarke, an engineer stuck on a doomed mining ship, struggling to find a way out while uncovering the secrets of the former crew and the cause of the outbreak. The backstory is the real star here. It's told through audio recordings, notes and letters by former crew members and survivors. The main story itself is serviceable, but has quite a few horror film clichés and tropes. Lots of plot devices are often recycled to keep the game going. For example, half the chapters consist of fixing something that has broken down somewhere in the ship for whatever reason.The gameplay itself is quite satisfying and provides a fair challenge that rarely feels frustrating or unfair. All weapons function differently from each other and give certain advantages and disadvantages. The crafting system isn't anything special, but it's not bad at all. As far being "scary", it's a pretty mixed bag. If predictable jump scares are your thing, then you will be scared most of the time. However, there is a psychological horror aspect to this game that the sequels never quite replicated. A lot of events are never actually seen or experienced, but rather heard or found after they've taken place. Some of them are quite startling and adds a sense of impending doom to your journey. Disembodied voices (if listened to carefully, may imply it's actually just Issac going insane) also add to this layer of fear. My biggest problem with the gameplay is that the mouse controls are unresponsive or too sensitive at times, but there are several   community guides to fixing this. Overall a solid 8/10 game for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2012
												I can't say enough about this game (or its sequel). Very few games have achieved the genuine suspense and atmosphere that it has. Although it relies a lot on jump-scares, the overarching, pervasive feeling of danger is effectively evoked and present throughout the entire game; unlike most horror films and games, it does not rely on the player/character to make stupid decisions to perpetuate its air of chilling anticipation. The combat actually requires a decent amount of skill, and if you're playing on a harder difficulty, the game *does* live up to the "survival" part of the genre. The enemies are interestingly not the lone source of the scare either; the environment and its hazards play just as big a role in it.All in all, I can easily say that Dead Space is my favorite game of all time. It does such justice to the survival-horror genre that I believe it should set an example for what other titles in it should aim for.

												For those looking for a game from one of the BEST years in gaming, look no further. Dead Space pits you in place where both fear and paranoia may become your best allies. Dead Space is the first of three games in the main series with two spin-off games, several novels, and a few animated movies. content:
Posted: February 10
												The game itself is fantastic. Great graphics, atmosphere, and gameplay. However, it has some annoying "console port' issues. There's two showstopping bugs. One happens in the first 5 minutes of the game, the other in the last 5. First bug is a door that has an invisible wall inside of it and won't let you go through. The 2nd bug is a crash to desktop when opening a door. Both can be bypassed by temporarily turning on v-synch. You'll want to keep the in-game v-synch off most of the time because otherwise you get locked to 30 FPS..I also recommend capping the game at 60 FPS using something like dxtory, otherwise there's some weird physics bugs. They don't impact the gameplay, but I saw a bunch of corpses that should have been stationary wildly twirling in the air. It was as comical as it sounds. All these bugs are realted to the fact that in the late 2000s developers had this habit of tying various scripting and physics math to the in-game FPS.  I assume this was done because the console version was locked to a certain, and consistent FPS. However when you're getting above 60 FPS on a PC, things start to wig out. If you notice anything weird happening, that's likely why. I also had an issue where I would instantly die while doing some of the zero-g sections. It would happen when flying between surfaces. Sometimes when landing on a surface at an awkward angle, my game would freeze for a moment and then play a death animation. Not sure if that last one is an issue with the game itself, or due to the some of the fixes I was using to improve other parts of the experience.Highly reccomend the game as it is worth playing. There aren't really any other huge issues with the port, but I thought the two issues I described were big enough to warrant mention and criticism. Check out: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dead_Space for some additional tweaks and fixes. I found the FOV adjust and the "mouse fix" pretty handy.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Awesome game. I wasn't really sure what to think of it when I bought it shortly after it came out. This series has become one of my all time video game favorites, and I have been playing video games for almost 25 years now.Tips to enjoy:1.) Turn out lights.2.) Play at night.3.) Be the only one home and expose your back to a large dark room.4.) Get headphones with surround sound5.) Enjoy peeing in your pants and jumping at shadows.Seriously, this game is morbid, dark, twisted, and tons of fun. I keep going back for more.The game may be old (2008ish), but is still lots of fun. Everything is done in 3rd person. This mean all interfaces, inventory screen, video/audio/text logs, maps, etc are shown in 3rd person at anytime where you can be attacked from mosters. The controls may seem unresponsive at first but it quickly adds to the game machanics and atmosphere and don't really become a burden. The lighting and sound design is spot on. That is where this game really, really shines. This game may not have the greatest graphics, but you couldn't ask for better lighting placement or sound effects. The game does mix things up and it never overuses a game concept which does add for atleast a second playthrough. Each enviroment feels different yet somehow familiar but you never get that feeling of "been there, done that."  The dismemberment mechanic (where the best way to kill something is to shoot its limbs off), the 3rd person everything, the lighting and sound design, the level design, the "Zero G' and vacuum machanic, the pacing of the game, and the general atmosphere of the game makes it unique and one not to be missed. This is one that you will remember for several years and probably pick up to play after a couple years and still find it fun.This game is NOT to be missed.

A Guide for Dead Space
By: Hootie

			 Framerate slowdown? Mouse acceleration and sensitivity issues? The invisible door bug?  The port for Dead Space 1 isn't perfect, and nigh unplayable on some machines.		


 Follow those instructions specifically as it says AND, then after that restart your computer. Trust me, it doesn't kick in until you restart your PCStep 2: Also Click on this link, again, it's another Steam Guide but this one helps to fix the terribly low and awful mouse controls that the game has on default, trust me, its a very serious issue - 


How to fix mouse control problems 
A Guide for Dead Space
By: Bropalm

			Here's how you can fix all problems with the mouse controls by editing the game's config file.		


Step 3: There's no step 3 because that number is not in the Steam text unicode of this user review client...jk moving on, MAKE SURE TO TURN OFF V-SYNCStep 4: *SPOILERS BUT I NEED TO TELL YOU* So there's a part in the very beginning of the game where you are going to come across what is infamously known as the "Invisible-Wall-Bug-Of-The-Dead-Space-PC-Port". This invisible wall bug is found right in the beginning of the game in the first chapter where you first recieve the plasma cutter right after you exit the elevator unarmed from the slasher necromorphs chasing you. This room has a wall that says "cut off the limbs" and has a guy screaming behind a door, if you were to continue your journey that exact door that dude is behind will not let you pass, seriously, it's a stupid glitch but theres many stupid glitches in this game that shouldn't be in there. So this is what you are going to do, I recommend you save your game before hand in the first save station to do this. Once you reach the first elevator and you are in it quickly go to your options menu and turn on V-Sync, you may have to deal with terrible framerate and mouse controls but once you make it pass that door you can turn it off and continue your survival through the USG Ishimura. (If this doesn't work then try to find a way to decrease your framerate under 30 fps, the game is capped at 30 anyway, I heard Fraps helps with this under the same process I specified).Soooo yeah, now that that's out of the way, lets get on to the review shall we?ReviewSo excluding the atrocious PC port Dead Space is a fantastic and immersive horror experience. Now I got to be frank with you, I pretty much spoiled Dead Space when I saw a let's play from like 3-5 years ago yet my memory was very vague when I played this game. To tell you what's going on in the story I recommend you play it for yourself because duh spoilers, that plus other people who give reviews will tell tend to explain the story, mine is more of the experience.Besides spoiling the game for myself I have also played Dead Space 2 and completed it (On the Xbox 360) and have got to say that the experience was very unique compared to if I played Dead Space 1 first and then 2. You know that feeling when you look at a picture of a famous monument and actually went there? Or go and experience that one place that's so talked about and then actually visit it? Well that's what Dead Space 1 was like when I played it, so much of the trilogy's plot all revolves around the events of what happened on the USG Ishimura and the planet Aegis 7 along with the developement of the main protagonist Isaac Clarke, that plus the event's of the USG Ishimura acts as a catalyst for pretty much the entire 3 game's story.As a survival horror game Dead Space does it pretty well even though the gameplay mechanics are straight up Resident Evil 4 just with new stuff that you can do. Now yes as much of the Dead Space community has stated Dead Space 1 is a lot more scarier than is Dead Space 2 for many reasons. Now I'm pretty tough when it comes to scary games yet Dead Space still tends to frighten me compared to the jump scare infested and cinematic sequel that was Dead Space 2. The game kept my heart at an above than normal pulse in certain parts and some parts have truly made my heart race.The Immersion in Dead Space is incredible with the sound design being spot on along with the game's mechanics and setting working together to make the immersive experience amazing, here's how it works: Dead Space's indicators is all attached to the character's body such as the character's "RIG" stating the player's health along with the Stasis meter being on the character's RIG aswell, The game's mechanics such as the Stasis ability and Kinesis ability are all integrated uses in the game's setting, story, and lore, not some thing tacked on for just gameplay purposes. For example the use of stasis and kinesis are actual tools used by the USG Ishimura's crew along with the weapons of the game being mechanical power tools used on the ship (excluding the Pulse Rifle of course). The sound design is spot on and it all makes sense and adds to the game, you will hear distant screams of unlucky survivors and necromophs alike that will make you wonder if there were any other survivors still on the ship through out your journey, you will hear clanks and sounds in the vents and in the distance that make you tense thinking that a necromorph can come out of any vent at any time possible.Dead Space's story is very interesting and many of the concept's of the game are ones that I have never seen in anything before, sure the game take's influences from franchises such as Alien along with how the premise of the game has already been done by titles such as System Shock 2. Besides that I think the game is very original for its time and I think anyone should do some research on the lore because the setting of Dead Space with planet cracking, the Marker, necromorphs and the Church of Unitology is one that I find interesting.The Bad n' UgryThe port for Dead Space on PC is atrocious, not for the fact that it has issues but by the fact that it's bugs are absolutely pathetic, like really, some of the bugs in this game make Call of Duty: Ghost's PC port look good, I mean here's a list of the bugs that I've encountered:1. The game doesn't even try to run on AMD alone 2. Stupid invisible door glitch in the beginning3. Broken physics and highly sensitive hitboxs for non-static objects that cause things such as corpes and dead body parts to flail around when you give a slight love tap to them (chapter 2 body bag dance party lel)4. Player model/Isaac Clarke tends to spaz out when you sprint on some parts of the ground5. Finicky mouse controls with horribly low sensitivity even on the highest setting6. Some wierd thing that happens to a tram door that gets stuck mid animation that causes you from passing7. Characters that die tend to spaz out when they go from static character to ragdoll (hilarious and somewhat immersive breaking)8. (MY ABSOLUTE HATED) So there will be parts where you will have to float in space and there is a slight chance that your character make freeze via clipping into geometry and just die as if Isaac sufficated from I don't know, polygons? This happened to me like 3 times and 2 were by the end of the gameBut hey that doesn't mean it's a bad game! So go out and buy it and have a good ol' time!
