content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
 "Make us whole, Isaac. Make us whole." TL;DR: Play as Isaac Clarke, the unluckiest son of a ♥♥♥♥♥(literally) engineer in video gaming history ever. Be haunted by a mysterious artefact that is somehow the key to stopping aliens(but still wants to kill you because plot holes).Dead Space is supposedly a survival horror TPS game. While I personally don't think this game as a good horror game, it at least attempts(and sometimes succeeds), which is much more better then Dead Space 3(that game didn't even try).This is what the game is about: you are part of a repair team, heading towards the USG Ishmura, the biggest 'Planet Cracker' in the universe. It sent out a distress call and lost connection, so you, as the engineer(you're accompanied by Kendra, a hacker, and Zach Hammond, a security officer, and his team), is to fix up Ishmura(and your ship as well, the USG Kelion) and find the source of the call. Of course, everything goes south when in the first 30 minutes, you become haunted by the 'Necromorphs', mysterious, grotesque and dangerous humanoid creatures that quickly panics the entire team. Now, since you're the only one able to do anything(because game protagonist logic), you have to find out what the ♥♥♥♥ happened here.The game is kinda like what everyone calls it: Resident Evil in space. After all, the developers based the gameplay off of Resident Evil because they didn't have much time for development. Though there are very unique gameplay features in Dead Space.The game doesn't have a HUD(Heads Up Display). Your health is represented by your RIG, the Resource Integration Gear. Everyone has one of these in the future- it a computer device(looks like a mechanical spine) that you attach on your back. Since this is a TPS, you can see your RIG most of the time, and as your health goes down, the bar on your RIG gets low(like how health bars get low), and it changes color to blue to yellow to red.This game also has a inventory and a store system, so you press tab to see your inventory. When you press tab, your suit(you wear a engineering/or a mining suit that makes you look like a  badass [images1.wikia.nocookie.net]) will display a hologram inventory screen in front of you. It fits in with the SF feel of the game, and is much more immersive then a generic HUD. Your ammo will also be displayed when you aim, much like Halo, though your number of clips is not displayed, so you have to check your inventory.You will find money inside crates and corpses of Necromorphs, which can be used at the store to buy ammo, health packs, etc. You will also find schematics for new items so you can just install it at the store and buy it. New suit schematic are important as they increase your armor and inventory size. You will also find 'Power Nodes' to open 'Node Rooms', which has very good things like much needed ammo on higher difficulties, and most important of all, new schematics(there are only one schematic for one item, so if you miss that schematic, it's gone for good).You can also go to the Bench and upgrade your RIG(armor, health, air, etc), weapons, your Stasis Module which slows down enemies and objects, and your Kinesis Module which picks up heavy objects without a use of ammo- very important in higher difficulties. You upgrade them with Power Nodes, so be careful- you never know if you'll find a Node Room right after you spend all of your Nodes on upgrades.There are also good variety of weapons, though the first free weapon you get, the Plasma Cutter, is very versatile and is good at everything(it's basically the best weapon in the game. you never want to sell it) As you can see from the name, it cuts things. It's a tool for cutting rocks, but in this game, it's used to cut off limbs. Why? Because headshots or bodyshots doesn't work for these monsters. You have to make them useless by cutting off their limbs. They don't die just from headshots(though they do lose their vision), and their torso is made out of ♥♥♥♥ing metal or something.So we know the gameplay is at least something, so move on to the story- it actually has a very deep world(that you get to know more about in the second game), and the story intrigues you right from the start. The atmosphere and the story in general is heavily inspired by a 1997 movie 'Event Horizon'. The box cover for the game(a hand floating in space) is a homage to a scene in the movie, actually.(the more you know) It has that general feel of 'what the ♥♥♥♥ happened here' like in Half-Life or Bioshock(this game probably did the best job on that), and finding out the mystery by checking out all of the text logs is pretty fun. The dispute between Kendra and Zach(Kendra says 'let's get the ♥♥♥♥ out of here', while Zach says 'We still have a mission') also seemed to be pretty good, though it stops right after Kendra disappears, then she comes back then Zach disappears.Oh, and Isaac- you just gotta ♥♥♥♥ing feel for him. He doesn't talk(he does in the later games), but he just does all of these things, and everytime he screams of fear(his 'AHHHHRG!!' is very memorable in some death scenes), you can't but say "dude... this is ♥♥♥♥ed up.". And oh yeah, the death scenes in this game is notorious for being grotesque(much like the rest of the game), and it's true. It's the only thing all of the fans have praised throughout the series(the later games adds even more).Let's take a look at some of the other miscellaneous things though- the graphics are not dated. It's good enough, and the gore is like I said, great(though I don't know if it's a good thing or not). The soundtrack is very similar to Half-Life's case. It's mostly ambient tracks, which makes the atmosphere a lot better, but lot less memorable.So we narrowed down Dead Space, and is it a good game? Yes, it is. It's a great game in fact- and you can tell from all of what I said earlier. Though it still has its cons.The controls. The game's notorious for having terrible mouse controls, while it gets better in the later games, and gets better in this game as well if you tweak some of the files, the fact that they haven't released a official patch on Steam makes me feel pain inside. The difficulty is also a problem. If you get used to it(and you will), it's really really easy. If you watch  Jesse Cox's   blind Dead Space playthough , he plays it on Medium and does not die a single time(and he's known to suck at bideo gems). The boss fights are especially bad- you just shoot at the yellow balls and poof, you win. Every. ♥♥♥♥ing. Boss.Also, the 'survival horror' part is very subjective- the game does a good job of jumpscares in fact. They pop out of the vents and sometimes sneaks up on you, etc. They even play dead sometimes. But all of the monster spawns are scripted, so if you know where they'll spawn(or if you played 70 ♥♥♥♥ing hours like me), it's not that scary at all anymore. The atmosphere still might still spook you, though many people have said that they are not even scared of that anymore. Dead Space 2 and 3 leaves the whole 'closed down environment' atmosphere behind(well, maybe not Dead Space 3), but Dead Space 2 has other things to scare you(spoilers!).Except for that, there isn't much to say. I give Dead Space a 8/10, it's a great game. The execution is near perfect, though the minor gameplay issues and the bugs ruins it a bit. The storyline is still great though, and since it is even more expanded in the later games, I highly recommend you to buy Dead Space 2 and 3 as well. In my opinion(that I will explain in the Dead Space 2 review), Dead Space 2 is gamelay-wise better, and while Dead Space 3 was a huge disappointment, it's still a good game and you should try it out.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												Ah yes, Dead Space.This is one of my favorite series of all time, and if you decide to purchase this game, I think you may just find out why. Isaac Clarke is a futuristic engineer who is sent on a simple mission to repair a Planet Cracker vessel called the Ishimura. After a faulty landing, the crew finds themselves stuck on this ship, and the terrors ensue. This game set the base for survival horror when it first came out, and for good reason too. You will be on the edge of your seat with this one, and in the blink of an eye, flying into the back of it as well. I reccomend this game to all zombie loving survival horror gamers looking for an ingenious space age twist.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												This game is a wonderful addition to anyone's horror library.  Dead Space brings a truly gruesome and unsettling atmosphere into humanity's near future, and provides an experience which at times makes you suck in your gut in fear of death, and at other times makes you feel at home as you stare into the quiet peace of space.  The third person over-the-shoulder gameplay style is similar to that of Resident Evil 4 and 5, leaving Isaac as a relatively slow but powerful tank with the ability to run when he needs to escape certain death.  It is a game that will make you question what the "right" decision is as you unravel more of the games dark story which is driven by conspiracy, betrayal, and mental insanity.  I definitely recommend it to lovers of survival horror games, as well as those who enjoy third person shooters and would like something different than your average run 'n gun.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Dead Space: Succeeds where many other survival horror games fail. This game is brutal, bloody, and as hard as asteroid debris. Pros: + Gore. You get a sense of dread in your stomach watching severed body segments float in zero gravity.+ Challenging. You will die several times. Several times. You really have to want to beat this game to get to the end.+ Long. It took me more than 17 hours to get through this game on medium, and that's pretty impressive for a game of this type.+ Stage design is immaculate. Your objectives in each section are varied, tie in nicely with the story, and the game looks great on a nice rig.+ The “Ripper” weapon is pure, unbridled joy. Cons:- The load screen makes you wait. If you try to minimize the screen and go do something else, it will still make you wait when you pull it back up. At least a third of the time you play this game you will be staring at the load screen. Ah, so this is how they meant to artificially extend playtime.- Frustrating controls and camera angles. Why must I watch from his shoulder like a parrot? Oh, you didn't mean to hit that button? Sucks to be you. Hope you like staring at load screens.- The protagonist is mute. When he gets ripped to shreds by Necromorphs, it's gross, but I feel no sense of connection to the hero.- The asteroid-shooting mini-game is pure tedium. Pro/Cons:+/- The upgrade system is appreciated, but the changes you make to your gear don't always seem that significant. +/- There is no cooperative mode, but then being the only person accomplishing tasks ramps up the tension. +/- Objectives can be vague and will make you consult online guides, but then, this game doesn't always hold your hand. The stages aren't as linear as they are in the 2nd and 3rd installments, where you're carted along one path like a theme park ride. Summary: This game is more than just Resident Evil in space. “Dead Space” does survival horror better. There is just a perfect amount of ammunition and supplies to keep you on the edge of your seat, amazing sequences, machines, and scenery, and it doesn't blatantly coddle the player. It qualifies as a classic. Who should buy this game:*Mature gamers that want a real survival horror challenge. *Horror aficionados who feel that most games aren't gory enough. Who should avoid this game:*Gamers who want something to play with friends.*Squeamish people that are upset by monstrous sounds, blood, and dead bodies. I give it an 8.9 out of 10.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Awesome game. I wasn't really sure what to think of it when I bought it shortly after it came out. This series has become one of my all time video game favorites, and I have been playing video games for almost 25 years now.Tips to enjoy:1.) Turn out lights.2.) Play at night.3.) Be the only one home and expose your back to a large dark room.4.) Get headphones with surround sound5.) Enjoy peeing in your pants and jumping at shadows.Seriously, this game is morbid, dark, twisted, and tons of fun. I keep going back for more.The game may be old (2008ish), but is still lots of fun. Everything is done in 3rd person. This mean all interfaces, inventory screen, video/audio/text logs, maps, etc are shown in 3rd person at anytime where you can be attacked from mosters. The controls may seem unresponsive at first but it quickly adds to the game machanics and atmosphere and don't really become a burden. The lighting and sound design is spot on. That is where this game really, really shines. This game may not have the greatest graphics, but you couldn't ask for better lighting placement or sound effects. The game does mix things up and it never overuses a game concept which does add for atleast a second playthrough. Each enviroment feels different yet somehow familiar but you never get that feeling of "been there, done that."  The dismemberment mechanic (where the best way to kill something is to shoot its limbs off), the 3rd person everything, the lighting and sound design, the level design, the "Zero G' and vacuum machanic, the pacing of the game, and the general atmosphere of the game makes it unique and one not to be missed. This is one that you will remember for several years and probably pick up to play after a couple years and still find it fun.This game is NOT to be missed.

content:
Posted: February 10
												The game itself is fantastic. Great graphics, atmosphere, and gameplay. However, it has some annoying "console port' issues. There's two showstopping bugs. One happens in the first 5 minutes of the game, the other in the last 5. First bug is a door that has an invisible wall inside of it and won't let you go through. The 2nd bug is a crash to desktop when opening a door. Both can be bypassed by temporarily turning on v-synch. You'll want to keep the in-game v-synch off most of the time because otherwise you get locked to 30 FPS..I also recommend capping the game at 60 FPS using something like dxtory, otherwise there's some weird physics bugs. They don't impact the gameplay, but I saw a bunch of corpses that should have been stationary wildly twirling in the air. It was as comical as it sounds. All these bugs are realted to the fact that in the late 2000s developers had this habit of tying various scripting and physics math to the in-game FPS.  I assume this was done because the console version was locked to a certain, and consistent FPS. However when you're getting above 60 FPS on a PC, things start to wig out. If you notice anything weird happening, that's likely why. I also had an issue where I would instantly die while doing some of the zero-g sections. It would happen when flying between surfaces. Sometimes when landing on a surface at an awkward angle, my game would freeze for a moment and then play a death animation. Not sure if that last one is an issue with the game itself, or due to the some of the fixes I was using to improve other parts of the experience.Highly reccomend the game as it is worth playing. There aren't really any other huge issues with the port, but I thought the two issues I described were big enough to warrant mention and criticism. Check out: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dead_Space for some additional tweaks and fixes. I found the FOV adjust and the "mouse fix" pretty handy.

content:
Posted: January 16
												For those looking for a game from one of the BEST years in gaming, look no further. Dead Space pits you in place where both fear and paranoia may become your best allies. Dead Space is the first of three games in the main series with two spin-off games, several novels, and a few animated movies. The story pits you in the midst of a communications blackout on a massive mining ship and  you're an engineer stuck inside the infested ship that hordes a morbid secret. You and the other survivors of a ship responing to a distress signal must now find a way of the mining ship before being consumed by the nightmares that reside within.This is no ordinary jumpscare thrills shooter as the encounters with the enemies in combat can be just as terrifying as the jumpscares placed by the devs. This game will test your will and the harder the difficulty the more you will gasp for air.

You get a sense of dread in your stomach watching severed body segments float in zero gravity.+ Challenging. You will die several times. Several times. You really have to want to beat this game to get to the end.+ Long. It took me more than 17 hours to get through this game on medium, and that's pretty impressive for a game of this type.+ Stage design is immaculate. Your objectives in each section are varied, tie in nicely with the story, and the game looks great on a nice rig.+ The “Ripper” weapon is pure, unbridled joy. Cons:- The load screen makes you wait. If you try to minimize the screen and go do something else, it will still make you wait when you pull it back up. At least a third of the time you play this game you will be staring at the load screen. Ah, so this is how they meant to artificially extend playtime.- Frustrating controls and camera angles. Why must I watch from his shoulder like a parrot? Oh, you didn't mean to hit that button? Sucks to be you. Hope you like staring at load screens.- The protagonist is mute. When he gets ripped to shreds by Necromorphs, it's gross, but I feel no sense of connection to the hero.- The asteroid-shooting mini-game is pure tedium. Pro/Cons:+/- The upgrade system is appreciated, but the changes you make to your gear don't always seem that significant. +/- There is no cooperative mode, but then being the only person accomplishing tasks ramps up the tension. +/- Objectives can be vague and will make you consult online guides, but then, this game doesn't always hold your hand. There is just a perfect amount of ammunition and supplies to keep you on the edge of your seat, amazing sequences, machines, and scenery, and it doesn't blatantly coddle the player. content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Dead Space is a third person, linear story-drivien, single player horror game. Gameplay focuses on third person shooting with some light puzzel solving.Oh, Dead Space, why did I wait so long to play you? This title has been in my backlog since 2010. I can't believe it took this long for me to play it, but I'm glad I finally did. The graphics hold up and in many cases still look amazing, but the real draw here is the ambiance. EA redwood Shores completely nails the derelict spaceship atmosphere. I'd like to put the sound design on a pedestal here as well. The 5.1 surround sound mix will instill a deep paranoia within you, making your walks through the ship extremely tense. Another stand out here is the HUD, or lack thereof. All the elements of a traditional HUD you would find in another game are here, but they are cleverly presented in a fashion (mostly through holograms) that fits the game world. You're left with a third person perspective that feels incredibly immersive and cinematic. I liked how most of the weapons had a utilitarian use (cutting, mining, torching, etc) that fit within the game world rather than just being military in design. The zero-g sections of the game did a good job of distorting your perspective and in a couple cases gave me that weird feeling in your gut like you're falling. It reminded me of Prey (2006). There's some solid Sci-Fi elements to be found here too.If there's a weak point, it comes from the story. It's not bad, but certainly not great. It doesn't bring anything new to the table and that's not necessarily a bad thing, just a little disappointing. What it does bring though, comes with competence, at least at first. The setup is perfect. You're there to investigate a communications black out. It was intriguing to unravel the mystery of what happened on the USG Ishimura. But near the end of the game, all the typical tropes and cliches of the genre surface and you're left scratching your head as to some character motivations and the would-be twists that you saw coming a mile away. Had the story been less typical and more interesting, I would call this a must play title. But it misses that mark for me. Near the end of the game I grew weary of the tasks and the "but first you need to do this" missions. I spent about fifteen hours for my play-through on normal difficulty and around hour ten I seemed to have built up a tolerance for the jump scares. My fear dropped a couple notches down to anxiety, but I'd say that's probably normal for most people and just the nature of repetition.Still, it's easy to forgive any negative points when you're having such a great time. The game lives up to the atmosphere of titles like BioShock and Resident Evil: Remastered. It's one of those games I'll buy the art book for. It's scary and well crafted throughout.TL;DR: Play this game.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Buying the Humble Origin Bundle with the knowledge that 2/3rds of the Dead Space series was included, my feelings were probably akin to a royal food tester's: I love the banquet, but the thought of that one deadly dish is absolutely terrifying. I've played my share of Survival Horror (starting with the granddaddy of them all, Alone in the Dark), but there's just something about Dead Space that's truly terrifying - the same reason Amnesia still sits on my digital shelf collecting digital cobwebs.But then the backlog starts piling, and a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do. I finished Dead Space, and that should count as something when I get to Purgatory. The worry of absolute terror never ended - that's really something considering the game clocks in about 12 hours; and most survival horror/action games usually lose the terror after a few hours of collecting heavy weaponry. I was hooked with the atmoshpere and story that borrows a lot from scifi horror greats, but somehow puts its own stamp of uniqueness on what it steals.Speaking of uniqueness, there's a lot of it in Dead Space. The gameplay twist that enemies go down easier by shooting off their limbs instead of the head sounds wonky in the beginning, but a few encounters with the necromorphs made me a believer. It's perfect because arms and legs tend to move more erraticly than one's head, which adds to the tension when aiming. Also, as a result, probably the most unique weapons I've handled in a game were created for this Dead Space. The cutter, the linegun, the ripper, all have their special use when it comes to dismemberment, with just the right amount of frustration to give them character - give them a sense that these are real tools.Another thing to note is the game's inventory system. Very much like Resident Evil's limited slot-based  inventory, complete with external storage nodes that transfer excess baggage from one spot to another, Dead Space ups the ante by adding money to the mix. This actually made inventory management fun instead of frustrating, as I was figuring out how much of which ammo I should have, I should sell in exchange for Power Nodes (basically upgrade points). It became a mini game in itself. I'd be sad to hear if this lead to the adoption of microtransactions in Dead Space 3, but for this humble begging, it's very much welcome. (It also helps that plot items have their own inventory space, so need to worry about not having a crucial item when you need it).That's Dead Space in a nutshell. A rancid, mutating death nutshell. I'm still getting that same sense of thrill/dread about sampling the next two installments, so maybe I'll give the other gut-friendlier dishes in my buffet a try for the time being.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												The first installment in the Dead Space series is set in the year 2508 and begins when a mining starship, the USG Ishimura, sends out a distress signal during a mining operation on the planet Aegis VII. In this game, players step into the role of Isaac Clarke ― a ship systems engineer whose journey starts on a seemingly routine mission to fix the communication systems on the planet cracker.It is not long until he realizes that he stepped into a living nightmare of vicious alien creatures and a dead silence ship where he must constantly fight to get out alive.The story in Dead Space is one of its strongest points. Most of it is told via video, audio and text diaries you find scattered around the ship. Another strong point is the atmosphere, a lot of it due to brilliant sound effects. It's a very impressive looking game overall, though sometimes you will feel like you are going through the same corridors over and over again. The combat is also good. Some sections may look a bit repetitive, however, the strategic dismemberment and the stomping are just extremely fun and satisfying.Being a fan of the survival horror and sci-fi genres, I played this game myself and have watched other people play it, and it simply does not get boring. It does stop being truly scary after the first few hours but jump scares are always around the corner.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												A true masterpiece. This game is a literally terrific combination of despairing emptiness, gory shootouts, and frigthening silence. It won't make itself impossible to play as Amnesia would, yet it will make you clinge to your chair and try to remember what on Earth made you start playing on the first place.Some people had problems with the camera and mouse, but I haven't seen any of that. Even more, I love how the game is controlled, similarly to Mass Effect.The lore is amazing, it will drag you and cry for more when it ends. Luckily there is more, by now. The art concept is sort of a crossover between "zombie apocalypse", "steampunk" and "space conquest", which I love to no end.You just can't go wrong buying this game.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Dead frustratingOkay, let’s get the bad out of the way first. The controls for the PC version of this otherwise good game are the worst I have ever encountered. I won’t go into detail but they’re so awkward they almost spoiled the game for me. Almost. (There are also some truly annoying problems with camera and viewpoint angles, but don’t get me started on that!) But what about the good? DEAD SPACE succeeds, despite the aforementioned problems, mainly because it oozes atmosphere. This is a very claustrophobic game that sucks you in and really does induce anxiety. You will jump many times, trust me. The story is okay, within the usual limitations of such games, the voice acting is uniformly convincing, and the graphics are good but not outstanding. Where this game excels is in the way it draws you in; immerses you in it’s dark atmosphere. This is a game that makes your palms sweat, which is exactly what it’s supposed to do.3.5/5

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I have mixed feeling for this game.Pros1. It's not a regular shooting game where you blast through your enemies and do n0 sc0p3 360. It hits the sweet spot between shooting game and horror game.2. Headshots do jack♥♥♥♥♥♥ You have to cut off their limb to do more damage. Also most weapons are designed to be good at cutting things so it is forgiving to players like me who suck at aiming.3. You get to be a engineer that kills off things and saves the day much like Gordon Freeman(my favorite protagonist).4. The ambience is great. Distant sound of crying makes you scary. Footsteps in the vents makes you♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants. You can never be confident that you are safe.Cons1. Control is just terrible. Vsync on, latency is too high. Vsync off, you can barely look around with max mouse sensitivity and 3000dpi. You have to turn on vsync in your graphic card's settings. Too small FOV doesn't help either. Movement is also very delayed.2. You can barely do anything. You can't jump, duck. I keep doing stomp attack as I press space bar expecting Isaac to jump. Compared to half life 1 and 2, it feels so stiff. It would be much better if Isaac can at least duck.3. Menus being in the game itself is very creative, but it creats problems on keyboard. You can't use mouse or movement key to navigate menu(it will just make Isaac look around or move), so you have to move one hand to seperate keys. This gets annoying quickly.4. There are not many weapons and some of them are just useless. And more weapons you have, more varied ammo drops are and more inventory clog. I only used cutter and rifle and still had inventory problem.5. Battles get old pretty quickly. Same enemy, same stratagy. Puzzles are boring and too obvious. Game just drags after chapter 5 or 6.I wouldn't recommend this for full price. But it's worth buying when on like -75% sale.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Don't let my low hours fool you. I have played through this game a number of times on my Xbox 360, but since I've stopped using my 360 (but still wanted to play this game), I bought it on Steam. Now, I thought I should address this issue first:I have heard a lot of people complain about the mouse and keyboard controls in this game. My advice: buy yourself a wired Xbox 360 controller, download the drivers for it, and use that. Apparently bad keyboard/mouse controls aside, this game does feel like it was made for controller, and the controler settings are solid.Now onto the actual game:The Positives:-- The story itself is good and I enjoyed it, but I felt like the story sometimes was a bit too far in the background (meaning I felt you were focusing purely on the objective and the story didn't really have much play in said objective). But overall, good story and despite the aforementioned, it was generally well implemented throughout the game. There are also twists, turns and little suprises that make it an awesome experience. Also, the ending was done really well!-- The atmosphere is fantastic! The got the lighting right, the sound effects right, crew logs, everything! It was just done so right!-- There are plenty of solid scares. There are some jump scares throughout the game and I know a lot of people hate those. But I'll be honest: jump scares really do work in this game.-- The weapons are very well done; although there are some weapon and general game mechanics that really do lend the player to using the basic starting weapon throughout the game (not that this is necessarilly a bad thing).-- Thought there is a realively straight forward (and argueably easy) way to play the game, there are so many other ways to play it. This ranges from weapons to the different modules (Stasis, Kenisis) to whether or not (and how) you use the object in the environment.-- There is enough variety in the enemies to make it interesting, but few enough to keep the game consistent ( if that makes sense). and as  the above point suggests, there is more than one way to fight each enemy (with the possible exception of the boss fights). I was say the enemies are very well done and always fun to fight.-- Boss fights are very well done, and the bosses are very cool!-- I know this is techincally part of the atmosphere of the game, but it is definitely worth mentioning on its own that the got creepy right! A lot of horror games get jump scares and maybe a few solid scares down-packed, but they never get the creepy element right enough to actually be creepy. This game does, and it does it well!The Negatives:-- The thumb-stick controls can sometimes feel a bit slow. It does feel like it should be a bit more twitchy. That being said, the controls do work rather well, so this negative isn't all that bad.-- Picking up items can be annoying in a select few situations. For example, an item maybe under a Stasis recharge point and instead of picking up the item, it will constantly engage the recharge point instead. That being said, there are other ways to pick up that item, but still....-- Save points are not disabled during combat. Intead of picking up ammo during a fight that I desperately needed, the game instead activated the save point and I died. To be honest, this has only ever happened once (and I've done three run throughs of this game on normal and my third attempt at doing it on hard).Overall, this dismemberment simulator is a very solid game with pretty much everything done right!9/10

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												Dead SpaceBeing honest, I would say that Dead Space is like Resident Evil 4 in space with futuristic weapons. The atmosphere throughout the campaign accomplishs what its goal, scare the hell out of you, at least in your first playthrough. More that once I was suspicious about entering a room or walking near a corpse.The graphics are pretty nice, considering its kind of an old game. I have played Dead Space only with the xbox controller, and the mapping, movement and aiming were really good; don't know about keyboard/mouse. The sound quality is amazing, the background music or noises that you hear makes you turn around and check for any foe. Sometimes when you are shooting a necromorph, you hear some odd noises behind you, and then you realize you got another necromorph behind you D:The boss battles were nice, the upgrading system with nodes, and the store had me hook up in having everything upgraded and bought.I've played Dead Space like 6 times, and I do not regret it. It is totally worth your money. Btw, I beg your pardon if I've written something wrong, as english is not my first language.

This review covers some of the features of Visceral Games' original Dead Space title that make its atmosphere effectively tense and creepy.[. . .] The sense that player-character Isaac Clarke is on his own in Dead Space is incredibly pervasive. The design of the ship often puts him in humongous corridors and chambers, and the zero-gravity mechanic in many such areas sees Clarke juxtaposed to the vastness of the distances. number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Antes de começarmos a falar deste jogo lembre-se desse nome " Warren Ellis ". Ele foi um dos escritores e produtores do jogo,onde todos queriam caminhar para um lado tendo Dead Space como um shooter em terceira com muito ação  e tiroteio ele foi o cara que disse "NÃO" Eu quero corpos dilacerados no chão muito sangue e um bela doze de horror,e em uma de suas entrevistas ele disse exatamente isso " Eu quero que o jogador tenha medo de jogar Dead Space " .Muitos podem ir de encontro mas pra min foi satisfatório.Dead Space faz com grande perfeição o que muitos jogos não tiveram capacidade de mostrar.Nesse jogo simplesmente não há limites para o horror ,de inicio a proposta é fraca,mas conforme a campanha vai se desenrolando  obriga o jogador a buscar o seu desfecho .O jogo possui uma jogabilidade honesta sem muito segredo e o nível de dificuldade em certos momentos chega a ser intrigante ,há diversos monstros na tela que o impossibilitam de realizar o seus atos . A escassez de munições e suprimentos de saúde é o ponto positivo e álíbi que o jogue tem de te mostrar que não é apenas atirar,atirar,atirar e atirar,de certa forma a outras formas de buscar o seu objetivo é claro dentro dos limites pré estabelecidos dentro do jogo .Em partícular eu recomendo joga-lo com Headset de alta qualídade ou média,pois o som do jogo é um absurdo de bom,foi realizado um  ótimo trabalha pela Visceral ao aplicar o som de maneira impecável nos ambientes da nave em que se passa o jogo.O fator medo esta presente em todo o jogo,inclusive há momentos em que aquele susto é inevitavel o jogo consegue fazer isso de forma simples e eficazAgora a controversia ,um grande título não é composto a penas por pontos posítivos e sim por negativos,sendo assim aqui fica alguns .• O personagem principal Isaac Clarke provavelmente deve ter o seus diálogos censurado dentro do jogo,pois eu não ouvi um diálogo se quer ,lamentável,deve ter esquecido de colocar algumas falas para ele,pois o que ele faz no jogo é fazer o que lhe é pedido sem argumentar em ipotese alguma .• Personagens sem carisma.• Muitos críticam que Dead Space é somente um corredor escuro com alguns monstro e nada mais.SIM! seria mais o menos isso,não á variações de monstros e o cenários são repetidos,muda algumas coisas de um para o outro .• Parte dos objetivos são clichês de outros jogos e chegar a ser cansativo . Definitivamente Dead Space traz o que há de melhor no cenário de horror SCI-FI.

content:
Posted: February 8
												I played this game in 2017.After hearing much about it and seeing it on the steam winter sales,I decided to give it a go. And oh boy...I had a blast with Dead Space.This game holds up really well after 9 years. The graphics have aged very nicelyand the gameplay is by now legendary and for good reason.This game throws the most horrifying creatures at you to fight and hopefully survive. The fact that you have to shoot their limbs offis a huge breath of fresh air from the typical headshots. You are given a small but funvariety of weapons to kill the necromorphs and an amazing setting.The space station that has gone completely to♥♥♥♥♥♥is creepy as hell but beautiful at some moments.The tight hallways make every corner super scary.The part I liked the least was the story. It might have been a bit confusing at times but it was a greatmistery and a cool adventure.All together:If you wanna try something old but GOLD, Dead Space is well worth the 10 bucks it is right now.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												For what it's worth, it's not much of a horror game. It's one of those adventure shooters that has ugly enemies. Whenever you pass by vents or see necromorph corpses that hasn't been disfigured, you'll already know that they're just there for jump scares. I will give points for the creepy atmosphere and all the bloody, organic rooms will give you chills. Bosses are also great, even though there's only three. The first one you encounter will let you use one of the game's mechanics of zero gravity jumps to dodge tentacles which makes you seem VERY cool and badass. The second one, I didn't enjoy much since I suck at aiming and then there's the gun overheating. The third and last one was actually a let-down compared the first one, which you'd expected it to be more of an overkill, slightly surviving with a slither of HP. The only thing good that came out of the last boss was how it picked you up and you were forced to use inverted controls to make you panic than you usually would. Then there's the storyline. I feel the twists were from an M. Night Shyamalan movie. You can already foreshadow what'll happen and the twists wouldn't really amuse you. It'll just give you sense of saying, "Welp, more work to do.". Character developement are pretty bad. All you know about the protagonist is that he's here on an adventure to find his girlfriend and slowly becoming loopy while not knowing about it. Really, the only thing that comes out of the storyline is the lore and backstory and most people who comes to shooters just want to use their itchy trigger-fingers and kill everything on sight. All-in-all, this game is just a generic shooter from Point A to Point B. It's a great shooter from its time I'll agree to that; however, it's not a scary game if you're wanting to buy this game for that sole purpose.+ Gameplay+ Use of Mechanics+ Puzzles+ Backstory- Current Game Storyline (Dead Space II or III might have a better storyline, which I'll have to see)- Final BossI'll give it a 3/5.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
Genre: Over-the-shoulder-TPS "Survival" HorrorReccommendation: A must play if you seek a challenging horror game with survival elements.Playtime: ~24 hoursRating: 9/10Review:One of the best sci-fi horror games out there. It's a Third Person Shooter, with an emphasis on aiming for the limbs of enemies rather than the body itself or the head. It is scary, but it's mostly just suspense, although very gruesome. This game's UI (User Interface) takes place as bars on the back of your suit (easy to see though), and windows are "2.5D" and they're on the world rather than on your HUD.Warning: If you are not okay with scary games, or you have a weak stomach, or you simply dislike gore, this game is likely not for you.The game has a very deep storyline, centering on a "Maintenance Mission" over at a wrecked spaceship, overrun by alien lifeforms which turned the spaceship's crew into mutants.As for gameplay, you are given "cutting" weapons, with a sort of laser sights so you can see the cutting area, and you have to aim at body parts like the shoulders, arms, hands, legs... Some enemies have other "parts". You need to learn how to kill each and every enemy efficiently in order to conserve ammo and health, as items are limited in this game. In this game there is also zero gravity areas where you'll be able to move around more freely (but not float around), and stand on most walls you see. Some areas have no oxygen, and your Air meter will run down per second, until you reach an area with oxygen. You are also able to use "Stasis", used for slowing down objects and enemies, giving you a better chance at doing certain things, especially saving ammo.Almost everything is upgradeable, including your HP, Air meter, Stasis, the damage/capacity/reload/speed of your weapons, Etc. This is done by consuming Power Nodes at an Upgrade Bench. You can buy those at stores, finding them around the ship, or receive them for killing powerful enemies.If you decide to play on Hard Mode, this is where the game truly shines. You'll need to be very careful on how you use your weapons, and you need to be aware of your surroundings. Items are used up quicker on Hard Mode, and you might see yourself going around with low HP often. I myself reccommend to play on Hard Mode, since this is a not-so-short game and Hard Mode makes it even longer and more interesting.Stability wise, this game isn't so good for that. It is rather old, but not too old, and normally plays well on most computers. There is, unfortunately, a "mouse lag" glitch, where aiming will never actually be smooth. It's easy to overcome this glitch though, and keep playing on while ignoring it.Tip: Disable V-Sync (Vertical Sync) on the in-game video options before you start playing, as it will only cause a lot of trouble and it'll increase the mouse lag further if left enabled.Replayability is okay, but the game is always interesting and fun no matter what.TL;DR: Really nice semi-scary game, lots of gore, very immersive and promotes aiming strategically. My rating is 9/10, almost the best game I've ever played.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I have no idea why this has so many positive reviews. Yes, Dead Space is an amazing game… On console. However this is the absolute worst PC Port ever released. The PC port is one of the most broken things I've ever attempted to play. KB&M controls flat-out don't work and you get insane input lag when playing with a controller. And you are stuck between two abysmal choices. You can either play at an unlocked framerate, and have shadows and lights flash in migraine inducing strobes until you reach a point in the game where your unlocked framerate breaks the games logic and you become trapped by invisible walls that you can't get around without restarting the game, and I mean restarting, as in actually starting again from the beginning. Or you can enable V-Sync and the game locks the framerate to your monitors lowest possible refresh rate, which for me was a hot 24 fps. Yes. 24 fps. Can you play a shooter at sub 30, with a controller? I sure can't. Oh, it also crashes, often. If you really need to revisit Dead Space, sadly playing on console is the only viable option. Oh, and you'll likely end up unable to refund the game because it stays running in the background after you close it. Thankfully Dead Space 2 and 3 seem to run fine.TLDR: Great game, worst port of all time. Play it on console.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I've always heard great things about this game, and the hype is right! I've finished the game and can barely wait to start the sequel!It's an over-the-shoulder shooter (much like Resident Evil or Mass Effect), and the immersion is incredible. There's no HUD blocking the screen, ammo displays are on weapons and your health is displayed on the back of your character's suit. All the in-game menus (Maps, Inventory, Journal, etc) as well as video and audio communication are displayed with holographic projections from your suit. The game also has areas of zero-gravity where you must navigate your way by flying across the rooms, and hopefully not plunge into deep space.The player takes the role of Isaac Clarke, an engineer and space ship systems specialist sent as part of a repair mission to the USG Ishimura, a large scale mining vessel. Upon arrival you quickly realize that disaster has struck the Ishimura and spend the game trying to get out alive. Throughout the game you can upgrade the space hazmat suit you wear, as well as buy and upgrade various weapons. The majority of the weapons you acquire are improvised tools, such as plasma cutters and buzz saws, reflecting that you're primarily an engineer, and not a soldier.All in all it's a great buy; solid gameplay, a gripping story, and an incredible soundtrack. I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												There's no denying that Dead Space is at least a little creepy, with it's suffocating corridors, hellish necromorphs, and the vast open terror of space itself, all to be explored alone on tight ammo. It's a bit repetative when played alone, as you gradually come to expect everything (although it can be fun in the dark with a good pair of headphones...), but there's an easy remedy for that:Grab a friend, sibling, spouse, parent, legal guardian, acquaintence, dependent, or otherwise to help you out. They work the keyboard and you work the mouse. I can say from experience that when both of you are relatively inexperienced with playing keyboard and mouse, and both of you are fresh players, it's a good time. The panic doubles, as not only do you not know what the game's AI is doing, but you also have no idea what your partner is doing. The ensuing madness is a romp; you gotta try it at least once.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Finished the game on Medium difficulty.One of the best action-horror games I've played.  +Interesting story w/ good twists+Great pacing - constant feeling of tension.+Great sound - you will hear things you can't see, like creepy whispers, things crawling around, and creepy growls/shrieks.+Great action - the dismemberment system is a lot of fun.  Forces you to carefully aim in tense situations.+Feeling of progression - upgradeable equipment/armor.  +Little to no backtracking. -This is a personal complaint, but a 180 degree turn like in the action Resident Evil games would've been helpful.-Vsync forces 30fps.  I get about 350+ fps w/ vsync off with my gtx 970, causing horrible screentearing.  Vsync w/ nvidia control panel didn't work so I used D3DOverrider to force vsync at 60fps.  A small annoying step, but it's easy to do and IMO necessary to get the best experience.  +/- Graphics - played this 2008 game in 2014.  Sometimes the graphics look very good, sometimes it looks dated.  However, it never took away from the immersion.+/- You might not like how much of the game is in a confined space. I liked it b/c it made things more tense.+/- The field of view might be too limited for you.  I thought it was fine and never noticed it until I read complaints. TL;DR - Buy if you want a sci-fi game that scares you, but still gives you the power to kill everything.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2012
												Definitely a game at the very least worth playing. Dead Space brings to the table elements of both survival-horror and RPG while maintaining a (third-person) shooter image. The storyline is fairly well written as while it's nothign special, it works out and it isn't boring really. The game itself is challenging but not in an attritional sense where it's only hard because of the sheer amount of enemies as opposed t the design and challenges itself. It's a hard game but not unfair (unless you pick that difficulty!). The gameplay is fluid and the battles are fun whilst challenging.It's also a great thriller game, with many moments made to get you to jump in your seat.Graphically speaking it's not a Crysis-level game but it still looks pretty damn good. The weapons and environemnts look nice, and the armour shines very well. You won't be disappointed.Maybe not worth $50 any more, but with how differently you can play with the varying weapons and abilities, it definitely has some replayability. Try to pick it up when you can.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												I'm not typically into horror titles, but I really liked this game. You don't play as a front-line combat jock, but as an engineer. Movement isn't fluid like most 3rd person shooters. The aliens you fight don't die from just getting shot, you need to figure out how to cripple and deal with them with your limited ammunition, and usually using unorthodox weapons. The sound is great and you might just be too creeped out to turn the lights off at the end of the night. All-in-all I really enjoyed it and even beat it twice. The other games in the series move further away from the horror aspect and become more fluid shooter titles.I've played with keyboard & mouse and a 360 controller. Both schemes have flaws, with the controller not having enough sensitivity, and the K&M seeming to have a sensitivity filter added at weird times. Steam has edited my play time for some reason. This game used to boot through steam, then through origin, and now back in steam.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Worth a purchase at a much reduced price like $5.  The plot line is absolutely atrocious although I have to remind myself that with how old this is, it might have just been growing pains of a genre.  It felt like someone opened the trope/McGuffin book and was racing to get as many in as they could before the game ended.  I started to keep a running tally, mocking the story to my friends as I went chapter by chapter.  But I played it all of the way to the end.  I even hypothesized why I didnt quit this like I did many other lackluster games in my Steam library.  After fixing the mouse issue, the game controls perfectly like it should for a horror game.  Just methodical enough for you to agonize if you are going to make the shot towards the monster charging at you.  The setting, level design (although its repeated), and above all the atmosphere are top notch.  The light RPG customization, zero G fights, the variations of QTEs, bosses, and regular minion waves that you can run right by.  The story setpieces almost detract from the moment to moment of playing the game.  I made to the end happy for the silly story to be over but appreciative of everything else.  It was worth the time to finish it, and I havent finished a game in a very long time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												I love to hate it.Iam easily scared by jumpscares in videogames and Dead Space does it's job really well. In fact its predecessor Dead Space2 was the first of these kinds of games i forced myself through.I played this halfway through on a Xbox360 but never managed to get through completly... I will try to change that. Im just not that fast at it. I usally play 30minutes at a time, maybe that will increase over timeBesides my own cowardness, this game is really good. Especially how it manages jumpscares.You walk down a dark hallway, suddenly a random pipe bursts..."haahahahaha fooled you!...- No really, the monster is behind you."I fell for that one multiple times.I really like the story going on, thats whats getting me to start the game again from time to time.Buisnesswise it's a great example of an AA Game. It doesn't had a big marketing campaign and it didn't need to "appeal to a broader audience" like Dead Space 3. It was made for people who like to play horror games and that was just fine. Unfortunatly those days are long gone. With Dead Space3 we finally arived in an era where every game has to appeal to everyone, especially to CoD Players, since CoD is the best selling game ever (at that time) and EA wanted a piece of that cake too. It's just that CoD Players usally play CoD and are not that much interested in Horrorgames that try to appeal to them. Anyway, Dead Space is a gem of the days when development budgets weren't so high and the expectations neither. When a game could still be a sucess without selling 7 million copies. Dead Space knows what it wants to be (a mean ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that is) and pulls it of perfectly.If you are into horrorgames, this should be a nobrainer. Keep calm and shoot of their limbs.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Immersive, Impressive, Addictive...the more you play it, the more you love it...I'm just six years late to start playing Dead Space. I must confess it wasn't my favorite game sytle until last week. So I decided to go through it and here I am: looking foward to go playing through the dead space trilogy...amazing game, awesome details, interesting atmosphere, very good sound effects and cinematics. The surprising features:1. The game engine is smooth with loading screens only in chapter transitions;2. The level design is amasingly perfect and creepy as well;3. Overall plot is very good and its main and secondary objectives are interesting;4. There are two mini games on it;5. Weapons visual, sound, and physical effects are really cool. No standard military weapons;6. Enemies are creepy and disgusting...but funny to kill;7. Boss fights are good;8. There are 'store feature' that allow you buying and selling in game items;9. Weapon upgrades are enjoyable and worth;10. In game player interfaces are well developed and animated (cargo lift buttoms, weapon benches, stores, control pannels);11. Looting system provides well balanced sort of items throughout the whole game (ammo, medkits, money, etc);12. Zero gravity missions and fights are as awesome as tense;13. Different sort of weapons provides an interesting replayability. Try only few weapons at a time and see the difference in game play and difficulty level;14. Story telling is well balanced between direct dialogs and in game information (video logs, text logs, cut scenes, etc).Overall, the game is still worth playing even at 6 years later. Just play it and have fun.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Although the game can seem a bit long for how simple the synopsis and variety of encounters are, the sense that the pacing is strange and unpredictable only amplifies the effects of the atmosphere.  The game mechanics are suited exceptionally well to the horror environment, not only leaving you with limited resources and carrying space, but also requiring some intelligent and unique aiming requirements that set the experience apart from the world of headshots typical of a game with guns.Not every situation uses the mechanics in an exceptionally exciting way, but each has at least one encounter which fits it perfectly, and justifies it's existence.  It can be hard to stick with at times, but overall felt worthwhile.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Having played the demo on the Xbox 360, I had to get this when it was on sale. I've always been a fan of Resident Evil (1, 2, 3, 4, REmake) and this immediately caught my eye. This really is like the Alien of the gaming world (as another review states), and if the games based off the Alien movies were THIS good I would have bought them all. It's got great graphics, fantastic acting, a gripping and chilling story accompanied by a great soundtrack and an insanely fun choice of weapons.It's jumpy as hell, if you can't handle jumping out of your skin every few minutes then this might not be your game. It creeped me out so much at one point I had to take a break, but all the while I just wanted to jump back on and keep going.Honestly, I struggle to find anything bad about this game. Yes, it is THAT good. My ONLY gripe is it's quite tricky to get mouse sensitivity the way you want...but, me being a gamepad user, this didn't bother me too much.9/10, easily one of the best games I ever played. In years to come, I'll still be playing it.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is an interesting trilogy so I had to start from the beginning. Although there are a few parts that make it feel like Dead Space: Prepare To Die Edition this is a great game. The weapons and powers are cool. Everybody thinks Resident Evil in space but it's actually got A 3rd person Crysis look also. The creatures are INSANE, better than Doom III. Whoever designed them, pure genius, just VERY cool. If you are a fan of 3rd person shooters, this is a must have game. If you are a fan of horror, this is a must have game. If you are a fan of both, like I am, then you will be VERY happy that you gave it a chance. The creatures, weapons, and innovative gameplay are what make this game SO worth every penny. Playing Dead Space 2 soon and will review as soon as I finish the game but I already know that it will be even better somehow. Dead Space 3 is the questionable one, I guess it is unavailable on Steam but I will have to at least give it a chance too when it goes down in price enough. I am a thrifty PC Gamer but this game was a smart buy!

content:
Posted: April 13
												TIME TO COMPLETE: 13.5 hoursBack when I first played Dead Space on the Xbox 360 it was the game which scared me; now it's the controls.I feel as if I should get this aspect cleared out first. The controls kinda suck and even on the highest sensitivity the clunkiness what still there to a certain extent though you'll be surprised when you get used to it looking back. It's more like that kind of game where you have to take a couple minutes to get used to them each time you start it up but then master them with ease.The weapons are great. There's something for each when it comes to a form of dismemberment but while I think you're not really dependant on any there's still the same 4 weapons you'll stick to every time you play. Considering that later on you'll probably upgrade them only strengthens the point further. The story seemed to have a much faster pacing than before though that could be said of many replays of different games. Nothing felt rushed and the story manages to captivate you no matter how much but overall it tends to be cliche. Without spoiling anything back in 2008 there was still a lot of unexplored ground but even then I wouldn't have considered it an original idea aside from the iconic, industrial aesthetic Dead Space has.As far as chapters or levels go you have 12 of them, each "moduled" into contained segments. While this kind of design is almost a synonim to linearity it makes up for when taken apart. You'd have a  friend come over and play a chapter from the middle of the game without necessarily needing to fill in what happened. Tight animations, "resource management" type of combat - that's what this game is.Overall Dead Space is a fun adventure for those who wish to play a horror game or shoot Necromorphs (or "alien zombies", whatever you wanna call 'em) in a manner similar to Doom 3. I had a pretty solid, almost "cinematic" experience with it and for the price it gets when on sale it's a nice offer. Dead Space is clearly a classic of the horror genre.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Dead Space relies very heavily on jumpscares and shocking imagery for it's horror. Don't get me wrong, it can certainly get quite tense every now and again, but it never really starts to feel like a 'Survival Horror' game as the game is fairly generous with both ammunition and health. Unless you're playing on higher difficulties you're probably not going to find the game all too challenging to be honest.That being said, Dead Space ironically excels at one of the aspects often done poorly in horror titles: It's combat. Almost every weapon in your arsenal is viable in any situation, giving you some very refreshing freedom to find a playstyle that suits you. The violence and gore is definitely also satisfying for those of us that enjoy watching limbs come flying off. The voiceacting is solid and the soundwork in general is very tight.You are very rarely (if ever) bored while playing Dead Space as you'll find yourself utterly immersed in it's great combat almost all the time, except for when the game gives you a break, typically in the form of exposition-sequences or fairly decent puzzles. While you don't have to be a math student to get over these hurdles they can definitely throw a spanner in the works every now and again. 7/10 - Complete with a compelling story with a few surprising twists along the way I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes gore, violence and a character that controls like a tank. The only real downsides to this game I can think of off the top of my head is perhaps the slight lack of challenge, the unreasonably confusing map, and the fact that it has some severe issues with Mous/Keyboard controls. A gamepad is strongly recommended for this title.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Short verdict: a door opening simulator that pretends to be scary.Deadspace had a potential. It's, in general, a decent game and there are a few good things in it, but those good things are overshadowed by stupid concepts and suboptimal controls.I'll start with the good things.- "Dead Space" is, all-in-all, a well-polished game. It runs smoothly, everything is thoroughly designed. When there's so many buggy and sloppy games out there, it matters. However, I encountered a game-breaking bug at the end of Chapter 11, when I couldn't open a door and it was on stand-by constantly. I had to use another player's save file that I've downloaded from the Internet to finish the game.- There is a nice set of weapons that you can upgrade. Upgrades are always a good thing, aren't they?- The level design is intuitive. And even, if you're not sure where to go, you can activate the path marking. That is very handy. It's much better than a mini-map.- 95% of the time game responds to your needs. Low on health? You get a health pack in the next crate or enemy. Low on ammo? Same thing.- Apart from shooting enemies, you also have some powers: stasis let's you slow down enemies and time; kinesis allows you to move objects/body parts. There are also zero-gravity areas, where you can walk on the walls and jump over large distances.Frankly, I didn't enjoy those powers and I absolutely hated the zero gravity missions. I'd rather prefer just shooting the hell out of things. But, at least the devs have tried and variety doesn't hurt. So, I appreciate that.And, now, (TA-DA-DA-DAAH), the bad things:- You need to dismember enemies to kill them. No, a headshot is not enough. A body shot does minimum damage. You need to shoot off their limbs/tentacles. It's so unnatural and because of the problematic aiming, also annoying.- On medium and higher difficulties, the enemies are bullet damage sponges. To shoot off a fricking tentacle, you need 2+ direct hits.  A fricking tentacle! Not an armored tentacle. Not a metal tentacle. Just a simple, tiny, soft-tissue tentacle! It just doesn't make sense. While playing on medium difficulty, I was constantly low on ammo in the last few chapters.(Note: on easy, it's a cake walk. You can shoot without any worries about ammo count).- Controls. The character is slow. Melee animation takes approximately 3-4 seconds to finish. The aiming lags. It's hard to hit a target, especially, in those sequences, when you're grabbed by that gigantic tentacle with the yellow bulb.Also, I played this game with an Xbox controller. It's easier like that. And, apparently, this game was primarily made with consoles in mind (framerate capped at 30 FPS, unmentioned controller support, cheats work only with a gamepad), BUT, when I need to shoot the asteroids or the monster in the outer space from a cannon, that is accomplishable only with a mouse. In short, this game has some serious camera and sensitivity issues. Some players even say that it's unplayable. And it's not much of an exaggeration.- Forced and narrow FOV. Unfortunately, Dead Space is not a first-person shooter. You have a very limited field of vision. I understand that the devs did that to prevent the players to notice the enemies that crawl behind, to make it more scary. But it's not scary. It's just inconvenient and, occasionally, annoying, especially, in some puzzles, when you need to oversee a large area, but you can't, because of the FOV.- The whole dismemberment concept. The idea is that the corpses can't transform into the monsters (necromorphs), if they are dismembered, and some might think that it's cool and gory. Except that it isn't. It's stupid and childish. And, since the human corpse dismemberment doesn't have any impact on the gameplay and, most of the time, you dismember the monsters with weapons anyway, so why bother? I think that it's a failed concept.- It's not atmospheric, it's not scary. There's nothing "horror" about it. The game overuses jump scares to make it seem scary, but it fails. Without the proper atmosphere, those things just do not work. Also, there are a lot of safe zones in between. So, no sweat. Not that I care, I just like to shoot things. But, for those of you who do care, I recommend F.E.A.R. It does a much, much better job at creating a tense atmosphere.- The story is mediocre. And many questions are left unanswered. I did understand what happened before and during the events of the game. And there are some explanations of why some characters did what they did, and what is the history with the Marker and the Church of Unitology. But those explanations are bad. It just doesn't make sense to me. I watched this video to find the answers: 


YouTube™ Video: The mostly accurate lore of Dead Space 

			Views: 32,019		

			Before you play Dead Space 3, you'll probably want to get caught up on the lore. Here is a way that you could that. Before you ask, yes, that is a dry-erase marker, no, swords aren't canon, and yes...		

 But it still seems like a non-sense to me.- Puzzles. Firstly, puzzles in a shooter? Why? Second, they are boring and all the same: you just need to re-arrange objects. Third, the FRICKING NARROW FOV!!!It's hard for me to decide, whether to put "thumbs up" or "down", but I think, all-in-all, Dead Space gameplay is so problematic that I can't recommend it. I did not really enjoy playing it, I finished it only because it was not bad enough not to finish it.My overall rating: 5/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												It's unfortunate, but, before I was able to really play this game, the option of giving it a positive review went right out the window. Yet again, a publisher treated the PC version of a title like an afterthought and gave us a slapped together copy/paste P.O.S. console port that CANNOT RUN WITHOUT THE AID OF THIRD-PARTY SOFTWARE. The vsync is broken and locks the game at 30 fps, and if you turn it off (assuming you can get past the screen tearing) it actually causes quite a few problems with the game. I can only assume that the movement and camera controls are in some way dependent on polling the framerate because it actually causes the mouse to have major problems and creates an invisible wall in a doorway very early on in the game. This can be fixed, but not without disabling the in-game vsync and forcing it through 3rd party software - in fact, the forced vsync option in AMD's Crimson control panel can't even get it to work (and from what I read, this is the same with the default control panel for NVIDIA cards) so you have to use a program like RadeonPro to get it to work properly.If that wasn't bad enough, the controller support is terrible. First, there are no separate controller / keyboard & mouse settings - this is an all-too-common problem with PC games and it really shouldn't be; I often like to switch between the two (and I know I'm not alone), but, without separate settings for a controller, I have to pause the game, go into the control settings and properly invert the Y-axis every time I want to use the controller and then disable it every time I want to use the keyboard & mouse - they are entirely disparate control systems that require their own settings. And just in case that wasn't aggravating enough, you actually have to enable/disable the controller entirely, adding an additional, tedious step to an already tedious process.  Even if you decide to just commit to the controller entirely (and let's face it, unless you want to be constantly bouncing in and out of the settings window, you kind of have to), the deadzones on the control-sticks are HUGE so moving the camera with any kind of precision is out of the question, and precision aiming is a KEY game mechanic in Dead Space - you're supposed to slice apart the enemies limb-by-limb. They don't even offer a camera sensitivity slider for the controller - just the mouse - so to use a controller you have to use something like Durazno - an Xinput modification program - and bump up the anti-deadzone to 45%-50%.I hate leaving a bad review for this game because, so far, the game itself seems great, and if you're someone who is willing to take the time and effort to get it working, you'll probably really enjoy it (just make sure you get it on sale). But when a publisher refuses to put the time and money into making a true PC version of thier game and instead just s*** out some console-to-PC-port garbage that won't even run without putting in hours of time troubleshooting issues that should have been ironed out before the game was ever released, I can't and won't give it anything less than a scathing review. F*** you very much, EA!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Not many horror games use space as the backdrop and the few that do, usually do so with raving success. Dead Space is part of that. It's terrifying, but like any scary game, the longer you play it, the more desensitized to the fear you get. That and paired with the fact that you eventually (should you choose to) upgrade your weapons to a high degree usually means the monsters that scare you die in embarassing fashion.The method is in which this game does go out to scare you is cheap as well. There are a lot of jump scares and set pieces. Any time you enter a large enough room, you know there will be an ambush. Eventually, you can start predicting when the scares happen. Monsters come out through vents and the predictable blind corner will usually have one waiting for you. Vents are scattered throughout the ship you're stranded on, so when you instinctively feel like an ambush is going to happen, it's easy to set yourself up and defend the waves.Good game overall. Scary games of this type should be shorter though because you can feel that the developers themselves know that you're no longer scared so what they'll do with ambushes is just increase the waves, turning what's supposed to be scary into a full blown shoot out with paced rumbles that can sometimes last longer than you have patience for.The Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star rendition was sp00ky though.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												I played this game a while back & it had some serious problems.  Those problems still persist today.V-sync is broken.  It locks FPS to 30 & causes severe input lag.  Turning off V-sync breaks the game & renders it nearly unplayable.  You need to either use RadeonPro for AMD, or turn off V-sync in the game & turn it on in the control panels for your GPU.The aiming is terrible.  Using a Logitech F310 controller roughly 30% of the joytick is deadzoned.  This means you have to move the (R) joystick a rediculous amount just to get the aim to move slightly & moving it a tiny bit more will cause it to swing your aim far beyond where you're actually trying to aim.  KB/Mouse controls are even worse & revolve around negative mouse acceleration combined w/ a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥emulation of the controller aiming.  There is a fix for the mouse you can find here.  It's not really a "fix" as it just speeds up the mouse input which in turn makes it impossible to use the mouse in the menus.  You have to use keys for menus with this fix.http://steamcommunity.com/app/17470/guides/#scrollTop=522Asides those two issues the game is good but you will be frustrated with the aiming because there is no real fix for it that I can find other than increasing the mouse speed.  Good luck trying to play this with a controller as the dead zone on aiming is ridiculous.  I managed to beat it using KB/Mouse after using the fix but it was still frustrating as all hell.  Not recommending it because it's a bad port or just doesn't run well on modern machines.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												Dead Space:TL;DR A msut play for any fan of survival-horror games.If you hate jumpscares there are a few in here but not too many as to turn you away.Full disclosure: NewGame+ 3 on retail disc.===========================================================================================================Pros: * Intense atmosphere of fear and anxiety* Excellent gore and physics* Masterful sound track that really sets the atmosphere up* Graphics are great and show little signs of age even after 8 years* Interesting puzzles* Animations are beautiful and fluid, you can actually feel the weight of Isaac's boots with each step* Voice actors are amazing* Necromorphs (monsters) are horrifyingly ugly, in a good way* Higher difficulty settings make ammo and health items more scarce and increase the necromorph population* The story is interesting and well made* Silent protagonist that fits well within the story* The gunplay and alternate fire modes are incredible in conjunction with the dismemberment system* Badass armor and weapons* Great upgrade system for the weapons and suit* New Game +* Inventory management is spot on and only makes the game more challenging* The game has no hud, instead the ammo counter and reticule are holograms from, the weapon and your inventory and video logs are holograms from your suit allowing you to move and explore while watching a log or managing your inventory.===========================================================================================================Minor Gripes:* While the camera is great for the most part, there are times where I wish I could swap shoulders to see around a corner better. It also feels a bit close at times but your character never obscures your view.* When trying to pick up a specific item on the ground can be a bit hard to grab the intended item when there are more than one in close proximity.* Controls are a bit hard to get used to on keyboard and mouse (specifically the menu navigation)* Enemies come from the vents on occasion which makes it rather obvious where they are going to spawn, which loosens the tension a bit* The areas with no oxygen are a bit annoying if you like to sightsee===========================================================================================================Cons:* Your money is going to Electronic Arts so they can continue their crusade against free will and good games.===========================================================================================================

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Third Person Shooter with horror elements. You are Isaac Clarke and you are an engineer. You are investigating research space station with which you lost contact. You discover that someting horrible has happened and now you have to fight for your survival. The story keeps you playing for a long hours.Audio9/10Graphics7.5/10Gameplay7.5/10Story8/10Time to beat11hrsSummary8.5/10PROS Pretty visuals with nice "black and white" concept Atmospheric Some views can still be breathtaking Findings. Lots of audio and text logs, which help you understand the story better. Great music playing in the background. Sound effects are very well prepared. They build the tension. Can be challenging. Some pretty nice scary moments. Captivating, interesting story Possibility to upgrade your weapons and suit.CONS Controls could be a lot better. ( I was playing mouse + keyboard ). Sometimes I was feeling like errand boy. "Isaac, do that!", "Isaac, go there!", "Isaac, fix this!". Come on! YOU'RE NOT MY SUPERVISOR! There're moments where graphics are noticably out-dated. But it don't mind in the end :) Final boss is a joke. Incredibly easy. Rigidbody gets crazy sometimes. Dead bodies can get stuck in various places.
