number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												A seemingly easy investigation mission of the distress signals sent by a peculiar space vessel named Ishimura will lead you, Isaac Clarke, into the living horrors of deep space as you will delve into the nightmarish abyss created by an unknown and bizarre force. During this journey you will uncover the tale of USG Ishimura and what went awry on it, and, of course, you will meet its new "inhabitants".Storywise, the game narrative develops pleasantly, in a progressive pattern, as our protagonist ventures deeper into the space vessel to find out the truth about it, therefore you don't need to worry for a "bland" and "colorless" story, this game managing to deliver a multitude of emotions towards the player, from empathy and guilt to fear and horror.Furthermore, leaving the story aside, in my playthrough at least, I have never encountered a single software "bug", the only inconvenience I met was the camera movement sensitivity, even at maximum being too slow-moving and burdensome for my taste, but of course, that is only a personal issue. Moreover, in terms of features, this game comes with a nice upgrading mechanic, done at 'Benches' you encounter throughout the chapters with special obtainable items called 'Power Nodes', which are found, in most cases, in places you would normally miss, so don't forget to search thoroughly for those 'Power Nodes' because the game rewards handsomely those that collect them. Besides this feature, a thing to note is the saving system which is by 'Saving Stations' spread throughout the map. Shops are also a nice touch, the game letting you buy and sell equipment at your own discretion rather than forcing you to scrape by on what you find. Also, I would like to mention that Dead Space shares some similarities with Doom 3 and The Suffering in terms of story and gameplay, so, if you liked one of these titles you will certainly love this one.This title really deserves the praise it got from its cult because it's an outstanding example of the Horror genre in video games and I kindly recommend it to everyone in search of a finely crafted game.

												Dead space has got to be the creepiest most visceral horror shooter I've ever played, more so than FEAR. The story is genuinely interesting, but the world itself more so.  Highly recommended.

												In space, no one can hear you scream -- or so went the tagline for a certain film set in space on a ship where things go terribly wrong a million miles from Earth. It's a classic game; dark, moody, dripping with the creeping terror that seeks your flesh as you trudge through the halls of the doomed USG Ishimura on a repair mission gone awry. content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Freaking scary imo. Very nice atmosphere. Especially the sounds are really awesome and make me♥♥♥♥♥♥my pants. Bought it for 2,50€ and very happy with it.The PC version has some problems which you can FIX easily. If you have too much Frames you will have bugs and the v-sync option ingame will make your mouse/joypad have a big inputlag.I used the program "nvidia inspector" and locked the frames at 73 (because i have a 75hz monitor) and activated v-sync through the program. With this settings the game works fine. Also the ingame "antialiasing" option is very bad so activate it through "nvidia inspector". I have it on 8MSAA and it looks very nice.Here some links how to fix the bugs (if you dont fix it you cant even get through the first door) and how to activate AntiAliasing.AntiAliasing/Antistropic Filtering -->  http://forums.guru3d.com/showthread.php?t=357956AntiAliasing/Antistropic Filtering -->  http://www.gargi.org/showthread.php?3609-Dead-Space-Antialiasing-auf-Nvidia-Karten-aktivierenBug fixing --> http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1725482You are a horror and sci-fi fan and still have not played this game yet? content:
Posted: September 9, 2012
												The number of inventory slots you have isn't enough to carry sufficient ammo from one Store to the next. I was running out of my bullet-based guns every time.Also, it seems like they had a real-time inventory just because they could. They don't even let you sprint when using it, so the only time you can use an invntory item is when there aren't enemies around. This means no stasis recharge and no oxygen recharge when you really need it. More realistic you say? It's the lack of realism that makes games fun. Get slashed once and die like you would in real life, then see if you like realism.Almost didn't complete this because the Store is real-time as well, so I couldn't resupply when there were enemies around. Just had to run for it. it means I couldn't complete the last part of the game which required guns, and I had to download an invincibility hack.Well worth its £3.00  =]

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2011
												This is a prime example of what happens when developers stop developing for PC and make games targeted for consoles only.  It is a game that wants to be System Shock.  It is filled with all the obligatory suvival horror tropes even down to monsters coming out of walls, harsh shadows, monsters playing dead, and the requisite jump scenes.  What it fails to deliver is gameplay that is actually any fun.  It starts well, and brings in neat features like zero-gravity, time-dilation, and telekinesis.  However, In short order managing those features, and their related resource constraints, becomes just another chore.  All this is even get past the absolute worst part of this game: the nonresponsive controls that just scream "Nerfed for Console Use".  I wouldn't spend more than $15 for this one.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												The second I started playing this game, I knew that it was special. This game perfectly blends quick responce and beutifuly smooth combat with a suspensful, scarry and well designed atmosphere. The enemys in this game are downright terrifying, and the story is awesome. The game has a linier campain, but is packed full of Bioshock-like RPG elements. The scarres in this game are real, not just popout stuff (although there are quite a few popouts), and it is one of the gorriest games I have ever seen! Even for being about eight years old the graphics are astounding. Like I said, the story is really good, it keeps you going in a great way, something that not a lot of games do. The voice acting is on point, from the chracters you meet, to the audio logs you find in lockers.  If you ever get stuck somewhere you just hold down B and a blue line shows you where to go, and you can check Isaac's commentary/journal if you are still lost. The entire game is in third person, which I did enjoy. This game is so fun, this is something that all gamers should experience.  If I were to rate it, I would totally give it a 10 out of 10, this game is a masterpiece and deserves every bit of the praise and populartiy it gets. If you have the money, buy it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I passed on buying this game when it first came out because it looked a bit odd. It wound up in my library through a HumbleBundle, and I decided to give it a play. I instantly regretted passing over this game all those years ago. The gameplay is great. Getting used to the control scheme and view point is not automatic, but it quickly becomes second nature. Characters are well thought out, and are developed excellently. Im a big sucker for a good story in video games, and Dead Space absolutely delivers. The story is fleshed out, and develops nicely as the game progresses. The atmosphere is excelent. I cannot stress this enough, the game keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The environment is littered with potential threats, keeping you constantly scanning. The designers didnt stop there though. They paired this trecherous environment with a "weapon" collection that some how just never has enough ammo, and a character that just cant ever get his hit points back up to full. Exhaustive scavenging and ammo conservation are essential to success, but then that just loops back to an environment that is trying to kill you 100% of the time. All in all, the game is absolutely amazing, I couldnt get enough of it, and if you dont buy it now, you will forever regret it.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I would love to say that this game has all you want from a space-bound horror story. That at times it reminded me of System Shock 2. That I would never be able to dream of space without dreaming of this game, but...And this for me is a major but,... but this game is unplayable for Logitech peripheral users, this includes myself (I own a nice shiny G13 gaming keyboard and a H360 headset ). My 1.5 hours in-game were mostly spent watching the intro cutscene (please, no more, I don't need to hear how Issac's ex needs to speak to him, I've heard it too many times now), whilst waiting to see if my changes have stopped the camera panning to the top left, spinning me around and around and around. The final nail is that the game was developed and published by EA, so once you've paid for your shiny game, forget about any support other than transferring your Steam version to Origin for every problem (seriously, I did try asking for help, hoping EA would have improved since being named the worst American company - Consumerist Magazine, but this was their only suggestion each time).Basically, if you own Logitech peripherals or expect support from the developer, don't buy this game.Okay, that's my rant over this game done, thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												I love Dead Space 1 and 2. I first played them on xbox and saw them on sale on steam one day and said "Hey, why not?" Well, as for Dead Space 1, this is a bad port. The controls feel really bad on this verison. The camera is floaty and hard to keep steady, and that is on both keyboard and mouse setup as well as a controller setup. Aiming felt really stiff and awkward. Even the visuals seem a bit of a downgrade from the xbox version. I just want to say quickly that Dead Space 2 plays quite well on both keyboard/mouse and controller setups, and also looks better then the console versions. I could barely get that far in the game because of how poorly this version controlled. It's a great game, but it just does not play nearly as well as the xbox verison.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												The sound design and weapon design are both top notch but every other part of the game is mediocre to downright bad. The games few high points come in a few clever environmental puzzles and a few fights where you have room to maneuver and aim. Unfortunately, there's a lot of just boring traversal and extremely cramped fights where you just dump ammo to avoid getting stun locked and killed. The story is very poorly written and told, it tries to be immersive but there's just no depth to it and the game tries to pull multiple twists that don't even make sense or carry any weight. The final boss fight might be the most frustrating part of the game as there's a lengthy unskippable cutscene at the start AND an even longer unskippable cutscene if you die. Add to all that, you need to tweak the game to even use the mouse like a mouse and no FoV and the game is exceedingly awkward at times. I played with a controller and the sensitivty was either too high for precision or too low to move and turn efficiently. I didn't feel the game was more suspenseful due to the controls, it just felt poorly made. This was especially prevalent in bossfights and certain sequences when you were grabbed and had to free aim while being jerk around. I died a number of times because both your firing point AND the spot you're shooting are snapping around with no fluidity at all. Certain enemies have animations where they're invincible and you have to wait for them to snap to another animation for them to be vulnerable again which looks awful and is tedious. The only way I would recommend this game is if you absolutely love suspense/horror as everything else it tries to do is done better somewhere else.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Don't get me wrong. This is a decent game, but I find the PC port nearly unplayable. I hope the console versions are better, because it's really worth giving this game a try.The terribly buggy port bothered me a lot during my playthrough, as I found the setting and story interesting overall. I sensed some influence from System Shock, and I was glad to see exploring was rewarded with background information through audio and text logs. However, it was hard to get immersed due to the absurd amount of bugs when playing the game at 60 fps. Sometimes enemies wouldn't spawn (and thereby have you stuck at some levels), or objects such as body bags would start spazzing out, killing an unfortunate character in their way.I eventually attemted playing the game locked at 30 fps, and suddenly the bugs dissappeared. However, it made combat much more "choppy" (probably due to the limited fps). For some reason aiming was also a lot slower/worse. Needless to say, playing the game at 30 fps didn't really help make the game feel better. It still felt like an unfinished port.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2011
												This is a prime example of what happens when developers stop developing for PC and make games targeted for consoles only.  It is a game that wants to be System Shock.  It is filled with all the obligatory suvival horror tropes even down to monsters coming out of walls, harsh shadows, monsters playing dead, and the requisite jump scenes.  What it fails to deliver is gameplay that is actually any fun.  It starts well, and brings in neat features like zero-gravity, time-dilation, and telekinesis.  However, In short order managing those features, and their related resource constraints, becomes just another chore.  All this is even get past the absolute worst part of this game: the nonresponsive controls that just scream "Nerfed for Console Use".  I wouldn't spend more than $15 for this one.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2011
												Do NOT buy unless you are really really willing to fight the controls. It's a diabolically bad console port that just fails at understanding a mouse. (Even without vsync)The game itself isn't that bad, got all the right aspects of a horror game, just not compiled correctly. The result is a pretty average FPS with about 0 scare value beyond the first 10 minutes. It seems like all the effort went into the intro.Most of the levels suffer millions of go-grabsomething-comeback syndrome, even when you ignore that every level starts and ends on the same tram system used to get around the ship. Also suffers major voice-in-ear syndrome. The lack of variation makes it a very tedious slog to finish.Only buy Dead Space if you're prepared to destroy your wrist and if it's at a rediculous steam sale price.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Disappointingly un-terrifying. After the first couple of fights with a necromorph they stop being scary. Sure there are plenty of jump-scares, but due to the terrible pacing you get desensitized to them pretty quickly. Full of plot-holes, bad characterization, completely unoriginal story…Honestly the best thing about this game was the sound design. The atmospheric bangs and clangs of necromorphs running through vents above you, roaring in the distance, orchestral stings and satisfying gun sounds add a lot to what is otherwise a very bland gaming experience. Unfortunately a lot of the sounds seem to be in low bitrate, which is a shame.It’s also a lot of fun to dismember necromorphs with the plasma cutter. If it wasn’t for the terrible mouse controls I’d be hard pressed not to recommend this game just for that.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2012
												The number of inventory slots you have isn't enough to carry sufficient ammo from one Store to the next. I was running out of my bullet-based guns every time.Also, it seems like they had a real-time inventory just because they could. They don't even let you sprint when using it, so the only time you can use an invntory item is when there aren't enemies around. This means no stasis recharge and no oxygen recharge when you really need it. More realistic you say? It's the lack of realism that makes games fun. Get slashed once and die like you would in real life, then see if you like realism.Almost didn't complete this because the Store is real-time as well, so I couldn't resupply when there were enemies around. Just had to run for it. it means I couldn't complete the last part of the game which required guns, and I had to download an invincibility hack.Well worth its £3.00  =]

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												1st thing is first: DEAD SPACE IS NOT SCARY!!This has absolutly NOTHING frightening in it, there is no TRUE horror & irrational thinking brought on by the unknown;there are just Jumpshocks after jumpshock after jumpshock after jumpshock after JUMPSHOCKS!!(It's ripping off D00M 3, except your not scared when the monster jump out at you, you're SHOCKed)HOWEVER....Just because this "survival horror" game is not scary DOES NOT mean it is a bad game.In fact, it's quite a cool game, with some new mechanics.Like how there is no HUD for the game: everything is shown on Issac's RIG suit, & the occasional screen displayed around his armour.And how the Fact that there is only one WEAPON (Security Pulse Rifle (Aliens rip-off) & all the other weapons are engineering tools.And I DO have to mention the creative ways to kill enemies: The Necromorphs (Aliens ripp-off again) can't be killed by conventional headshots: you have to use your mining tools to cut off their limbs as they do the most damage & inhibit their attacks/movment, which IS admittedly creative. Although, I don't think they're doing anything creative with some enemies having the obvious Lost Planet "Shoot the glowing orange point for more damage" parts on monstersAnd the story IS kind of bogus: It isn't THAT original, & all the stuff you think is going to happen happens, they DID get the style (if it DOES exsist) right, as it's "Generic but everyboy copies it's generic"They DO have some good back story, although you'll need to play the 2nd, worser Dead Space 2 to see it done PROPERLYAlso, is it just me, or does the USG Ishimora (<-bad spelling) look like it was BUILT to look like it's an unpleasent place that has gone to hell even BEFORE the monsters arrive?Because if ALL the elevators were built out of cages & chains to begin with, then it's almost like they're EXPECTING to be attacked..........but that's just me nitpicking.At the end of the day, it is widely agreed that out of the Dead Space series, this one is the best.And I would recommend you get it, but at half-price.It's enjoyable.... but it's not "the master of sci-fi horror" that idiots might tell you it is.3/5

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2013
												Through out this I am going to make a lot of comparisons to Resident Evil Remake and Alien Isolation, because I want to show you that games made 6 years BEFORE this game and 6 years AFTER this game nailed an oppressive atmosphere with nowhere near the amount of jumpscares as this game. The Spencer Mansion in Resident Evil Remake certainly had scripted jumpscares, the dogs through the window the second time you went through, the zombies through the window, the hunters through the windows. LOADS of windows. But, it still would have a terrifying atmosphere even without those scares. Just the fact that it gave you about a magazine for every 3 zombies and that you could kill about 2 zombies with 1 magazine meant that you had to find your way around zombies, which meant dodging around them or taking a longer but safer route around the mansion. THAT is survival horror. But Dead Space, which clearly takes inspiration from Resident Evil Remake, (because what survival horror doesn't?) doesn't take things like the atmosphere. I mean sure, it has scary moments, even when enemies aren't there, but that's just because I'm afraid something will jump out and a loud musical sting will play. I'm not scared of the ship, or the monsters, I'm scared of the musicians slamming there hands down on the piano again. Alien Isolation, a game that came out in 2014, last year, go 'it'. How to do survival horror without unscripted jumpscares, and having an oppressive atmosphere. The bit when you walk through the synthetic bay, where all the dying 'Working Joe's' go to die. You walk through a corridor with about 10 'Working Joe's' standing idol, and you just know that if you turn your back they'll throttle you, but they don't until 10 minutes later when the game throws 8 shotgun shells, 3 flares, 2 medkits and 6 revolver bullets at you, but that's besides the point.I do not think that this is a bad game, I just don't think it's a good one either. It takes the claustrophobia and 'survival horror' from RE:R and A:I but they seem a lot clumsier here. Sure you may love this game, but I'll stick with the good stuff until EA get this right the fourth time round.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2012
												Plays out like Resident Evil 4 in space but with more focus on horror and less QTEs. Scarce ammo, fantastic atmosphere from the amazing sound design & environmental effects, and the isolation & vastness of space fuel this modern survival horror adventure. The most impressive immersion element for me was how they handled the "HUD"; instead of on-screen indicators, your health bar and energy are on your back with ammo on your gun. The only problems with it are port issues (you need to disable v-sync to use a mouse properly), the funneled levels, and a general lack of difficulty.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Right off the bat I can say this... taking Ridley Scott's Alien, Paul W.S. Anderson's Event Horizon and John Carpenter's The Thing....Slamming them together into one survival horror Sci-Fi game was BRILLIANT!!! Now I will admit that this game was a little bit lacking in subtle undertones in the horror department and was relying more on jump scares  but not all games can be like the early Silent Hill games. However all that is made up by the environment of USG Ishimure and how claustrophobic you feel in its lonely dark corridors. The combat focus of not relying on head shots but instead dismemberment was a very nice touch. This gear shift in tactics makes your choice of weapons to carry very important. In a game like Resident Evil 4 a fully automatic weapon aimed at the head of a zombie will have the same result as a magnum but in Dead Space your fully automatic Pulse Rifle is almost useless against a necromorph and you'll just end up waste ammo. Using "tools" were by far the best weapons in the whole game such as the Plasma Cutter or the Ripper which adds to the " your a engineer on a mining ship" motif.The story of Issac Clark does seem a bit dull at times but what more do you want from a guy that doesn't talk and only grunts while swinging his arms about or stomping his feet. Now the universe that the game takes place in is outstanding in my opinion since a lot of Sci-Fi aspect are very true. For instance the idea of "planet cracking" for resources isn't far from the truth. Some day in the future we will find ourselves mining the stars for ore and metals. These little things in the background of the plot makes the nerd in me giddy. The use of Anti-gravity tech and a "stasis module" brings another level of depth to the game play mechanics in the areas of puzzles and combat. By using the Stasis on rushing enemies you can slow them down for a brief moment to tear them apart with your weapon in hand, while the Anti-gravity will allow you to alter parts of the environment around to navigate through obstacles and ferry important items. Even after playing through the game years back I still do enjoy coming back to it ever now and then with a big smile on my face.  So if you like a gore filled Sci-Fi nightmare where you find yourself being spooked by the sounds of tapping on metal or pipes blowing off steam at just the right time where it makes you stain your desk chair with brown goo then pick up a copy of this game, Dim the lights, put on a beef pair of headphones and maybe scotchgard your chair in case you get a bit jumpy from things going BOO!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I would love to say that this game has all you want from a space-bound horror story. That at times it reminded me of System Shock 2. That I would never be able to dream of space without dreaming of this game, but...And this for me is a major but,... but this game is unplayable for Logitech peripheral users, this includes myself (I own a nice shiny G13 gaming keyboard and a H360 headset ). My 1.5 hours in-game were mostly spent watching the intro cutscene (please, no more, I don't need to hear how Issac's ex needs to speak to him, I've heard it too many times now), whilst waiting to see if my changes have stopped the camera panning to the top left, spinning me around and around and around. The final nail is that the game was developed and published by EA, so once you've paid for your shiny game, forget about any support other than transferring your Steam version to Origin for every problem (seriously, I did try asking for help, hoping EA would have improved since being named the worst American company - Consumerist Magazine, but this was their only suggestion each time).Basically, if you own Logitech peripherals or expect support from the developer, don't buy this game.Okay, that's my rant over this game done, thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												The sound design and weapon design are both top notch but every other part of the game is mediocre to downright bad. The games few high points come in a few clever environmental puzzles and a few fights where you have room to maneuver and aim. Unfortunately, there's a lot of just boring traversal and extremely cramped fights where you just dump ammo to avoid getting stun locked and killed. The story is very poorly written and told, it tries to be immersive but there's just no depth to it and the game tries to pull multiple twists that don't even make sense or carry any weight. The final boss fight might be the most frustrating part of the game as there's a lengthy unskippable cutscene at the start AND an even longer unskippable cutscene if you die. Add to all that, you need to tweak the game to even use the mouse like a mouse and no FoV and the game is exceedingly awkward at times. I played with a controller and the sensitivty was either too high for precision or too low to move and turn efficiently. I didn't feel the game was more suspenseful due to the controls, it just felt poorly made. This was especially prevalent in bossfights and certain sequences when you were grabbed and had to free aim while being jerk around. I died a number of times because both your firing point AND the spot you're shooting are snapping around with no fluidity at all. Certain enemies have animations where they're invincible and you have to wait for them to snap to another animation for them to be vulnerable again which looks awful and is tedious. The only way I would recommend this game is if you absolutely love suspense/horror as everything else it tries to do is done better somewhere else.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to be in a sci-fi space horror movie? If so, then Dead Space is for you.The best aspects of Dead Space are the sound, music, and overall solitary/frightening mood the game sets. There were several occasions where I found myself turning around because I heard something echoing in the distance… sounding as if it was coming closer. Even the zero gravity heavy steps you take sound fantastic with a hollowed, deep bass sound. When the environment is right and the audio is incredibly well done, you have a great setting for a game.The biggest downside of the game was the linear story line. You get a few options of which upgrades you would like to make to your gear but really, you will only want to use 1 maybe 2 guns as some are very weak and pretty much useless. The character development is bland as well. Do not play Dead Space looking for a great story because you will not find it.The gameplay may also feel stiff at first, even for a third person shooter but it kind of makes sense. You are in a heavy space suit, your mobility should be limited. To counter this, the gun controls are tight and precise. You can really feel the power of them (especially once upgraded).Even with the nearly non-existent story, the environment really immersed me. Play the game, take your time going through it; do not rush it. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Ever felt isolated to the point where insanity and reality merge into one horrifying and unforgiving world?  Dead Space is without doubt one of my favorite games of all time.  It caters to gamers who enjoy the survival horror genre while juxtaposing action and unrelenting gore simultaneously.  Throughout the game, you have numerous tasks which all cater to one overall objective towards the end: escaping the Ishimura mining space ship.  One critical element I enjoy about this game is how physical disgusting the creatures are, ranging from midly grotesque to absolutey aberrant.  Dismembering the creatures is fun especially if you decide to play it on hard difficulty settings.  The harder the difficulty, the more strategic the player has to be when it comes to utilizing health kits, ammunition rounds and even stasis energy packs.  If you want your palms to sweat while being sick to your stomach, then this game is the one for you.  I give this game a 9.8 out of 10 (A+)!Signing Out,ElPresador!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Buy, rent, try, or pass? I'd say this (given what's likely an aged price-tag) is a game to add to most collections. Buy.My one big con for DeadSpace: unresponsive controls.My list of pros: The cinematic quality of the portion I've played is astounding. Nearly unparalleled. I'm almost happy to give up some control responsiveness for how gorgeous and immersive this game is. You have to play it to understand. And if you're the least bit adventurous, in the middle of the night with some nice headphones, in the dark. The jumpscares are great! I think this game made my little brain go "DIE!DIE!DIE!KILLITWITHFIRE!!!" more than any other game before it. But lemme say something again, the movement and punch/kick controls are terrible. Like I said, I'm ALMOST happy to give up some control responsiveness, too much was taken away though. But if you sharpen your aim enough, and make those couple of hits you DO have time to get in count, well, you can learn to live with it. It's certainly one of the most sluggish I've ever played.The sound (even if at times predictably string-section-horror-y) and music fit the setting very well. And the visuals, I'm happy to say are impressive in many ways even today, in 2014. Something else worth mentioning is how expertly executed the TOTAL absence of user-interface was in DeadSpace. I absolutely LOVE that everything about the world you're in, must be accessed through the character you inhabit. He has various projectors built into his suit which project the prompts, information, and statistics you would expect to find up front and in your face with this type of game. But here, you see it as your character might, seemingly floating in the air beside your character. As you pan and position your camera angle, the world rotates in a detached way, giving you moments of surreal perspective on what you might look like from someone elses eyes in there, in that dark bloody mess of a futuristic room. The experience is certainly not one I think any mature gamers should miss. This would've INSTANTLY cursed me with nightmares for a month when I was younger.As for the story, replayability, and evolution of the game. I actually haven't played through the entire thing and don't want to misjudge it based only on what I've seen so far between PC and console version. But either way, it has been very good over all and a game I definitely recommend picking up.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												The transition of survival horror took the meaning of horror in a different direction, wIth Resident Evil 4, we moved from the overall feeling of dread and suspense in the previous titles, to a more generic jump-scare type of horror (with maybe its exception of regenerators). Resident evil 4 was by no means a horror masterpiece, but it was campy and fun, and its gameplay was fantastically implemented, with set pieces oozing from it's pores to thrill the player.Dead space tried (and failed) in my opinion to bring back any of that tension. Instead we have a linear set of sequences filled with scripted jump scares from monsters overdesigned to look horrific.There's only a few times of note worthy moments in this game. One in particular was when you enter a room full of dead bodies, and later the game loops around to this room, except now it is populated with a monster which can make monsters from corpses. I had never encountered this monster before I found this room the first time. I instinctively dismembered all of the corpses, and when I came back around it paid off, instead of a dozen monsters I only had to deal with one. That was a moment of rewarding the player for actually playing the game in a way a video game should be played, trusting the player to emergent decisions as opposed to leading them down set routes with set expectations of play. It did that moment once.So much potential wasted as well. It would have been a lot better if it was more open, Metroidvania. It had the capacity to do that since we have the floor system. And the scripted jump scares could have been randomised or intellegently coded AI which could determine a best attack when the player is at their weakest.In short, this series is overhyped garbage.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I passed on buying this game when it first came out because it looked a bit odd. It wound up in my library through a HumbleBundle, and I decided to give it a play. I instantly regretted passing over this game all those years ago. The gameplay is great. Getting used to the control scheme and view point is not automatic, but it quickly becomes second nature. Characters are well thought out, and are developed excellently. Im a big sucker for a good story in video games, and Dead Space absolutely delivers. The story is fleshed out, and develops nicely as the game progresses. The atmosphere is excelent. I cannot stress this enough, the game keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The environment is littered with potential threats, keeping you constantly scanning. The designers didnt stop there though. They paired this trecherous environment with a "weapon" collection that some how just never has enough ammo, and a character that just cant ever get his hit points back up to full. Exhaustive scavenging and ammo conservation are essential to success, but then that just loops back to an environment that is trying to kill you 100% of the time. All in all, the game is absolutely amazing, I couldnt get enough of it, and if you dont buy it now, you will forever regret it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												The second I started playing this game, I knew that it was special. This game perfectly blends quick responce and beutifuly smooth combat with a suspensful, scarry and well designed atmosphere. The enemys in this game are downright terrifying, and the story is awesome. The game has a linier campain, but is packed full of Bioshock-like RPG elements. The scarres in this game are real, not just popout stuff (although there are quite a few popouts), and it is one of the gorriest games I have ever seen! Even for being about eight years old the graphics are astounding. Like I said, the story is really good, it keeps you going in a great way, something that not a lot of games do. The voice acting is on point, from the chracters you meet, to the audio logs you find in lockers.  If you ever get stuck somewhere you just hold down B and a blue line shows you where to go, and you can check Isaac's commentary/journal if you are still lost. The entire game is in third person, which I did enjoy. This game is so fun, this is something that all gamers should experience.  If I were to rate it, I would totally give it a 10 out of 10, this game is a masterpiece and deserves every bit of the praise and populartiy it gets. If you have the money, buy it.

												Well... was it worth $5? Yes. But not more than that. Sure the violence is over the top, the weapons are unique, and there are a few legitimate scares. content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Worth buying at at least 66% off via my "Never buy games at full price" motto and "Percentage-to-hours" hypothesis (accounting hours played and enjoyment in regards to the absolute lowest percentage that I would consider buying it at if I suddenly lost the game and had to rebuy it). Pros:The story is incredible: the main protagonist doesn't speak or react to events, so it honestly feels like you're in the seat, which is perfect for a horror/survival shooter like this. The NPCs are vital to the story (there's 4 major ones, and a fifth person who appears every now and then and is a key part in the backstory) and feel realistic, and they add to the game experience unlike many games out there these days. The game's mechanics are timeless and the graphics are splendid, even if the game is generally dark. I felt emotionally attached to this game (more than any other, at least) because of how well the developers created the events in the story; stuff felt like it was happening to me, and that's the sign of a well made game. Save points are everywhere, checkpoints are well placed before major events, stores are crucial to the development of the character, and benches are your best friend who only turns up once a month (or in this case, chapter) but are a blast to hang out with (you upgrade you gear here with power nodes). This game was clearly designed with a lot of thought.Cons:The lack of gamepad mapping was kind of annoying at first, but the controls are still good. Sensitivity is downright poor sometimes, especially with the mouse. The bosses were not hard: the one in the middle or just past the middle was harder than the last one, and took way longer. Ammunition is very important in this game, which made it super annoying that enemies that dropped ammo before would often not the later on in the game it got. The story towards the end felt a little forced, but if it was planned with Dead Space 2 in mind, then it's fine, but it just felt like it happened because they did not want **START OF SPOILER** an unhappy ending **END OF SPOILER**. however this does not affect how I feel about the game. The game had some annoying glitches in it, like getting stuck in places in zero gravity and not being able to get out, and also falling through lifts into space and dying if you were not properly on the lift when you activated it. The machine gun-type weapon you use two times to clear asteroids had bad controlling, but it wasn't hard to beat that bit anyway. There's not much in terms of weapon variation, and you can very easily beat the game by just using a Plasma Cutter, maxing it out with the power nodes in the bench, maxing out your RIG the same way, and buying plasma energy all game.Overall, I give this game a rating of 9/10. You could tell that this game's multiplayer could be incredible if done right, but unfortunately it doesn't come until Dead Space 3 (EDIT: Dead Space 2 has a nice 8 player, 4v4 mode that's actually not too bad). The game's single player is a top 5 best campaign in shooter gaming history, with Call of Duty: Modern Warfare, Halo, Half-Life and maybe Half-Life 2. The controls on the PC port are pretty unresponsive with the mouse, but with the controller it's basically solved, though there seems to be no remapping, which is off putting to some. Because of this, I got the full experience of this game (dark setting, headset on, XBOX 360 controller) and enjoyed it immensely. Handy tip: when you reach the Target Practice minigame, I have a feeling that if you play it enough, you will not have a credits problem/deficiency for the rest of the game. So when you reach it, play it a lot and you will have all the money you need.

												Don't play this game with a full bladder...trust me. So believe it or not, but I've played all the Dead Space games...besides the first one (yes...even the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Wii game) and I always saw people saying, "The first one is the scariest." so I was like, "Okay I got Dead Space 1 during a humble bundle sale 2 years ago, let's try this out." Oh boy...it's scarier than I thought.The thing about this game is that the atmosphere is so dark and so creepy with the appearance, the background sound, and that fact that it's just you, alone, with these Necro's on this gigantic space ship that it literally gets to you. It gets to you so bad that when a necro pops up you can't help but spaz a bit and pause the game.This is without a doubt a great horror game, plus it's a ton of fun.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Right off the bat I can say this... taking Ridley Scott's Alien, Paul W.S. Anderson's Event Horizon and John Carpenter's The Thing....Slamming them together into one survival horror Sci-Fi game was BRILLIANT!!! Now I will admit that this game was a little bit lacking in subtle undertones in the horror department and was relying more on jump scares  but not all games can be like the early Silent Hill games. However all that is made up by the environment of USG Ishimure and how claustrophobic you feel in its lonely dark corridors. The combat focus of not relying on head shots but instead dismemberment was a very nice touch. This gear shift in tactics makes your choice of weapons to carry very important. In a game like Resident Evil 4 a fully automatic weapon aimed at the head of a zombie will have the same result as a magnum but in Dead Space your fully automatic Pulse Rifle is almost useless against a necromorph and you'll just end up waste ammo. Using "tools" were by far the best weapons in the whole game such as the Plasma Cutter or the Ripper which adds to the " your a engineer on a mining ship" motif.The story of Issac Clark does seem a bit dull at times but what more do you want from a guy that doesn't talk and only grunts while swinging his arms about or stomping his feet. Now the universe that the game takes place in is outstanding in my opinion since a lot of Sci-Fi aspect are very true. For instance the idea of "planet cracking" for resources isn't far from the truth. Some day in the future we will find ourselves mining the stars for ore and metals. These little things in the background of the plot makes the nerd in me giddy. The use of Anti-gravity tech and a "stasis module" brings another level of depth to the game play mechanics in the areas of puzzles and combat. By using the Stasis on rushing enemies you can slow them down for a brief moment to tear them apart with your weapon in hand, while the Anti-gravity will allow you to alter parts of the environment around to navigate through obstacles and ferry important items. Even after playing through the game years back I still do enjoy coming back to it ever now and then with a big smile on my face.  So if you like a gore filled Sci-Fi nightmare where you find yourself being spooked by the sounds of tapping on metal or pipes blowing off steam at just the right time where it makes you stain your desk chair with brown goo then pick up a copy of this game, Dim the lights, put on a beef pair of headphones and maybe scotchgard your chair in case you get a bit jumpy from things going BOO!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Players step into the boots of Isaac Clarke, a systems engineer that's part of the dispatched maintenance crew. Outside of fixing the communications issues, Isaac has a number of reasons for arriving on the Ishimura -- he has a number of friends that are stationed on the ship, including someone very special to him that sends an urgent holovid with a few cryptic messages before she disappears. Unfortunately for Isaac and his crew, shortly after they arrive on board the crippled vessel, all hell breaks loose. Their craft is destroyed, leaving them stranded on the Ishimura. The crew is attacked by nightmarish creatures known as Necromorphs, who kill most of Isaac's team and separate him from the surviving members. Even worse, the ship and its systems have started to be corrupted or are failing thanks to the Necromorphic infestation. It's up to Isaac to wander the halls, search for any friends or survivors that are still alive, and fix as many problems as he can until he can find a way to escape the ship, which can take you 12 or more hours to complete. - Jeff Haynes (ign.com) -

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												To be short , its a great game if you like space horror.The graphics are awesome the lighting effects are stunning. It has plenty of weapons you can buy or upgrade which is very nice. Upgrades are also applied to armor.1 tip im giving is a little tweak because of the horrid mouse controls ( lag , dead points , low sensitivity ) if you encounter these go to your APP DATA folder C:\Users\USER\AppData\Local\Electronic Arts\Dead Space and open the settings.txt in the bottom line just paste the following :Control.AimAssistEnabled = falseControl.AimingPosition = 0Control.ControllerSensitivity = 2Control.DeadZone = 0Control.FireButtonControls = trueControl.InvertX = falseControl.InvertY = falseControl.MouseAcceleration = 0Control.MouseSensitivity = 2.00000000Control.Shock = trueControls.AcL.X = 0x1104007EControls.AcL.Y = 0x00030008Disable Vsync from nvidia control panel or something else and you're done.The game is straight forward and the story just adds to the atmosphere. With 2.5 hours played i give it a 8/10 i might think higher of it though as i progress.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Below was the first part of my review.  I have since managed to make it into the game.  And while it is still nothing compared to part 2, It is at least worth playing so you can get a little more of the story.  However this one won't be played a second time.   On a lighter note though.  The Leviathan was done very well.Picked up the game because somebody mentioned it was the Alien game we've been waiting for.  If only that were true. Within the first 2 hours of play I was so unimpressed I doubt I will finish the game.  First off I don't know why they made it so you looked like a hunched over monkey when walking.  Second the creatures were not impressive and the weapons were even more lame.  I think I would give the flamethrower the award for most useless weapon of all time in any video game created.   The fights were predictible with little surprise.  Walk 10 feet have something drop down in front of you, shoot the leg and arm and it dies.  Rinse. Repeat.  Another thing,  I don't  understand why people think that just because you paint all the walls with blood it makes the game spooky.  It is very cliche' and not very imaginative.   So I guess what I'm saying is I would not recommend this to anybody unless they were utterly bored and this were free.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												3/10, the single most terrible game I've encountered in half decadeTerrible PC port  before loading/starting an actual game, the frame rate on menu is excruciatingly low, and cursor suffers heavy lag. During the game, cursor suffers deadzone and low sensitivity which was made worse by little to no cursor acceleration. Although the issues above are fixable if you are willing to go through series of complex lengthy guides. Still, after manual fix the cursor will ended up 4times more sensitive while running than standing still looking around.Insensitive/irresponsive movements  Character only has 4 directions of movement thus never moves diagonally, he stops & stand still for a brief second when changing from W to D, not to mention that was after you’ve press the key a split second ago.General game design failure  character was “by design” placed to the left corner, blind to attack comes from left, and walks in an unacceptable angle heavy skewed to the right, by the time you get used to it I will point and laugh at you while playing a game superior in every possible way, because anything is the game of the year comparing something like this that dare to muster up the courage and call itself a game. 


YOU ONLY HAVE ONE JOB!! ONE ♥♥♥♥ING JOB!!!!...and this is with widescreen fixer, without it you shall know why it calls itself a horror game

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												When I was a younger and more ignorant person, I looked on the advertisements for Dead Space with holy disdain, distancing myself far away from the gory, horror-filled secular content that I was not accustomed to.My, my. How the times have changed for me.Dead Space is a game in which you play as Isaac Clarke: an engineer who was assigned with a small crew to investigate the mysterious mining freight, the USG Ishimura. While onboard, they discover the disturbing necromorph creatures have made a new home amidst the dead bodies and decrepit machinery and have also graciously trapped you onboard to endure with their delightful company.Let me say, the manners of these creatures are atrocious. They don't invite you tea (they don't even have a daily tea), they don't acknowledge you verbally, and most of all they get incredibly intimate with you far too soon to begin any intimate relations in the first place. My stay with them at the Ishimura was atrocious. I'm definitely not going back anytime soon.All bad jokes aside, Dead Space is a damn good looking game. The presentation through the graphical and sound design is fantastic, especially on PC. The ship feels dead, alone, but at the same time writhing with disgusting alien growth always off somewhere in the distance. If it were for the atmosphere and presentation alone, I'd be giving this game a high recommendation.But, alas, far more problems hinder Dead Space from being a fantastic horror experience. For one, the writing's pretty stale. It's not bad. But not really that good either. The majority of the speaking characters are all pretty one-dimensional and not that interesting to talk to. And the story tries to tie such emotional weight for Isaac and his wife, Nicole, but it just isn't there. The main reason behind this failure to feel any emotion with Isaac is that he's a silent protagonist."But, Double Uppercut, that's a strange criticism for you to make! You like Half-Life and Portal, don't you? They have silent protagonists and they're the best games ever. Why are you hating on Dead Space for having the same thing they have?"Well, you can enjoy cheese but it doens't go good on everything, does it? I dare you to smother some melted cheese all over some ice cream and tell me it's delicious.See, a silent protagonist is supposed to be used purely for player-immersion. If you want to create a character the player can empathize with, they have to speak. I relate to the struggles of Kratos (only in the first God of War) and Joel from the Last of Us, because they're given enough time to have their characters fleshed-out and distinct enough for you to learn who they reall are, as well as care for them. Do I think Gordon Freeman, Chell, or Link are fantastically-written characters? Of course not! They're merely vehicles for the player to immerse themselves in the larger game world. They don't have backstories, and if they do you personally experience it because they ARE you. Isaac feels like a player-driven vehicle, but whenever his wife is thrown into the picture or the question of his insanity is brought up, I feel nothing. I don't know who Isaac is, and I honestly don't care.The gameplay, while pretty fun, is a little clunky too. I'm not a huge fan of how Isaac controls. He tends to walk around a little too awkwardly and the looking around with the mouse is a little too slow. Even when the sensitivity was bumped up, Isaac just wouldn't look around right. On top of that, the game has a weird upgrade-system bolted on that seems to cater more towards an action-focused style of gameplay rather than a horror-focused gameplay. Silent Hill gave you weapons but you didn't have to worry about upgrading them or upgrading your health. It was purely focused on you surviving. While playing Dead Space, I was always thinking about saving money or extra supplies to buy stuff and make Isaac more powerful, which doesn't feed well into that isolated-horror game vibe. It's more of a mechanic for action-focused shooters and fighting games. By the end, I didn't have my metaphorical pants scared off, I felt like a bada**.That's f***ing terrible. EA, you should be ashamed of yourselves.That's just the problem that lies at the heart of Dead Space. It's not that scary. Sure, the monsters are pretty freaky and jump out at inopportune times, but they don't have a lot of presence- ESPECIALLY towards the end of the game when you mow through hordes of necromorphs by the dozens. It's not like Silent Hill where each fight with one of the monsters you'd encounter felt as intimidating as the last, because you never upgraded your character. You always had the same gear and the same health bar. Maybe the designers of Dead Space should have focused on limiting your supplies and making the creatures much tougher to reinforce that horror vibe.And maybe I should stop talking about how much I love Silent Hill during every god**** horror review I write.For what it's worth, Dead Space is a fine game. I think it's pros outweight its cons. The visuals and atmosphere and inventive anti-gravity and space segments really make up for what is otherwise another bland science-fiction horror story. It feels like so many ideas were taken from other horror stories like Alien, The Thing, and even The Shining to some extent. It just doesn't have much to it to really stick with you after you've finished the game. If EA really fleshed out the game by making it more of a horror game than an action game with little horror elements thrown in, this could've been a lot better. But I'm sure people can find some enjoyment in what terror this game provides. However, I think you could play Close Your Eyes for free and it's a much better horror experience than Dead Space. I'm giving it a 5/10. It's a pretty solid game without any defining features to make it fantastically memorable- either as terrible or wonderful. If it intrigues you, go buy it. But if you're looking for something truly frightening, I'd recommend you try out something else.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												TL,DR: The port is awful. If you really need to play this game, do it on console. The game is just worse than RE:4, which also has a better PC port (They’ve updated it).First, I’ll talk about the port, then I’ll talk about the game.The port is awful. With vsync on, the input delay is hilariously bad. With vsync off, the game is extremely unstable. Critical characters will fall through the ground, and you’ll have to reload over and over until you get lucky. Sometimes, especially in the zero G sections, the game gets confused about where you should be, or how you should be standing, and then just gives you and kills you. I’ll falling through the ground multiple times, and there was one section near the end of the game the froze over and over. The mouse support is terrible. The acceleration feels very odd, and even at max sensitivity, I needed to pick up the mouse and swipe several times just to turn 180. I don’t think there have been any graphical improvements over the console version, so you might as well just play that version.The game isn’t great. If you need to scratch that 3rd person “horror” shooter itch, just play RE:4 again. Yeah, the controls are kinda odd, but the mouse actually works properly. Once you get used to the RE:4 controls, they feel much smoother and more responsive than Dead Space’s. Prepare for more unfavorable RE:4 comparisons by the way. The gameplay in RE:4 rarely stops. Yes, there are traditional cutscenes, but they aren’t too frequent. Dead Space doesn’t have traditional cutscenes, but you do get talked at by “support” characters almost constantly, and when you’re being talked at, you can’t run, or open doors, or use save stations. I feel that the game will drop inputs fairly regularly, and movement is annoyingly slow. Dead Space introduces a mechanic in which you can dismember various enemies, but there’s always one correct choice per enemy. For example, a standard zombie is running towards you, cut off the legs, then cut off the arms. It gets quite repetitive. In RE:4, there are time when you might want to go for headshots, or legs shots.Dead Space tries be scary at all times, and I suppose it has a more consistent tone, but I was actually scared less often in this game. It can get scary at a couple moments, in fact, precisely two moments in my opinion, largely owing to the sound design, which is usually good. Most of the enemy design is just a worse version of The Thing (John Carpenter, no one cares about the 50’s version). It’s actually quite odd how inconsistent the quality of the scares are. Sometimes, you hear a terrible sound of anguish, and an odd, strained breath, followed by a vision of a shadow of a strange, once human creature slowly walking around a corner, backlit by a cold, fluorescent light. At other times, you’re locked in some airport terminal waiting room until you kill X number of lame zombie men. There’s an enemy that can regenerate, and you can never kill it, but there very first time it’s introduced, you’re locked in a small room with it, and can get used to how amazingly slow it is. They try to hype up the same monster later on, but you already know just how small of a threat it poses.The world of the game feels like it was design to be open from the beginning, but then some cooperate suit decided that that might confuse people, so they made it linear. Not only is it linear, you have a magic line on the ground that makes sure you never get lost, because it’s not like being lost can be an effective aspect of fear. RE:4 is linear as well, but it feels like it was designed to be linear from the beginning, and it just seems to flow better.Most survival horror games build tension by limiting your ammo and health supplies, but Dead Space doesn’t do that. Instead, your inventory is always full, and you will often need to backtrack to the nearest store to empty it out. You get upgrade materials to improve your armor and weapons, but you get so much cash from selling all that health and ammo you aren’t using that you’ll have everything leveled all the way up by the end. RE:4 gave you too much ammo as well, but cash was limited, and you needed to save up for the guns and upgrade you actually wanted.The story is pretty straight forward, and none of the characters are interesting. RE:4 has a basic story as well, but all the characters are so strong, and the entire narrative is delivered with such camp, that it’s always entertaining. Dead Space treats its story much more seriously, which was a bad idea, because the story is lame and predictable.Story spoilers:  She was dead the whole time.  It was so obvious that I didn’t even realize it was supposed to be a mystery, but they treat the revelation as a grand, Earth shacking reveal. This review is obviously very negative, but the game is more disappointing than really bad. It isn’t as good as RE:4, but the zero G areas are fun (if glitchy). Cutting off limbs is fun at first, and deciding what to upgrade first can be interesting. The scenery changes often enough to stay interesting, even if most of it really doesn’t make sense to be on a space ship.  A couple of the monster designs are quite good. But overall, I would tell you to skip this game unless you are massively into action horror, and have already played RE:4, and F.E.A.R. (the first two), and Condemned (the first one), and Fatal Frame (the first two), and Metro 2033, and a few others that I’m sure I’m, forgetting.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												Dead Space is a great example of a game that puts you on egde. It never truly scares you, but it certainly makes you raise your guard constantly knowing that despite your best paranoid efforts, a necromorph will still startle the crap out of you from behind. Being locked in a room with twenty enemies and low ammo certainly puts you through a major stress test.When it comes down to it, I personally believe Dead Space 1 was the pinacle of Dead Space gameplay. Isaac didn't say anything, and the environment fit perfectly in place with what it was supposed to be: An abanadoned, infested space station. Your two allies only called every now and then, so as to not oversaturate the game with dialogue and let you focus on absorbing the atmosphere and enjoying the awesome limb-splattering combat system.The combat system is nearly sheer perfection in terms of feeling. Every shot from most weapons can seriously pack a punch when upgraded, and there is nothing more satisfying than shooting somebody so hard all their limbs fly off or their head explodes. Every enemy was satisfying and fun to fight, with the exception of the f*cking Guardians, which felt like a cheap gimmick at first and always turned into a chore.The story is pretty weak at best. It all comes down to Isaac basically repairing the entire space station then attempting to retrieve "The Marker", which he fails at as well. Thankfully, once I really started playing I didn't even care it had a bad story anymore. The gameplay was addictive and multipaced: going from slow to incredibly fastpaced in mere seconds. This more than made up for a horrible story.At the end of the day, the story sucked, but the game was hella fun to play. It's even one of the few games I have fully replayed just for the gameplay, so that should mean something at least. Doom didn't need a good story to be an awesome time blowing off demon and alien limbs, why should Dead Space need a good story too?

number of helpful: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I have to say, I am becoming increasingly disappointed with big gaming website critics. They have let me down far too often. This game's praises were sung across all major gaming sites, and yet it's just not that good. Is it beautiful to look at? Sure, but that's about all it has going for it. This game was scary for about the first hour, but after I accumulated a few strong weapons and the "jump scares" started becoming repetitive, I was no longer surprised by anything. So maybe the story is where this game shines? Sorry, no. I get the sense that this game's story was trying to be Aliens, but after a couple hours of play, I rarely cared what my next objective was since they were all such mundane meaningless tasks anyway (such as going around an obstruction, or restoring power to some section, etc).Finally there's the combat. While I thoroughly enjoyed the look and feel of the weapons, this game gets sci-fi technology right, the actual combat was mediocre and repetitive. The dismemberment mechanic was a nice touch, but not enough to keep me engaged. So while the major gaming websites gave this game an 8-9/10, I would give it a 6/10.I bought this game on sale along with the second one, so hopefully the sequel will be better.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I enjoyed many of the sci-fi elements of Dead Space. Zipping around in zero gravity and performing repairs on an enormous mining ship were quite fun.That said, I found it impossible to take this game seriously. Its world has no internal logic that I could find. The number of times something happens solely BECAUSE SCARY are too many to count. After the third time I found a can of flamer ammo in a wall box conspicuously labeled "EMERGENCY SUPPLIES", it became clear that this was a very traditional survival horror game with a sci-fi coat of paint. Horror games absolutely rely upon your immersion in the gameworld, so constantly breaking my suspension of disbelief by putting momentary thrills ahead of the world-building was a dealbreaker.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												I wanted to like this game, I really did. At first look it of course reminded me of Doom 3 which i loved. But 5 hours playtime later and i hung it up and never going to pick it up again. The control scheme is the most bass ackward thing ive ever seen for any shooter. It feels like Isaac Clarke is actually a brick that somehow walks around on legs. The mouse lag is horrible and you cant see half the screen because of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ decision to make this an over the shoulder game. Get stuck in a corner after running from something chasing you? Then good luck trying to aim at anything, its just going to zoom in on the back of your head.But hey if you like jumpscares then this game is for you because every enemy is a jumpscare. Necromorphs from the ceiling, necromorphs from the floor, necromorphs from windows. They were scary cause i wasnt expecting it then they just became a nuisance. It makes you want to slow down to a crawl every time you enter a new room just so they cant get the jump on you. Lets leave the lame jumpscares for the devolpers that cant afford to program everything else that makes a good horror game.Edit: dont let the 120 hours fool you, simply left my computer running for a few days

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Tedious, relatively boring, pestering, unncessary padding, annoying.edit: (I beat this game with 11 hours in-game time, it wasn't logged because I played it offline. I played the game on medium/normal difficulty.)After hearing so much praise for this game, i'm rather surprised it was incredibly lackluster experience for me. I don't think it's because of having good expectations going in and them not living up to them. It was actually just not that good of a game to me.Dead Space is a game with very cliche story-telling and boring, uninteresting characters who have rather immature fights with each other, and you pretty much just have you shoulder the responsibilites of... everything really. They ask you to do just about everything and spit really menial boring "story dialouge" at you that I found myself almost passively ignoring because it was just so bland and uninsprired and typical/predictable. Even then, there was hardly a story to really follow, in the sense of, it was really laid out for you. Incredibly simple.There's a church, they have the ishimura on a illegal planet cracking trip to uncover the marker. Then psychotic "the church" people believe the coming of gods new children are here (the necromorphs) and it's time for humanity to die out and be replaced by the necromorphs which are 'better' than humans. It's just so simple and boring and like, it really only took a couple of logs you pick up in the game mid-to-late game to really just lay out the entire story for you in a nutshell. Everything else is focused on 'survival'. Which is really just an extremely unncessary amount of fetch quests, because apparently, for the most part, not a damn thing in the ship almost the entire game takes place works. Every single new chapter is really just these really baseboards characters whining and crying about how nothing works and nothing is simple and how spooked and scared of the necromorphs they are and how they think (x) is dead.I ended up just getting infuriated and annoyed by the story design of essentially doing nothing but fetch quests with no new interesting developments or changes to the story. Like yeah they added new characters, but it was just a guy who was like "The marker is bad, lets' destroy it or give it back." and then the crazy church guy who was like "Humans are weak, necromorphs are gods new children, let them take over."Woah, totally interesting not cliche boring characters.Then we get to the gameplay. It was easy, very easy. Too much money floating around, the beginning guns are really good (except the assault rifle) and there's no need to change them. There's no tension or fear I felt fighting the enemies. The atmosphere was boring because you quickly just got used to gore and blood be splattered everywhere and seeing nothing but metal walls, the entire atmosphere just got incredibly tasteless and bland. Rarely did a set do anything to set itself apart from other rooms, and I don't count things like the hospital either, that's just a metal room with medical equipment and tools in it.Anyways, how was the gameplay easy? The very first gun you get is basically just god-like and really, really good. Not in the sense from the get-go, but giving it mods and developing the thing just turns it into a killing machine. With plentiful of ammo for it always around, I never felt tension or fear cause bullets for the gun that just quickly kills everything was everywhere. And if it wasn't everywhere? ...you buy it! There's so much money in this game and excess of items, I don't think I used one large medpack in this entire game, I just sold them for credits, and ammo for the line gun (one of the first new guns you can acquire) is quite easy to find and I rarely ever used it. So I could sell off the ammo for it for loads of cash, which in turn can be used to buy modules that allow you to mod you guns and make them EVEN MORE POWERFUL! :DAnd with that, you can increase your health, increase your air-time in space, increase your guns powers, your power to slow-down enemies.You can also buy new suits that allow you to carry more stuff, aka more stuff to sell. There's a lot of money lying around in this game, there's lots of items WORTH a lot of money just lying around. Medpacks are in ample supply. I beat this game using nothing but the first two guns you can acquire and the flame thrower to clean up some of the smaller more simple monsters that I don't want to waste ammo on.And then we get into bad game design. It's incredibly hard not to compare this to resident evil 4 and think about how much wrong there is in this game.The lack of variety in enemies, how easy it is to dispatch them, how the game constantly spams them at you whenever they can.Now, first off. When I say lack of variety in enemies. They really all just look the same, except some of them have tougher skin. The game showed off new enemy types WAY too far late into the game, and by then, they're very easy to kill, and not very interesting either. Really all the enemies are, are just tentacle babies, and floor crawlers, and then your standard guy standing in their legs and with sycthe arms. To kill enemies in this game, you kill them by cutting off their extremities. I just cut off their legs first and then their arms, to basically immobilize them and then easily cut off their arms.I don't care to get too much into that, cause it's really just that. Easily lopping off limbs without much of a sweat. Nothing changed to make it more difficult or interesting or dynamic. It was almost... generic. It like just easy enemies lining up for the headshot except their head is their limbs.The pacing is awful, this game spams enemies at you at every given turn, it's becomes an annoyance. I actually yelled at game game for putting just even more enemies in needless locations. Constantly in tiny rooms, never can go down a big room without some alien attack. It was aggravating and annoying, I couldn't do anything without monsters being there. There's ways to build tension and fear without having boring insessant conflicts all the time. You can't even do the no-gravity space puzzles without being attacked. It's incredibly tiring and annoying.I don't know, this entire game was a disppointment to me. Most of what I did felt like a chore, combat was easy, I felt no fear or tension, the story was elementary, and the characters were faceless contructs that had relatively nothing to contribute to the "story" and had I want to say no personality to speak of.Some people may find enjoyment in this game, because they will perhaps just simply enjoy gunning down zombie-like monsters and exploring the (woefully unexciting) ship and space, and that's fine. Plenty of people enjoyed this game clearly. However I found the experience to be a complete letdown and i'm just voicing why I think that it was not good.Regardless, thanks for reading my review. I hope it helped you in your decision to get this game or not. Have a good one.Edit: Also I played this game in its enterity on my xbox 360 controller.

 The game itself is good, the port is horrible Dead Space is a great game franchise. It had a good story, and the gameplay was great. The port however is really bad. This game should be capped at 30FPS, the game bugs very badly when vsync is disabled and you're around 60FPS+. There will be invisible doors blocking you from progressing, you will get stuck in the floor and die while jumping in 0 gravity mode, and the game will crash intermittently. I suffered through this terrible port to move on to the other two in the franchise.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Very rarely am I unable to tolerate a game. Dead Space is one of them. I don't know if it's just the PC version, but the controls are absolutely unbearable. I knew that things would be bad when the menu was impossible to navigate because of mouse lag, horrendous mouse acceleration, and mouse sensitivity which was difficult to adjust.Just getting the controls to a tolerable state by disabling V-Sync, forcing V-Sync in NVIDIA Control Panel, and adjusting mouse sensitivity in a configuration file was a chore. The worst part is that after all the tweaking, the controls still suck!Isaac moves like an oaf, mouse sensitivity and acceleration changes depending on the X/Y axis and whether or not you're aiming. Combined with the slow, lumbering movements, it really hampers the gameplay.The bottom line is that I can't even play without getting frustrated.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I don't understand why this game is well-rated on Steam. Don't get me wrong - Dead Space 1 is a great game on consoles, but on PC, they f**ked the port up in a number of ways.1) Framerate is locked to 30FPS when you have VSYNC enabled in-game2) Keyboard and mouse control is like steering a boat through jelly. Takes a big movement to register anything (seems to have a large 'dead-zone'), and the sensitivity is way down. You will be scrolling your mouse across your whole desk to turn a full circle in-game. If you turn the sensitivity to max, it's slightly better, but then the cursor flies all over the navigation menus. It's crazy.People have written guides on how to attempt to remedy this and some people have good success, those with ATI graphics cards have to do additioanl tweaking to get it working if they can get it working at all. None of this is the point though, you shouldn't have to trawl forums and run through trouble-shooting just to fix something that should have been immediately obvious to the developers in testing - the controls are broken.Either play with a gamepad, or just play this on console - you will have a much simpler-to-enjoy experience either way.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												If you plan to buy this game, I would implore you to reconsider:I bought this game 2 years ago and have tried to play it on 3 different computers. All of them have above recommended specifications. One computer can handle Fallout 4 and the other two are capable of playing Crysis, Global Offensive and Saints Row 4 all at their highest visual display settings. Two of these computers use AMD chips with AMD GPU and one uses Intel with sufficient HD integrated graphics. Realistically, this game should work on all of these, or at the very least, one of them.I am but one small voice, though. Searching Google for "Dead Space crashing" will show you that the amount of the people with this problem is not small. It should be noted that there has been no official attempt by developers to make the game actually compatible. The developers have abandoned creating patches for this game and I don't have any evidence to support that they might resurrect it.This is a great game, but it would seem that if you bought it on PC you wasted your money.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												System used at the time:Intel Core i7 593032GB DDR4-2666Samsung 840 Pro 256GB SSDNvidia Geforce GTX 980Very difficult game to recommend. Story is average, plot twist was a bit predictable, and the controls are infuriating.Graphically it is quite good, particularly for its time.Sound is possibly the best thing about the game, it is very creepy.The worst thing about this game, though, is the autosave. I had one area where I hadn't been able to save for a while, I'd come to an elevator and then a long corridor. I cleared out the enemies, moved on, and then the game has you double back. At this point, an unkillable monster lands right next to you, and the devs figured this is a great point at which to make the game autosave.I had no health left.So I was constantly trying to continue, only to be killed as soon as the game loaded from that autosave. Thankfully, there was one time I managed to spawn early enough before the monster spawned in place, and I escaped and was able to complete the game eventually.The game relies mostly on jump scares, there is very little that you'd actually get freaked out by, besides the jump scares.I found the field of view was awful, and made me feel nauseus quite regularly. The controls were also very poorly set for a PC game, and I don't recall there being a lot of options with regard to key binding.I've heard that Dead Space 2 and 3 brought some significant overhauls to some of the worst points of this game, so they would be more worthy of a purchase than this game, I would say.
