												This is a terrible port. First, the game launched at 800x600, and there was immense mouse lag while trying to navigate the menus. Unfortunately, the mouse lag still occurred after fixing the resolution to match my monitor's native resolution. I turned off V-sync, which solved the mouse lag issue, but understandably introduced awful screen tearing. Furthermore, the game does not support 120Hz, so you're pretty much forced to be subjected to the screen tearing. Gameplay-wise, I encountered the invisible door bug that occurs just after gameplay starts, preventing progress.Don't waste your money on this terrible port. Spend it on a non-EA game instead.Ugh.

number of helpful: 12 of 28 people (43%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Port Doom 3 to the consoles, then port it back to PC with non-rebindable controls and a laggy mouse, and the result is Dead Space. The game starts out in the survival horror vein, but soon suffers an identity crisis, locking the player in arena-like spaces with dozens of fast moving monsters attacking at once, which is dubious considering that the character is as agile as a pregnant potato and takes up at least a third of the screen. Choosing a third-person perspective for a game with a silent protagonist is another strange design decision that removes any sense of immersion, especially when the character just stands over a dying woman like a manikin with no trace of emotion. Add highly repetitive and mostly predictable gameplay involving completing two to three objectives per level, some of which are recycled later on, and there is no surprise that Doom 3 ends up a far superior game, with near identical visuals and storyline, but no artificial handicaps, better immersion, action, and horror.

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2012
												This game is a classic example of a great concept gone horribly wrong.  I really can't understand why Dead Space has gotten such a following.  This game combines a mediocre story and setting with clunky combat, terrible controls, and quite possibly the worst camera angle and FOV in the history of gaming.  Aim mode drops your aim sensitivity so much it's almost impossible to use and even adds joystick deadznoes to the mouse control.  Put this all together and you have the definition of artificial difficulty.It's not even as scary as Doom 3 due to relying entirely on jump scares which the game always warns you about with the music.I'd say the best part of the game are the zero gravity sections which are pretty fun, but even those are severely hampered by the poor camera which makes it difficult to navigate.  Overall, I can't find any way to recommend this game.

number of helpful: 13 of 30 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Let me preface this by saying that this isn't a bad game. It's just sort of medicore.There is a great deal of attention to detail at the beginning of the game, but you get the feeling that EA contracted these people to develop a game that was longer than it needed to be. A lot of the objectives are pretty much, "We need to do this one big thing during this chapter, so you need to do this thing 1 and this thing 2 in order to do the big thing." It wasn't very compelling.The ship itself has a great interior but you don't feel like most of it was meant for people to live on. It is cold and uninviting, which, while forboding, wasn't exactly great at connecting the player to this environment. This detail was better addressed in Dead Space 2.The combat is novel. The problem is that they give you these cool weapons to purchase in the game, but you don't actually need them. I completed the game using nothing but the default weapon.The pacing of the scares was, again, great at the beginning, but became rather predictable the longer you played. It felt like a lot of action and almost no suspense. A detail which was also addressed better in Dead Space 2.There was an aggravating bug in one section using zero-G that made my character die immediately. It was made more aggravating because it was a puzzle section and each time I died I had to start over.Don't get me wrong, Dead Space does do some things great that other games don't do very well. The need to conserve ammunition for instance is pretty good and balanced out by the in-game store. It really does have a survival horror feel.Lastly, it runs very well with my Radeon HD 7770 and 2.9 ghz x4.Overall, it's just okay. I had a bit of fun, but it was sort of hampered by a few poor design choices.

content:

												I gave this game a negative review simply because of the way it was ported. Don't get me wrong-I don't hate a game just because it is ported. However, it angers me when a game is ported in a terrible way. Right from the start, I noticed the mouse sensitivity was crap. I adjusted it many times, eventually pushing it to the max sensitivity, but I still had to pick up my mouse at least four times to do a full 360. I ended up plugging in my Xbox One controller, which kind of solved the issue. However, I then noticed how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the FOV was, even for a 3rd-person game. I eventually got over it, just to find an invisible door that I can't go through for the life of me, even after trying multiple times. Mind you, this all happened in the course of about 5 minutes, so I alt-F4'ed and never looked back. Worse port than GTA4.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Just as a heads up to potential buyers, if you do not like to fiddle with computer tech stuff, don't try this game. As I write this, I've been stuck for about an hour with one problem after another: Laggy mouse (turn off vsync), mouse sensitivity too low in-game, and normal in menues, and a fabulous Show Stopper Game Destroying bug right at the start of the game, where you are actually stuck and cannot continue the game. An invisible wall prevents you from moving forward. The solution? Well, I googled it, and after a good long while (the official fix on steam did nothing), I found a tip that said to turn on Fraps (!) to lower the framerates. And it worked....!This is 2015, and the game intro screen says the game is from 2008. They have had seven years to fix these annoying and game breaking bugs, and haven't done it. Shame on you EA. My already low opinion of them has become even lower. As for the game content, I expect that to be good. I will continue playing the game. But any immersion will be completely ruined due to the crappy interface. Would I recommend the game? Well, the short answer is "no". The long answer can be found above: Don't buy the game unless you are willing to try and overcome these technical problems.After playthrough:After overcoming the initial problems, I discovered that there were more problems later on, linked to vsync, and turning it on and off. And having a mouse where sensitivity could be increased helped against the low mouse speed. The game content? It is excellent, a high quality game experience. For example:- No unnecessary running- Lots of shortcuts after completing an objective- No "stupid" deaths, like falling off a ledge- Checkpoints before difficult fights- Creepy atmosphere, good plotAll in all, you can tell that this is a well-thought out game. That people have really worked with the details. It is a little strange to play an FPS game where you can neither duck or jump, but in a way it is relaxing. You know if you can't reach someplace, you're not meant to go there. No invisible walls (except the bugs) to prevent creative players from going where they are not supposed to.Last impression... well, I downloaded and started playing Dead Space 2 just now, and all the issues were fixed. It makes me wonder why they didn't fix this game as well. It's a shame, since it's such a nice game in all aspects except that.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
Okay, so I fixed the glitch....and it has turned my opinion around. I like weird cool science fiction stuff, I like space, I like zombies, and I like aliens. This pretty much takes all of those and rolls them up into one neat big fat game. It doesn't do a terrible job at it, ei-AAAAAAAHHHHHHHH!!!...sorry, jump scare. So, as I was saying, after I turned on verti-AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Okay, okay, sorry...they won't get me a thir-3,000 jump scares laters!So now that I've been sufficiently not really jump scared (I was being sarcastic.) I still enjoy the overall atmosphere and awesome-tude of this game. Really, even the character design when they're out of special helmeted uniforms is fairly creepy, with the completely unrealistic plastic looking graphical faces, etc, etc. Seriously, though...Look. Aliens. Zombies. Alien Zombies. It's a winning combination, and the designs they came up with for the enemies are pretty freakin' spooky. They wiggle and jiggle about and you get to dismember them by stomping on them. I can't complain about that. And for all the weirdyness, the game has held up graphically, as well. My major complaints are mostly based around pacing, which seems so incredibly slow to me as to negate the horror aspects of the game. I get it, you're trying to build some suspense, but sometimes that just goes a bit too far. 7/10 - would have been 8, but I'm easily irritated by stupid glitches that cause a game to be unplayable until they're tweaked. Most people would call this nitpicking, I call it expecting things to work out of the box. Still changed my mind, though. Totally deserves a recommendation.

This means that taking one step back could cause a monster to double back and pathfind all around the map to get to you, and one step forward makes the monster run straight at you again. Funny, but totally breaks the atmosphere. In another spot, I couldn't progress due to my computer loading an NPC quicker than the game expected, which stopped some script from running, and this making a door not open, which was less funny. I kept having to reload over and over, until one time the door magically opened.Overall: Just another hastily-ported console game from EA.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												With hard to manage HUDs, clumbsy and drunken-esuq movements, and slowmoving combat movements with fast moving enemies, not recommended. The story is, overall, kind of bland for this setting. With the whole alien virus from an alien planet and government intervention thing and all. There are too many "battle stratagies", with stasis mods and the like, but no real time with the players slow movement speed between actions and the enemies fast movement speeds to do anything stratigic with them but unload and hope you hit something. And with intended to be immersive features for 3rd person, it only makes it feel crowded and hard to manage. There are no real actions that help you in combat, such as take over, or crouch. And in order to defeat waves of enemies, you have to maintain the sites with the lock function, but when enemies get too close (which they will on a regular basis) the melee attacks are uncoordinated, clumbsy, and useless unless planned for, which melee attacks are not meant for. Along with confusing, and useless other features, like 3D map overlay, and alternate weapon mods that don't really do anything useful, this game is not recommended, and not the best 3rd person shooter on the market. If your looking for a decent 3rd person with all these problems fixed, try the Mass Effect trilogy.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												They say that the best scary movies are the ones were you don't get to see the monsters.  Deadspace took this to heart.  You don't get to see the monsters coming at you.  In fact you don't get to see much of anything at all.  You do however, get to see the back of the main protagonists space suit.  Riveting as that may be to some, I just found it to be very annoying.  Add to that a small degree of input lag and it becomes extremely unimmersive.  He quickly goes from being the player character to an NPC who keeps getting in your way.  Any survival horror that makes you wish for the death of the main character is fundamentally flawed.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												The most boring game I have ever played actually. Your character is so slow it feels like your're walking around in syrup.Extremely easy since you only need to shoot 2 limbs off to kill everything except for certain boss monsters all of which have gigantic shoot here signs. You can raise the difficulty higher, but only after you beat the game once, and quite frankly I would rather jab forks in my leg than play it again.As a horror game is fails miserably in all regards except for maybe the monster design, they look pretty neat.Way too predictable, meaning all of the "scary oogabooga surprise" moments get shut down as soon as they happen or even before they get a chance to even do anything. About half way through the game I just kept hoping every chapter was the last one, since I did pay for the damn thing and should at least finish it. The most satisfying moment was uninstalling the game, which is bittersweet since it's still in my library, possibly stuck there forever. Poor Isaac Clarke should have retired long before this game was ever made and been given a wheelchair to give his day to day life a little more speed.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												To understand why I am not recommending it, you need to first understand in what time it came out, and what time we are now.It could be safe to say that, while Dead Space did not invent the shock horror genre, it did give it a very strong boost.That said, we are now in a time and year where we've been frequently exposed, if not overexposed, to shock horror and quick scares. Horror in gaming has had to evolve and those that didn't or failed to do so obviously got left behind.With this little bit of perspective, you should understand that Dead Space (at all times I am talking about the first instalment, I haven't tried the sequels yet) no longer offers any real scares any more. Only those not accustomed to this kind of horror would still feel the dread. And quite frankly, that can't be a whole lot of people any more, let alone 'Gamers'.(if you do happen to find that rare person, videotape it. Those tend to be a real hit on Youtube)Everything that this game throws at you feels like it 'once' was scary and impressive. Especially as it, if my knowledge doesn't fail me, came in a time when it did a lot of impressive things. It's visual quality was top notch and people hadn't tired fully yet from QTE's.But that's the thing (and I know I'm harping on it way too much), it just doesn't scare me any more. And you can also see where the concept had it's flaws. Sure, getting grabbed by that huge tentacle and having to timely shoot it's weak spot before it consumes you is a shocker the first time, but when you die... It just starts all over again once you've gotten to that point from your last checkpoint, and the scare factor is completely devoid of it.In fact, because I was playing on the Hard difficulty, I've had to attempt the second encounter of said tentacle for over TWENTY TIMES. This is partly thanks to the fact I was trying to do a Plasma Cutter only run. Suffice to say I was nothing short of annoyed and bored, eventually. Modern games nowadays tend to include some kind of compensation or balancing so the challenge remains fair but largely doable, unless the game's whole deal is to be unfair.And that is why I am not recommending it. Not because it would be bad game, not because it would happen to be unfair or brutal. I simply don't recommend it because it's no longer adhering to the standards of modern Horror. Which is largely to blame for the genre itself evolving and drastically changing recently.If you would get the game, get it for the nostalgia and to understand where the genre 'used to be'.Just don't expect a product that will knock you off your socks.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												I had high hopes for this game, but I couldn't even get it to work correctly.First I had serious mouse lag, so I looked up a fix on google and found that disabling VSync would fix it, and it did. Okay, cool, great...so I get in the game and the controls are awful. I can't move and look at the same time??? What are we trying to replicate the late 80s/early 90s and the plethora of games with awful controls from that time period?! The only way to turn was to completely stop moving, then use your mouse to point in the direction you want to go, then move again. Using WASD + a mouse at the same time is not allowed...roflOk, I thought. Whatever. It's dumb as hell, but maybe I'll get used to it. So I play for about 2 minutes and get to a doorway I can't go through- got the classic "run in air" motion. Sigh...so I alt+tab and go to google again, and tried several "solutions". None worked.At this point I pretty much said screw it, quit the game and uninstalled. I really don't have the time or patience for this kind of crap anymore. When I install a game, I want to be able to play it...is that too much to ask for? Apparently it is for Dead Space.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												It's basically System Shock 2 with Resident Evil 4 style gameplay... only not nearly as good as either. This isn't a bad game by any means, just mediocre. All the "horrors" are pretty much just jump scares, which I'm not really into, and they are pretty predictable. The AI being terrible doesn't really help there. It has "got me" a couple of times, but mostly it's just boringly linear and predictable. I find the added clanking sounds everywhere to be just annoying as well (not creepy either, you can EASILY tell if it's just background noise or an actual monster by turning); silence would've made the monster sounds way more tensing. Even with all that, and a weapon that mows down enemies, the environment still keeps me at least a little tense, so there's that.The story is... well... it's ok. Only because it's CLEARLY "inspired" by System Shock 2 (with a dash of Alien tossed in). And that's kind of a nice way of saying it's almost a ripoff. Though at least they managed to make me care at least a little about a silent protagonist. Unlike "Goggles" from SS2, which nobody even knows his name.I found the graphics to be quite good for the time though, and the UI is pretty neat. The textures all look reasonably sharp and it runs perfectly even on my 460. The art direction is pretty uninspired for the most part, however.The upgrade system is interesting as well. The level of customisation is nifty. I dislike how there are empty upgrade nodes though, but whatever. I wonder how many upgrade points you get through the game though. This is all putting aside the fact that it is a mediocre console port. Controls are passable at best, unplayable at worst. The UI controls are even broken beyond belief. You know it's a bad console port when saving is hard because of the controls. Also, the worst vsync integration I have ever seen in a game. Holy cow. Makes the game almost unplayable. If you do buy this, turn it off.Half the "horror" in this game is because you are playing a guy who has less agility than a guy in a wheelchair, who walks around like he's in a tank. I very much dislike games that use this scheme (I'm looking at you, Resident Evil 4). There are far better ways to instill fear in the player than to just cripple there movement. Give me some agility and melee capabilities, and up the AI's reaction and speed and you could achieve the same effect, and you have a games that's *gasp* fun to play.I'd say skip it unless it's a genre you are really into (tank control third person "horror" game). Even with that, go play System Shock 2 and get over it's old graphics, because it's a far, far better game that defines how you do a space horror game. If this game scares you and System Shock 2 doesn't even phase you then you are quite the simpleton, I'd have to say.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
WHY DO PEOPLE FIND THIS GARBAGE FUN???????????????????????????OK, got that out of the way.  Now on to my honest, unbiased review.  The game is graphically poor.  The horror is cliche and cheesy.  The story is good, but nothing special.  The combat is simple at best and unremarkable.  What sealed the deal for me is the fact that the game seems so underdeveloped that they couldn't implement a proper movement mode.  When your main character walks/runs anywhere you can barely turn.  When you are stationary your character turns crazy fast.  If you turn down mouse sensitivity you cant aim.  The character animations even clip between movement and turning, it's ridiculous.  Some of the most basic and vital mechanics of the game were so lazily and blatantly looked over that it's extremely sensible that after you see EA developed it you think to yourself;  "I shoulda known it was EA."The only excuse this game has is that it's very old and outdated.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2013
												To appropriate a phrase that Pauline Kael used to describe "Aliens," Dead Space is a "Boo Game."  It's basically just you wandering around a ship and every few yards or so a monster will pop out and say "boo!" over and over and over again.  Occasionally there is a kind of interesting boss fight, but "boo!" is like 75% of the game and it gets old really fast.I honestly don't understand why these games are popular.  The controls are sluggish, the action is slow, the gameplay is repetitive, and the levels are mostly just tedious corridors leading to even more corridors without a whole lot of range of movement.  The scarcity of ammo is kind of a nice touch, I guess, as it at least gives the game a more desperate feel and highlights the "survival" in survival horror, but that's really the only thing nice that I can think of to say about this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2013
												Dead Space has an interesting story, but lacks polish in a lot of other areas. Like so many games, it introduces interesting concepts, only to execute them poorly. For instance, you sever the arms of aliens to kill them. The catch? Mouse control is awful. It requires precise aiming, and you can clearly tell that it's a console port by the way you are moving. In fact, I was forced to disable v-sync to even get the mouse working at all. A lot of other things work poorly, including AA (any type), loading saves (yes, loading saves), and simulated physics. It's also not immersive (probably due to the abundant issues) and therefore not intense/frightening at all.I -might- play this for the story, but with all the other problems, it's really not worth it.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Ugh, I don't get all the glowing reviews for this one. You walk your slow guy around following the blue lines on the floor. The music gets dramatic! Creeps jump out at you! Kill them, find objective, press E. Then trudge around some more and do it again. That's the game.The combat is pretty mindless. You don't have enough room to find a good tactical angle for shooting; most of the enemies just magically spawn up close right after you trigger some scripted event. Also, your movement speed is very slow and switching from a melee attack to gun takes forever. So it's stressful in that you have to shoot accurately quickly, but there's very little you can do with your positioning.In my five hours, I've yet to have fun or look forward to a new play session, so I'm going to stop now.

content:
Posted: February 2
												Dead Space:DO NOT BUY.This game is not worth the hassle! If you suffer from motion sickness with certain games, Dead Space is very, very bad! Also, it's a revolting console port. It's a shame because the story is good and so is the combat.Positives:+ The level design is solid, with lots of different areas, including zero gravity sections which can be quite disorienting and parts of the mining ship are not vacuum sealed, so you'll be running on a limited supply of oxygen. + Additional powers are granted by finding advanced scientific modules, which allow you to slow time or use telekinesis on heavy objects. Smart integration throughout the levels.+ Many weapons and upgrades.+ Combat is fast paced and has a sense of urgency to it.+ Diverse alien creatures which keep you intrigued.Mixed:~ Graphics are average.Negatives:- For a horror title it isn't scary at all, despite obvious efforts by developers to implement jump scares, "eerie music" (lol) and dark rooms. Only idiots or those who are easily rattled would think otherwise.- I'm getting severe dizziness while playing this game, even up to an hour after exiting. This is the WORST physical symptom I have experienced from a PC game EVER. In 99% of games I'm completely fine and if I do happen to have a minor problem, disabling motion blur fixes any issues - but not in Dead Space. I've downloaded a third party program to try and adjust the FOV, but it didn't help me. The camera angle is completely ♥♥♥♥ed. This is a huge issue which makes the game very difficult to enjoy.- The mouse sensitivity is a nightmare, it is worse than the burning flames of hell. Good luck aiming your gun at all LOL - DISASTER! You need to edit the game files just to fix it, cool.- Encountered a game breaking bug 5 minutes in, where an "invisible barrier" stops me from proceeding through an open doorway (apparently it's a glitch with unlimited FPS settings). This is 8 years after Dead Space was released - no patch! Had to tinker with NVIDIA control panel to resolve the issue!- Movement is as slow as a sloth when running, no jumping or crouching controls, very basic. 3/10Lazy developers. If you're not going to make Dead Space properly playable, why even port it to PC? Such good content, but such a broken PC version. Could have been a far better game than it is. GARBAGE!

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												I can't bring myself to play this game after 7 chapters anymore because it's such a piece of crap. I don't mind stupid runaround quests, i don't even mind it actually has no story at all, i don't usually mind stupid traps sending me back to the checkpoint over and over again, what i do mind though is the combination of all this ♥♥♥♥ in one game creating a huge boring hassle just getting from chapter to chapter.This game tries too hard be like combination of The Thing and Event horizon and whatnot but it fails so bad. The Thing wasn't about tentacly monsters and Event horizon wasn't about being on a spaceship with tentacly monsters so it just doesn't deliver any tension or horror, only cheap predictable "scares" and silly tentaclemonsters running around you hoping they catch you in a narrow corridor because if they try to fight you in a more spacious environment you might get some good laughs watching them run around like a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Probably so you could take your time aiming with those weirdly clunky controls trying to figure out where the monster might be since half of your screen is blocked by the dude's back.The absence of story doesn't really help, it just makes it all even more pointless. Yes i know about the logs and whatnot, it's just all really really boring and most of the times nothing happens. Yeah a new bigger tentaclemonster appears because some crazy guy going on about the tentacly children being the successors of humans which are this and that and therefore they deserve to die. And then you go running around picking stuff and putting it on the other side of the deck. That being done by a mute doofy guy, but that's actually nice of the creators to not include any voiceacting to the main character because they realized it would be superpointless since the game has no real story, so they actually saved some money and hopefully used it on charity or something. And that's pretty much it about the "story" of this game.I love scifi and horror and i couldn't imagine i wouldn't like a game that is scifi horror, until Dead space.Seriously it's cheap, predictable, it has no story, it has clunky controls and most importantly it tries too hard at being tense that it's just not scary.

number of helpful: 1 of 14 people (7%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Dead Space shamelessly rips off of far greater games, and oftentimes fails to live up to the games it so desperately tries to imitate. That being said, Dead Space is redeemed by its fantastic combat, pacing, and production values. Overall, Dead Space is a solid title that deserves to be bought when on sale. The major negatives that drag Dead Space down are all tied to its derivative nature. Dead Space attempts to have non-linear metroidvania-style level design, most likely due to classics such as System Shock 2.  Unfortunately, Dead Space does a generally poor job at it. In System Shock 2, the levels were built open for a reason; the Von Braun was built to imitate a lived in space. People who have played System Shock 2 will clearly remember how the decks were divided into sleeping quarters, marketplaces, cargo bays, and other sections that fit together in a plausible way. Dead Space's levels, however, are extremely hublike and repetitive in nature. The areas have no sense of practicality at all, often being a string of bland metal hallways, connecting rooms that are filled with decorative and pointless machinery. Speaking of which, the game's is graphically strong, but aesthetically lacking.  It really feels like the designers based the ship's design off the grungiest parts of Alien and Event Horizon, and the monsters off of the goriest segments of The Thing. The unfortunate part is the lack of discipline involved; the designers simply spammed these incredibly derivative visual designs over everything, but seemed to forget that the goriest parts of The Thing were only scary because they happened sparingly and unexpectedly, and the darker segments of Alien and Event Horizon were only atmospherically suffocating because of the way they contrasted against otherwise sterile environments. And of course, the combat itself does suffer slightly, as it sometimes leans too heavily on classic survival horror titles such as Resident Evil. It can arbitrarily try to make itself clunky, which isn't effective at raising tension, and is only frustrating when paired with the mouse and keyboard. The amazing thing about Dead Space's core mechanics is how they manage to redeem the rest of the experience. Blasting limbs off of enemies is viscerally satisfying, and the major drawbacks of the game feel extraneous to the core experience, which is, once again, fantastic. There aren't that many types of enemy, but each and every one requres a different set of tactics to take down, meaning that the player will constantly have to adapt to mixed hordes of undead. While the game is not nearly as scary as, say, Amnesia or Silent Hill, there is always the tension that comes with being startled or overwhelmed by enemies, and the extra shot of adrenaline is definitely welcome. Overall, Dead Space is a solid 6/10, and deserves to be picked up on sale, along with the vastly superior sequel that refined and nearly perfected the formula.

												♥♥♥♥ THIS GAME.I do NOT recommend anyone buy Dead Space on PC.  This game is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port.  However, I recommend someone to go ahead and buy it on a console. The story is OK, and it isn't as cliche for a horror/survival game as others that exist. Going back to the main point on why this is a♥♥♥♥♥♥port there are terrible controls and rampant bugs throughout this game.The controls are terrible. You will fight the controls more than the necromorphs. Using the keyboard plus mouse on this game will get you killed. You will spend a considerable amount of time even struggling to hit continue on the menu screen because of your mouse speed. You will struggle to turn Issac around as he is getting gang♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by necromorphs, and you will just kill yourself in irl when you try to shoot something with your mouse, the aiming/shooting system is terrible.  I feel like it's talking as much effort to aim/shoot as when I'm trying to get laid.  I tried using v synch and adjusting my mouse/keyboard settings in and out of game to help with the grievances of the controls, but I gave up and tried using an xbox controller. Using an xbox controller it still feels like the controls are a clunky mess and aiming isn't as bad of a problem, but it still annoys me to great lengths. Although, running around using a controller is easier than on my keyboard and I don't hit the wrong buttons as much when I need to use telekinesis.Aside from the controls there a lot of bugs in the game. A lot of these bugs will either prevent you from advancing the story, get you killed randomly, and of course there are random crashes. A few examples of these bugs are such as when  I once got into the store machine to change my suit, but I was stuck in there; the little loading time for Issaac to change his suit never finished and I had to restart my game. Another problem I had was when I was going through the plant..hydroponics area and there was this giant wheel thingy that was electrified. When I was gravity jumping to get back to the kill the Levithan there was a glitch where the wheel thingy would kill me and prevented me from completing the game; I had to restart the game and go through a lot more jumping because of that. In addition to those bugs, in my play time I had quite a few CTDs, and had to go back through a previous level to reach a part of the game where I was before my last CTD happened.  I feared the CTDs more than the necromophs.TLDR Buy this game if you want to torture yourself with terrible controls and if you like Dead Space lore..I dont think this game is actually scary. Dead Space 2 was pretty freaky.Yes, that's right! Thumb me down you butthurt little ♥♥♥♥♥es!

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												This is one of those games that really give you a different feel than most. Even though it is not a new game, it makes you play on the edge of your seat. I'll admit that I never played it before, since I was afraid to do so. But I decided to just do it anyway since it was recommended to me. Most games don't get me on edge like Dead Space did. That has to speak for something. If you like Sci-fi movies and games and dig the space horror genre, this is a MUST buy. I sunk 14 hours into it on the first play through, and who knows how many more are coming. That will have to wait until after I play Dead Space 2.It is worth noting that after you beat the game, you get to start over with all of your gear and items + 10 power nodes, 50,000 credits and a level 6 military suit. It also unlocks an even harder difficulty for those of you who like to REALLY feel like the Ishimura could be the death of you. Most games like this don't seem to have much replay value, but I think I will definitely revisit this sometime soon. Do yourself a favor and buy this one

Posted: October 27, 2011
												Best "new" horror franchise? I think so. This game here had me gasping for air and i've seen my fair share of sick♥♥♥♥♥♥(movies like: Inside, High tension, In the mouth of madness, Event horizon, etc). I can't say that this game gave me the "jump scares" (although there were some such moments) but i can definitely say that it made me feel uneasy,disturbed, out of breath and overall it created a very unpleasant atmosphere. There were times that i felt like playing the game just to progress story-wise but i kept postponing it because i wasn't willing to undergo the torture. The whole experience felt like a journey towards catharsis through the bowels of hell. Just a word of warning though. Do yourself a favour and play it on HARD for your first playthrough (so that the game isn't demoted to a plain shootfest) with a pair of good headphones in a pitch black room (HD res and all that Jazz is also a must for this). Enjoy!

content:
Posted: December 6, 2011
												For a straight console port, Dead Space was surprisingly decent.  The story is very engrossing, which is good for games.  The weapon and character upgrades are somewhat limited but at least the game throws lots of aliens at you to dispense of some ammo.The science-fiction writing here is top notch, but the game suffers from terrible controls that can only be corrected for PC to a certain degree.  The world is also very immersive but the controls unfortunately take some of that away.  If you can live with and work around these control issues, you'll find an excellent shooter with an eerily scary world to march through.But really, upgrade the shiznit out of that plasma gun and it will set you free.

content:

												Dead Space is a game that gave the horror genre a much needed jumpstart. After years of Resident Evil sequels we finally get a well executed space horror game that marries both horror and gore. Even today I am rather fond of the look of despair this game has going for it.One thing I do recommend is playing this game with someone in a dark lit room. There is something fantastic about sharing fear, and a good friend sitting with you through Dead Space is a pleasure that is hard to describe.If that doesn't sell you this game, just remember that this game has horrible tentacle babies. content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Dead Space is a third-person survival-horror video game. The player takes on the role of an engineer named Isaac Clarke, who battles horrific monsters known as Necromorphs on a deep space mining ship called The USG Ishumura. If your looking for a good horror game and you have not played this one yet look no further. Dead Space will suck you in with its gameplay, setting, story and charathers. You will not be dissapointed. I would like to note that its best to play this title with a controller as there seems to be some mouse control issues though you can try to fix it by going into your Nvidia/AMD control panel and enable V-Sync and Triple Buffering from there and disable the in-game V-Sync as it cuts your monitors refresh rate by half.Overall I its been a long time sience a horror game has hooked me in like Dead Space and is an excelent start to a great franchise :D

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												This game is really well paced, has an excellent story.  Level design is rarely repetitive, and the areas with zero gravity and no air are some of the most interesting challenges the game provides.  The over the shoulder camera works pretty well for a mechanic that is intended to provoke claustrophobia without making you feel like you have to wrestle with it..    The only real criticism I have for it is due to the way I played it.  I tend to meticulously collect all the loot possible, which doesn't always match the narrative, but if you don't do this then you put yourself at a real disadvantage.  That being said, if you do collect and upgrade regularly then medium difficulty is relatively easy.  I think giant, dangerous spaceship machinery killed me more often then enemies.  It's real fun, completely recommend, especially given that you can get it for free on Origin.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2010
												The first time I saw a video about this game it was like some EA guy rambling on about how they had just discovered a new element that allows them to make scary games. "Scary" is apparently defined as "disembodied girl voice singing twinkle twinkle little star". I kid, though, this game has proven to me that George Lucas was right all along: there really is sound in space. And it's screams. Screams everywhere. Like the screams those Tie Fighters make, only instead of coming from a space ship they're coming from my girly mouth. I haven't been this happy about a game's sound since the time I figured out how to alter a Furby's files (I'm pretty sure Tim still has nightmares about that). Not to spoil anything but the core plot from the game was stolen from that episode of Star Trek The Next Generation where the crew goes out too far into the universe and discovers that their thoughts can make things real, but it's really just all in their heads. I.e., Dead Space is every sci-fi ever.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2011
												This game is pretty awesome. It's like Resident Evil 4 (with better controls) mixed with System Shock mixed with Event Horizon. Your mileage may vary on whether it's scary or not, but it's definitely scarier than the later installments. The story is nothing to write home about and you can probably see one of the major plot twists coming a mile away. This doesn't prevent it from being an enjoyable game though.What DOES prevent it from being a 100% enjoyable game is the fact that it has 'console port' written all over it. The FOV is fairly low as you might expect. There are also quite a few mouse problems, including mouse acceleration that cannot be disabled, lower vertical sensitivity than horizontal, and sensitivity that varies wildly based on your frame rate. Additionally, the in-game Vsync setting is completely ♥♥♥♥ing broken. It locks you to 30 fps and introduces an unplayable amount of input lag.If you have a computer capable of running the game at a consistent 60+ fps (which isn't difficult) I would recommend forcing on Vsync and triple-buffering in your graphics card driver if you have an AMD card or using D3DOverrider if you have an Nvidia card. This will fix the inconsistent sensitivity. If you have a mouse that lets you adjust the DPI separately for each axis you can set the Y axis DPI higher than the X axis DPI to compensate for the Y axis being less sensitive. There's no way I know of to remove the acceleration. The FOV can be increased using Widescreen Fixer but it will make menus farther away from the camera and thus more difficult to read, so you may have to toggle it off periodically.Other than the technical issues I think Dead Space is still a great game and I would definitely recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												While not a subtle horror experience, as the game boasts, this game does have some good moments. If you want to be scared by it do this: play it with the lights off, or while they're dying. I've been startled, and even totally unnerved. Buy the game, it is worth it. On the outside, Dead Space looks like it relies on cheap scares, and really isn't that scary, but if you get into it, you feel alone. Your team is unreliable for any help, Isaac only speaks in 2 onward, and your only friend is your weapon of choice, mine are mining tools, like the ripper, which works great. The enemies behave like zombies, but not 100%. They walk exclusively in straight lines, and are quicker and cleverer. Being stuck with them is unsettling. But it does feel like Event Horizon. Except the Ishimura isn't evil, the Red Marker is, however. I hope when I finish it, the second is as good, if not better.

												I still remember the day Dead Space arrived on XBOX 360 and I picked up my pre-order with excitement. Posted: June 15, 2014
												Easily one of my most favorite game series. This game is for players who want a decient scare but are also willing to get immersed in the story. Dead Space is about an engineer named Issac Clark who inspects the USG Ishimura, thinking there's a simple fix he and his crew have to do. Soon after boarding, all hell breaks loose as secrets are revieled and tensions become wavering. Soon after starting this game, you'll want to play it over and over again then going onto the next game. I easily give this game a 9/10; this game is completely bone chilling with its atmosphere, but sometimes has its occasional stupid but hilarious glitch. I recommend this game to all players and should be a must play game.

												I am personally a fan of the Dead Space series. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												The biggest compliment that I can give Dead Space is that it gives me an experience akin to watching the Aliens movies, which I love. You play as silent protagonist Isaac Clarke who boards the USG Ishimura in order to discover what has happened on board the ship. THe motivation which drives Isaac further forward is his desire to be reunited with his wife who happens to be on board the Ishimura.Dead Space has a variety of monsters to face and a few distinct and unique ways in which to deal with them thanks to the weapons Isaac has at hand and which are available for him to purchase later in the game. While the weapon choices are fairly limited, the different ways in which they can be used to eliminate your enemies will allow you to have a variety of options in which to play the game.The graphics still hold up and the setting is eerie enough, with the sound effects truly spectacular if you are using a proper sound system or headphones. While the story and characters may not be the strongest, those are not the reasons you play a game like Dead Space. If you are looking for a third person survival shooter to scare the ever-loving crap out of you, I cannot recommend this game highly enough.4.5 out of 5 stars.

												Another story-heavy FPS with decent gameplay.  It is legitimately scary in places, though it does rely on the occasional jump scare.  There's also a section at the end (shooting asteroids from a turret) that is infamous for its awfulness, but IIRC, I beat it on the second try (after spending the first try figuring out what the hell was going on), so it's not _that_ bad.  Don't play on Hard on your first try.  It's balanced assuming you can do a New Game+ playthrough with all the upgrades acquired on your first trip through.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I have to admit, I am biased. I love sci-fi, I love action horrors... And Dead Space is an awesome blend of those. I don't really play many horror games per se... But being put to a metal container in the vast depths of space without any chance of immediate escape just has some allure. This game is a horrifying, gory, repelling ugly mess that will just force you to love and hate it at the same time because of all the scares and great moments of satisfaction, like when you clean a room full of necros. It's the only horror game (the first installment and its successors) that has ever compelled me to finish it and suffer through all its gritty atmospheric length. Dead Space is my most favourite horror game.

												If you're into games like Resident Evil, Batman Arkham series, or Silent Hill then this game is definitley going to knock your socks off. I'm not usually into this genre but Steam had it on sale for so cheap I couldn't pass it up, I've played it long enough to realize I am hooked. Dead Space is a game you turn all the l ights off put on some headphones and escape into a dark world where you could die at any time. Personally, I play 'ironman' (don't ever save) for that extra edge. This game heavily depends on your reaction time and reflexes because danger could be around any corner or above you, if you're not quick enough or can't decide how to react then you are dead. The story is pretty cool too, I'm only on chapter 6 but I am very interested on where this story is going and then once this is done I'll be going right to Dead Space 2.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												Even though this game is old, it is scary as fu**. You are an engineer aboard the Ishimura where an alien plague like thing has broken out. It sound scary because it is. You will hear screeching, banging, dragging, and other sounds when running through dark hallways. You never know where the enemy is. Definitely the scariest game I have ever played. The campaign is long and filled with different enemies and weapons. You will surely not play the game through in one sitting because this game is so scary you will be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ all over the place. TL;DR: This game is old but holds up well, will scare the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you with a long campaign and many scare encounters. 5/5. Note: Everyone on PC will have issues with aiming due to a poor port. Easily fixed by either using a controller or following this guide: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dead_Space#Mouse_Lag_and_Random_Sensitivity

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2013
												In space nobody hears you scream. Get it. And the 2nd one too. (Hands off the 3rd one tho.) The psychological terror and horror of aproaching that seemlesly harmless vent shaft is something every true man must experience. And a true woman. And a true unborn child. Just kidding. The atmosphere is a Dead Space signature and the sound architecture of every level is jaw-dropping. So good, you'd wish it'd be a bit worse. (the screams are loud enough to make you loose your body fluids, yet silent enough to drive you into paranoia, wheter you're starting to imagine things.) Gunplay is hectic, fast but still has a tactic feel to it. ("Aim for the limbs!" everyone says. Even the f*ckin' art cover)The suit and gun upgrades are somewhat dull, but it's enough to give you the feeling of progression. The main point driving you forward is the story. So the conclusion: A good shooter, a brilliant horror game and a mediocre RPG at once, this game is an ideal way to empty your bladder while having a blast doing it. (Uhm... did I just say that?)[DISCLAIMER: In case my review wasn't obvious enough, this is a truly SCARY game. The "I'd rather♥♥♥♥♥♥my bed, than leaving it" type of scary]

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Classic that holds up well even  against today's games.  6 years have passed since dead space stepped on the scene showing the survival horror doesn't have to be just zombies or creepy towns.  This game is unapologetically gory but thats just one part of the appeal. Game play is solid witha  dismemberment system that actually will affect your success or failure in the game. The Space in Dead Space is promenent with plenty of sci fi themes mixed in with the horror. The protagonist will work on space drives, traverse zero g sections, have to conserve oxygen in vaccum areas, and gains access to an upgradable aresnal of sci fi weapons that rance from plasmas cutters to energy beams and a lot in between.Dead Space's greatest success is in its truely creepy atmoshpere. Excellent sound design featuring footsteps, indistinct whispering and well done voice logs set the tone. Ligting and startling enemy encounters help to round out this truely  scary experience. Highly reccomended for anyone that has an interest in survival horror/scifi games.  *A note disable the ingame vysnc to unlock the default 30fps game. Forcing vysnc through your gpu drivers will give a preferable 60fps and forcing Anti-Aliasing from gpu drives is also highly reccomended to make this game look its best.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												Dead Space is a sci-fi horror game.  If you've ever seen the movie Event Horizon, it has a very similar "feel" to it.  The game does have some flaws (some weird V sync issues and the part with the asteroids), but I really like the feeling of dread that the game gives you -- I felt like I never had enough ammo or health to survive.  Some would say that is a poor design choice but it adds to the game in my opinion (you are an abandoned ship in the cold void of space, so it makes sense that there aren't a ton of supplies in the ship).  It's no Cry of Fear, but this game is scary.  Having a Necromorph (or worse, more than one) sprint at you as you fumble with your weapons is a very intense experience.  If you are a fan of sci-fi, horror, or sci-fi horror, Dead Space is worth playing.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												A game that perhaps revived and redfined survival horror.  No longer did you follow the typical "shoot them in the head", but instead was goaled with dismembering.  Perhaps my favorite horror game to come out in the last six years, it was definitly the best in the series with a A+ ending.  The rest of the series follows up well, however, as it goes on, it loses more of its survival horror and migrates into more of a action game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2010
												It's like Resident Evil, without the mediocrity. You could call it an action horror game, but that would be making Resident Evil look good. It's quite a different experience from your usual action game. It is one of the most atmospheric horror games that I have ever played (next to Silent Hill 1-3). I found myself coming back to this game every day (or should I say night?). It's just that much fun. The only problem I have with it is the repetitive enemies and their character models, but don't let this deter you from getting this game. It's a very satisfying experience that you will enjoy. Just turn off the lights, up the volume, and get freaked out!

												So far im liking the game. It is atmospheric, aesthetically stunning, and the combat is fantastic. The sound engine is beautiful, and the music raises the tension dramatically. The one problem with the PC version is the awful AWFUL mouse controls. If you are using a mouse and keyboard, feel free to deduct a 2 or 3 from the score I am giving. I have a wired 360 controller to play with and it is an absolute dream. The game is a stunning achievement regarding the horror franchise and I am happy to recommend it to anyone, with prior warning of the controls

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												This game is really well paced, has an excellent story.  Level design is rarely repetitive, and the areas with zero gravity and no air are some of the most interesting challenges the game provides.  The over the shoulder camera works pretty well for a mechanic that is intended to provoke claustrophobia without making you feel like you have to wrestle with it..    The only real criticism I have for it is due to the way I played it.  I tend to meticulously collect all the loot possible, which doesn't always match the narrative, but if you don't do this then you put yourself at a real disadvantage.  That being said, if you do collect and upgrade regularly then medium difficulty is relatively easy.  I think giant, dangerous spaceship machinery killed me more often then enemies.  It's real fun, completely recommend, especially given that you can get it for free on Origin.

												Dead Space the first. If only they made the second as good. Enjoy your laser targets hitting the background and moving on the targets because in Dead Space 2 it becomes much more difficult as it is moved into crosshair mode. I never had any control issues back when I used a R.A.T. 7. I have always liked minimal sensitivity in FPS anyway. I don't find it necessairy to do 1080s. Don't plug joysticks in with mouseplay my Cyborg 3d Gold I would leave plugged in would make my mouse automatically move. A friend told me not to buy it because it was scary. I found it interesting and addicting putting all nightmares aside.

Posted: January 9, 2014
												While it fails at being a horror game (the attempts to scare you are laughable at best) it does suceed at being a really well designed, tense action game. You owe it to yourself to at least check out this game to see what it does with the hud. It basically has no hud and everything is shown on the character. The story was also surprisingly interesting as it only started coming up halfway through the game and didn't overstay its welcome. Overall a strong start to a trilogy. I hope the next one improves on the few flaws this one has
